title: Biden Rolls Back the Trump Legacy
first_paragraph: After an almost normal inaugural ceremony, Biden gets to work. It’s Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

title: What One District Did to Prevent Students From Failing
first_paragraph: Madison Hermosillo started her sophomore year at Roosevelt High School alone in her room, bewildered and quickly falling behind.

title: A School District Vowed to Stay Open, Until Its Staffing Ran Out
first_paragraph: Lizzy Palermo says she was one of the few students in her suburban Georgia high school who consistently wore a mask to classes in the fall. But it didn’t save her from having to quarantine after the district opened buildings in August, as students and staff members came to school with the coronavirus.

title: Biden Unveils National Strategy That Trump Resisted
first_paragraph: President Biden, seeking to assert leadership over the coronavirus pandemic, signed a string of executive orders and presidential directives on Thursday aimed at creating the kind of centralized authority that the Trump administration had shied away from.

title: The Board Voted to Keep Schools Closed. Parents Revolted.
first_paragraph: The anger over the decision to teach fall classes remotely was spelled in chalk on Beth Martin’s sidewalk.

title: Biden rolls out ‘full-scale, wartime’ coronavirus strategy, including requiring masks on some planes, trains and buses.
first_paragraph: President Biden, pledging a “full-scale wartime effort” to combat the coronavirus pandemic, signed a string of executive orders and presidential directives on Thursday aimed at combating the worst public health crisis in a century, including new requirements for masks on interstate planes, trains and buses and for international travelers to quarantine after arriving in the United States.

title: Biden is unveiling a federal pandemic response strategy, which Trump resisted.
first_paragraph: President Biden is using Thursday, his first full day in office, to go on the offensive against the coronavirus, with a 200-page national strategy that includes aggressive use of executive authority to protect workers, advance racial equity and ramp up the manufacturing of test kits, vaccines and supplies.

title: Critic’s notebook: ‘Celebrating America’ promised that daylight is coming.
first_paragraph: Inaugural balls are generally thrown for the winners. After a long, hard-fought campaign, the newly elected leaders, their families and their supporters have a chance to dress up and enjoy themselves.

title: Patty Sakal, A.S.L. Interpreter for Virus Updates, Dies of Covid at 62
first_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: Trump Financial Disclosure Reveals a Business Upended by the Pandemic
first_paragraph: Over the past year, former President Donald J. Trump’s family business suffered steep declines in revenue as the pandemic upended the nation’s hospitality industry, according to a financial disclosure report released hours after Mr. Trump departed office on Wednesday.

title: For Many Across America, a Sigh of Relief as a New Era Begins
first_paragraph: Early Inauguration Day morning, she slipped into her pandemic-era work clothes of gray sweatpants and white shirt and ground the beans. Then, with her mug of coffee, she watched on her kitchen television as the green-and-white helicopter took air, removing from the White House grounds the outgoing 45th president of the United States, Donald J. Trump.

title: Biden’s 17 Executive Orders and Other Directives in Detail
first_paragraph: In 17 executive orders, memorandums and proclamations signed hours after his inauguration, President Biden moved swiftly on Wednesday to dismantle Trump administration policies his aides said have caused the “greatest damage” to the nation.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
first_paragraph: Joe Biden was sworn in as the 46th president of the United States today in a scaled-down pandemic inauguration that was heavy on masks and social distancing.

title: Virtual ‘Parade Across America’ featured dancing, drumlines and dogs.
first_paragraph: With the coronavirus pandemic curtailing the traditional presidential parade from the Capitol to the White House, the inauguration of President Biden replaced it with a made-for-screens montage of performers from all 56 states, territories and Washington, D.C.

title: Big Changes to the SAT
first_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic is hastening sweeping changes to the SAT college entrance exam. The College Board, which produces the test, said that to reduce demands on beleaguered students, the general exam would no longer contain an optional essay section. And subject-matter tests will cease in the United States, too.

title: Biden Inaugurated as the 46th President Amid a Cascade of Crises
first_paragraph: Joseph Robinette Biden Jr. was sworn in on Wednesday as the 46th president of the United States, assuming leadership of a country ravaged by disease, dislocation and division with a call to “end this uncivil war” after four tumultuous years that tore at the fabric of American society.

title: An ‘intensely emotional’ Renée Fleming sings ‘Ave Maria’ and ‘America the Beautiful’ at Inauguration Day Mass.
first_paragraph: Renée Fleming, the superstar soprano who has sung for audiences on the scale of a Super Bowl broadcast, made a more intimate appearance at a private Mass attended by President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris on Wednesday morning.

title: Biden Takes the Wheel
first_paragraph: Preparing to take the helm of a country in crisis, Biden declares: “There’s always light.” It’s Inauguration Day, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

title: On Day 1, Biden Moves to Undo Trump’s Legacy
first_paragraph: President Biden unleashed a full-scale assault on his predecessor’s legacy on Wednesday, acting hours after taking the oath of office to sweep aside President Donald J. Trump’s pandemic response, reverse his environmental agenda, tear down his anti-immigration policies, bolster the sluggish economic recovery and restore federal efforts aimed at promoting diversity.

title: On Night Before Inauguration, Biden Leads Mourning for Virus Victims
first_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. arrived in the nation’s capital on Tuesday for the first time since his election, and on the eve of his inauguration, he did what his predecessor declined to do by leading a national mourning for Americans killed by the coronavirus.

title: In Farewell Video, Trump Repeats Familiar Falsehoods
first_paragraph: President Trump released a farewell video on Tuesday that was replete with inaccurate claims that have become staples of his remarks.

title: Retooling During Pandemic, the SAT Will Drop Essay and Subject Tests
first_paragraph: In the latest sign of trouble for the standardized testing empire that has played a major role in college applications for millions of students, the organization that produces the SAT said on Tuesday that it would scrap subject tests and the optional essay section, further scrambling the admissions process.

title: Justice Dept. Ends Stock Trade Inquiry Into Richard Burr Without Charges
first_paragraph: The Justice Department informed Senator Richard M. Burr, Republican of North Carolina, on Tuesday that it would not pursue insider trading charges against him, quietly ending a monthslong investigation into his dumping of hundreds of thousands of dollars in stock in the turbulent early days of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: In Confirmation Hearings, Biden Aides Indicate Tough Approach on China
first_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s top intelligence, foreign policy and military advisers sought to draw distinctions with the departing Trump administration and lawmakers looked for hints about the new approach, as the Senate opened confirmation hearings for three nominees on Tuesday.

title: California Man Lived Undetected at O’Hare Airport for 3 Months, Officials Say
first_paragraph: As the global pandemic ground many aspects of life to a standstill, millions of people still managed to fly around the country, including more than 29 million on U.S. airlines in October alone.

title: Yellen Outlines Economic Priorities, and Republicans Draw Battle Lines
first_paragraph: Janet L. Yellen, President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s nominee for Treasury secretary, vowed on Tuesday to pursue policies to help workers whose livelihoods have been upended by the pandemic as she warned lawmakers that the U.S. economy faced a painful stretch before coronavirus vaccines were fully deployed.

title: The virus death toll in the U.S. has passed 400,000.
first_paragraph: More than 400,000 people in the United States who had the coronavirus have died, according to data compiled by The New York Times on Tuesday, as the anniversary of the country’s first known death in the pandemic approaches.

title: Critical questions on security, pardons and politics will be answered in the next 24 hours.
first_paragraph: Rain is not in the forecast for President-elect Joseph R. Biden’s inauguration on Wednesday, but uncertainty, sown by his predecessor, will cloud the proceedings.

title: Pandemic Teacher Shortages Imperil In-Person Schooling
first_paragraph: As exposure to the coronavirus forced thousands of teachers across the United States to stay home and quarantine this winter, administrators in the Washoe County School District, which serves 62,000 students in western Nevada, pulled out all the stops to try to continue in-person instruction for students.

title: Trump Orders Lifting of Virus Travel Ban, but Biden Aides Vow to Block Move
first_paragraph: President Trump on Monday ordered an end to the ban on travelers from Europe and Brazil that had been aimed at stopping the spread of the coronavirus to the United States, a move quickly rejected by aides to President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., who said Mr. Biden will maintain the ban when he takes office on Wednesday.

title: Trump lifted coronavirus travel restrictions from Europe and Brazil; Biden team says it won’t last.
first_paragraph: President Trump on Monday ordered an end to the ban on travelers from Europe and Brazil that had been aimed at stopping the spread of the coronavirus to the United States, a move that was quickly rejected by aides to President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., who said Mr. Biden will rescind the move when he takes office on Wednesday.

title: Biden Will Kick Off Inaugural Events at a Ceremony Honoring Victims of Covid-19
first_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. will arrive in the nation’s capital on Tuesday evening for an inauguration eve ceremony at the Lincoln Memorial Reflecting Pool honoring the nearly 400,000 people who have died during the coronavirus pandemic that will be his first priority after he is sworn in the next day.

title: California recommends pausing a batch of Moderna vaccines after possible ‘severe’ allergic reactions.
first_paragraph: The California state epidemiologist has recommended that the state pause the distribution of more than 330,000 doses of the Moderna vaccine after a “higher than usual” number of people showed signs of a possible severe allergic reaction.

title: Yellen Readies Big Changes for Treasury
first_paragraph: Janet L. Yellen, President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s nominee for Treasury Secretary, will tell lawmakers at her confirmation hearing on Tuesday that the United States needs a robust set of fiscal stimulus measures to get the pandemic-stricken economy back on track and that now is not the time to worry about the nation’s mounting debt burden.

title: In Minnesota, a G.O.P. lawmaker’s death brings home the reality of the pandemic.
first_paragraph: Republicans in the Minnesota State Senate were feeling jubilant after the November election. They had held onto a slim majority despite an onslaught by Democrats. Now, it was time to party.

title: In Minnesota, a G.O.P. Lawmaker’s Death Brings Home the Reality of Covid
first_paragraph: Republicans in the Minnesota State Senate were feeling jubilant after the November election. They had held onto a slim majority following an onslaught by Democrats trying to win control. Now, it was time to party.

title: As the U.S. surpasses 24 million cases, Los Angeles confronts a more contagious variant.
first_paragraph: As the total number of U.S. coronavirus cases surpassed 24 million on Monday, Los Angeles County, one of the hardest-hit areas, may face even more dire weeks ahead. Deaths in the county have continued to climb as the national death toll nears 400,000.

title: As Biden seeks to jump-start his term, law enforcement braces for possible violence.
first_paragraph: With the inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden just three days away, an air of anxiety hovered over Washington and state capitals across the country, as they braced for the possibility of more violence after right-wing extremists stormed the Capitol this month in a bid to stop President Trump’s loss from being certified.

title: Alan Canfora, Who Carried Wounds From Kent State, Dies at 71
first_paragraph: In April 1970, Alan Canfora, a junior at Kent State University in Ohio, was outraged when a friend was killed in the Vietnam War. He was infuriated all the more when President Richard M. Nixon announced an expansion of the war into Cambodia.

title: Before the Capitol Riot, Calls for Cash and Talk of Revolution
first_paragraph: Keith Lee, an Air Force veteran and former police detective, spent the morning of Jan. 6 casing the entrances to the Capitol.

title: Biden promises a ‘bold’ federal vaccination campaign.
first_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., racing against a surge in coronavirus cases and the emergence of a new variant that could worsen the crisis, is planning a vaccination offensive that calls for greatly expanding access to the vaccine while using a wartime law to increase production.

title: A First for an American President, and a First for Donald Trump
first_paragraph: When President Trump faced (and overcame) the gravest crisis of his first campaign, he defended his boasts of sexual assault on the “Access Hollywood” tape as ultimately harmless gabbing. “Locker room talk,” he said, nothing to dwell on.

title: U.S. Executes Dustin Higgs for Role in 3 1996 Murders
first_paragraph: The Trump administration executed Dustin J. Higgs early Saturday for his part in a triple murder in 1996, marking the 13th and final scheduled federal execution under President Trump.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
first_paragraph: China is experiencing its worst surge of the virus since the summer, forcing 28 million people into lockdown and challenging the government’s success in subduing the disease.

title: Tom Lankford, 85, Dies; Southern Journalist With Divided Loyalties
first_paragraph: Tom Lankford, who as a reporter for The Birmingham News took some of the most memorable photos of the civil rights era even as he worked hand in glove with the city’s police department and the F.B.I., sometimes landing scoops in exchange for things like wiretapping members of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s family, died on Dec. 31 in a hospital in Gadsden, Ala., about 50 miles northeast of Birmingham. He was 85.

title: How the New Variant Could Affect Kids and Schools
first_paragraph: A new variant of the coronavirus, first identified in Britain, is expected to rapidly spread in the United States. That has fueled fears that children, who have largely been spared the worst of the virus, may become just as susceptible and contagious as adults.

title: The Big Promises Biden Is Making
first_paragraph: Biden asks Americans to “imagine a future” beyond the virus, pushing a $1.9 trillion plan to promote jobs and prosperity. It’s Friday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

title: More Than Half of States Widen Access to Vaccine, Raising Hopes as Well as Chaos
first_paragraph: When New Mexico announced that it was expanding the pool of people eligible to get a coronavirus vaccine to residents 75 and older, Anthony Kump, who is 80, immediately signed up.

title: Top Official at Indian Health Service Will Step Down
first_paragraph: The director of the Indian Health Service has said that he will resign, giving President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. a chance to install new leadership at an agency that has drawn intense criticism for its failures to provide adequate care to tribal communities both before and during the pandemic.

title: Overwhelmed, More States Turn to National Guard for Vaccine Help
first_paragraph: As tens of thousands of his National Guard colleagues descended on the nation’s capital to ensure the peaceful transfer of presidential power, 10 miles up the road, Emmanuel Alfaro was doing what he viewed as the pinnacle of his career in the Guard: administering Covid-19 vaccines to his fellow citizens.

title: Adriano Espaillat is the latest member of Congress to test positive for the virus after Capitol siege.
first_paragraph: Representative Adriano Espaillat, Democrat of New York, announced on Thursday he had tested positive for the coronavirus, as concerns continue to mount on Capitol Hill that efforts to corral lawmakers into secure locations during last week’s siege by Trump supporters may have led to a super-spreader event.

title: Julia Letlow, whose husband died of Covid-19 before being sworn into Congress, will run for the seat.
first_paragraph: Julia Letlow, the wife of Representative-elect Luke Letlow, a Louisiana Republican who died of complications from Covid-19 days before he was to be sworn in, will seek the open seat in an upcoming special election.

title: Here are the highlights of Biden’s $1.9 trillion ‘American Rescue Plan.’
first_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Thursday proposed a $1.9 trillion rescue package to combat the economic downturn and the Covid-19 crisis, outlining the type of sweeping aid that Democrats have demanded for months and signaling the shift in the federal government’s pandemic response as Mr. Biden prepares to take office next week.

title: As His Predecessor Is Impeached, Biden Tries to Stay Above the Fray
first_paragraph: His fellow Democrats are red hot with rage after the assault on the Capitol, but President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has maintained a studied cool, staying largely removed from the searing debate that culminated on Wednesday with President Trump’s impeachment and keeping his focus on battling a deadly pandemic, reviving a faltering economy and lowering the political temperature.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
first_paragraph: As Americans focus their attention on the fallout from the Capitol siege and the debate over another presidential impeachment, the pandemic is reaching what only a few months ago was considered a nightmare scenario.

title: Private Schools Cashed in on P.P.P. Funding
first_paragraph: This spring, when the federal government disbursed billions of dollars in emergency pandemic funding, the traditional K-12 public schools in Los Angeles got an average of about $716,000.

title: Biden to Restore Homeland Security and Cybersecurity Aides to Senior White House Posts
first_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., facing the rise of domestic terrorism and a crippling cyberattack from Russia, is elevating two White House posts that all but disappeared in the Trump administration: a homeland security adviser to manage matters as varied as extremism, pandemics and natural disasters, and the first deputy national security adviser for cyber and emerging technology.

title: Puerto Rico’s Deposed Governor Describes His Family’s Panicked Flight From the Island
first_paragraph: Puerto Rico had just announced its first three cases of Covid-19 last March, a curfew was coming, and Ricardo A. Rosselló, the scientist-turned-governor who had resigned in disgrace months earlier, saw an opening.

title: Supreme Court Revives Abortion-Pill Restriction
first_paragraph: In the Supreme Court’s first ruling on abortion since the arrival of Justice Amy Coney Barrett, the court on Tuesday reinstated a federal requirement that women seeking to end their pregnancies using medications pick up a pill in person from a hospital or medical office.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
first_paragraph: In an attempt to speed up the sluggish pace of the U.S. vaccination campaign, the Trump administration changed course today and instructed states to immediately begin vaccinating Americans over 65, as well as adults with conditions that make them more vulnerable to the virus.

title: Atop the Powerful Budget Committee at Last, Bernie Sanders Wants to Go Big
first_paragraph: Shortly before the 2016 election, Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin, the Republican nominee for vice president and the speaker of the House, told a group of college Republicans why he thought Democrats winning control of the Senate would be a policy nightmare.

title: States Told to Vaccinate Everyone 65 and Over as Deaths Surge
first_paragraph: The Trump administration, racing a surging Covid-19 death toll, instructed states on Tuesday to immediately begin vaccinating every American 65 and older, as well as tens of millions of adults with medical conditions that put them at higher risk of dying from coronavirus infection.

title: Three lawmakers test positive after being in lockdown at the Capitol.
first_paragraph: Three members of Congress who have tested positive for the coronavirus this week say they believe their infections are linked to their time spent in a secure location with colleagues who did not wear masks during the rampage last week in the U.S. Capitol.

title: Gorillas at Zoo in San Diego Test Positive for Coronavirus
first_paragraph: Several gorillas at the San Diego Zoo Safari Park have tested positive for the coronavirus, becoming what federal officials said on Monday were the first known apes in the nation to be infected.

title: Did Mixing a Riot With a Pandemic Yield a Superspreader Event?
first_paragraph: A grim reality has begun to dawn on Capitol Hill: The riot on Wednesday may have started a coronavirus superspreader event, fueled by the mob that roamed through the halls of Congress and unmasked Republicans who jammed into cloistered secure rooms.

title: State Capitols ‘on High Alert,’ Fearing More Violence
first_paragraph: It was opening day of the 2021 legislative session, and the perimeter of the Georgia State Capitol on Monday was bristling with state police officers in full camouflage gear, most of them carrying tactical rifles.

title: Reeling From a Riot, Washington Faces Rising Coronavirus Cases
first_paragraph: While Mayor Muriel E. Bowser of Washington, D.C., was grappling with the riot that tore through the Capitol last week, another crisis was slowly unfolding: a surge of coronavirus in the district.

title: Troops Flood a Rattled Washington Ahead of the Biden Inauguration
first_paragraph: Law enforcement authorities, responding to threats of violence before the Jan. 20 presidential inauguration, will deploy up to 15,000 National Guard troops to the nation’s capital and set up checkpoints in the city to avoid the botched response that helped rioters overrun the Capitol last week.

title: ‘It Became Sort of Lawless’: Florida Vaccine Rollout Turns Into a Free-for-All
first_paragraph: Linda Kleindienst Bruns registered for a coronavirus vaccine in late December, on the first day the health department in Tallahassee, Fla., opened for applications for people her age. Despite being 72, with her immune system suppressed by medication that keeps her breast cancer in remission, she spent days waiting to hear back about an appointment.

title: Major Technology Companies Join List of Biden Inaugural Donors
first_paragraph: Major technology companies like Google and Microsoft, as well as telecommunications giants like Comcast and Verizon, are among the nearly 1,000 people and groups that have donated at least $200 to the committee organizing President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s scaled-back inauguration celebration this month.

title: In Michigan, a Dress Rehearsal for the Chaos at the Capitol on Wednesday
first_paragraph: First came the “Unlock Michigan” protest. More than 1,000 cars, many draped with flags supporting President Trump, drove around the Michigan State Capitol, blaring their horns and decrying Gov. Gretchen Whitmer’s coronavirus lockdown orders. Hundreds of others, many armed with military-style weapons, milled about on the lawn.

title: ‘Our New York Moment’: Southern California Reels as Virus Surges
first_paragraph: A sustained surge of coronavirus infections has locked Southern California in crisis, overwhelming intensive care wards, ambulance services, funeral homes and local officials.

title: Biden Plans Coronavirus Vaccination Blitz After Inauguration
first_paragraph: In a sharp break with the Trump administration, President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. intends to release nearly all available doses of the coronavirus vaccine soon after he is inaugurated, rather than hold back millions of vials to guarantee second doses will be available.

title: Facing Intensifying Crises, Biden Pledges Action to Address Economy and Pandemic
first_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Friday promised an accelerated response to a daunting and intensifying array of challenges as the economy showed new signs of weakness, the coronavirus pandemic killed more Americans than ever, and Congress weighed impeaching President Trump a second time.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
first_paragraph: Weeks into the American vaccination effort and the country is terribly behind schedule. Of the roughly 21.5 million doses that have been distributed, only about six million have been injected into the arms of Americans, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: The virus spread faster in counties where large universities held classes in person.
first_paragraph: The spread of the coronavirus accelerated sharply in U.S. counties where large universities held classes in person last fall, federal health researchers reported on Wednesday.

title: Los Angeles County urges ambulance crews not to bring to hospitals patients they cannot resuscitate.
first_paragraph: With hospitals in Los Angeles County swamped with Covid-19 patients, a memo that went out to the county’s ambulance crews last week caused public alarm and prompted explanations from medics on social media about their care practices.

title: As State Legislatures Aim to Convene Amid Covid, One Tries a Drive-In
first_paragraph: New Hampshire’s House of Representatives convened on Wednesday morning in a parking lot, whipped by an icy wind and drowned out by occasional passing freight trains, in a legislative improvisation worthy of Rube Goldberg.

title: A congressman who voted against certification tests positive for Covid-19.
first_paragraph: Representative Jake LaTurner, Republican of Kansas, announced that he received a positive test result for the coronavirus on Wednesday night, after he spent the day participating in a failed effort to stop Congress from formally certifying President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory.

title: Biden Denounces Storming of Capitol as a ‘Dark Moment’ in Nation’s History
first_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. denounced the storming of the Capitol on Wednesday as the violent expression of President Trump’s refusal to accept his defeat, calling it “an assault on the citadel of liberty” and saying the president had stoked the mob with his brazen and false claims that the 2020 election had been stolen.

title: Governors from both parties denounce violence at the Capitol.
first_paragraph: Governors across the country condemned angry mobs of President Trump’s supporters who stormed the Capitol on Wednesday, and called on the president to publicly denounce their actions.

title: Suspect in Attempted Murder of Police Officer Escapes From Holding Cell
first_paragraph: The police in Portland, Ore., are still searching for a suspect in an attempted murder who escaped from a precinct station house on Saturday after a cleaning crew left the door to the holding cell he was in unlocked, the authorities said on Wednesday.

title: New Year, New Drama in New York Schools
first_paragraph: Will New York City keep schools open for young children and those with the most complex disabilities, even as its virus numbers climb? The answer remains unclear as the political battle lines were redrawn yet again this week.

title: Democrats Win Both Georgia Races to Gain Control of Senate
first_paragraph: Jon Ossoff completed a Democratic sweep of Georgia’s Senate runoffs on Wednesday, a striking political validation for his party in a state that has been challenging for Democrats for most of the last two decades.

title: Arizona, Roiled by Covid in Summer, Faces Even Worse Outbreak Now
first_paragraph: The summer surge that raged across the Sun Belt started in Arizona. For more than a month, from early June until mid July, the state added cases at the highest per capita rate in the country. Thousands died. Hospitals were stretched thin. At the peak, more than 3,800 cases were emerging each day.

title: Warning of Shortages, Researchers Look to Stretch Vaccine Supply
first_paragraph: Federal officials and drugmakers, faced with a slower-than-expected rollout of the coronavirus vaccine, are racing to find ways to expand the supply, looking at lowering the required dosage and extracting more doses from the supplies they have.

title: Second doses have begun for the earliest U.S. vaccine recipients.
first_paragraph: After Sandra Lindsay became the first person in the United States to receive a Covid-19 vaccination outside a clinical trial, something unexpected happened: She acquired a fan club.

title: A pharmacist accused of sabotaging vaccine doses is a conspiracy theorist, the police say.
first_paragraph: A pharmacist who was arrested on charges that he intentionally sabotaged more than 500 doses of the Covid-19 vaccine at a Wisconsin hospital was “an admitted conspiracy theorist” who believed the vaccine could harm people and “change their DNA,” according to the police in Grafton, Wis., where the man was employed.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
first_paragraph: In the week since our last newsletter, U.S. distribution of coronavirus vaccines has descended into turmoil. Now, millions of vaccines could expire before they reach people in need.

title: Running low on oxygen, emergency workers in Los Angeles County are told to administer the minimum necessary.
first_paragraph: California’s daily coronavirus case tallies remain around four times what they were during the state’s summer surge, and officials predict that the aftereffects of a December surge linked to holiday gatherings will worsen as the winter drags on.

title: Biden Plans Minimalist Trip From Capitol to White House on Inauguration Day
first_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s inaugural committee released new details on Sunday about his trip to the White House after his swearing-in at the U.S. Capitol that further underscore the downsized and largely virtual nature of his Inauguration Day plans.

title: Nancy Pelosi Secures Another Term as Speaker, as Senate Hangs in Balance
first_paragraph: Democrats returned Representative Nancy Pelosi of California to the House speakership on Sunday for what may be her final term, handing a tested leader control of the slimmest majority in almost two decades as Washington prepares for a new Democratic president.

title: As the Virus Spikes, Vaccine Distribution Is One More Hurdle for States
first_paragraph: The coronavirus vaccine may end the pandemic at some point, but for now its slow rollout is straining relations between the federal government and states and cities, and is adding one more huge challenge for overstressed health departments.

title: Inflatable Costume May Be Behind Outbreak at California Hospital
first_paragraph: An air-powered, inflatable costume, worn by a staff member on Christmas to spread holiday cheer, may be to blame for a coronavirus outbreak that infected dozens of workers in a hospital in San Jose, Calif., a hospital spokeswoman said.

title: The Los Angeles area is hit with a Christmas coronavirus surge.
first_paragraph: Los Angeles County, already in the throes of a devastating surge in coronavirus cases after Thanksgiving travel and gatherings, is being hit with a spike from Christmas festivities.

title: Homes of Mitch McConnell and Nancy Pelosi Are Reported Vandalized
first_paragraph: The homes of Senator Mitch McConnell and Speaker Nancy Pelosi, the two most powerful members of Congress, have been reported vandalized, days after the contentious passage of a stimulus bill that has been criticized as inadequate by a broad coalition ranging from progressive activists to President Trump.

title: ‘From Crisis to Crisis’: The Moments That Defined a Historic Congress
first_paragraph: It began with a pair of firsts, one hopeful and one grim: The most diverse Congress in the nation’s history was sworn in two years ago during the longest government shutdown.

title: In Abrupt Reversal of Iran Strategy, Pentagon Orders Aircraft Carrier Home
first_paragraph: The Pentagon has abruptly sent the aircraft carrier Nimitz home from the Middle East and Africa over the objections of top military advisers, marking a reversal of a weekslong muscle-flexing strategy aimed at deterring Iran from attacking American troops and diplomats in the Persian Gulf.

title: Without Trump, or Masks, Mar-a-Lago Partied On
first_paragraph: President Trump’s private social club in Palm Beach, Fla., hosted a New Year’s Eve gala at which revelers without masks dined indoors and danced to performances by Vanilla Ice and members of the Beach Boys.

title: States Are Shutting Down Prisons as Guards are Crippled By Covid-19
first_paragraph: Battered by a wave of coronavirus infections and deaths, local jails and state prison systems around the United States have resorted to a drastic strategy to keep the virus at bay: Shutting down completely and transferring their inmates elsewhere.

title: In a Widening News Desert on the Border, a Tabloid Start-Up Defies the Odds
first_paragraph: At the Chihuahuan Desert’s eastern limits, in a parking lot above Lake Amistad, Brian Argabright photographed anglers and their catch at the Border Bass Battle for The Del Rio News-Herald, a chronicler of the wind-swept border town since 1884.

title: Shhh! In Los Angeles, New Year’s Eve parties are still happening.
first_paragraph: Throughout the coronavirus pandemic, well-attended parties have mostly been shut down across Los Angeles, which has led to a culture of secrecy on social media.

title: Chief Justice Praises the Courts’ Responses to the Pandemic
first_paragraph: The nation’s courts have reacted nimbly to the coronavirus pandemic, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. wrote in his year-end report on the state of the federal judiciary.

title: AstraZeneca and Sinopharm clear regulatory hurdles in a week of vaccine milestones.
first_paragraph: The world hit a few more pandemic milestones this week with the distribution of the coronavirus vaccines developed by Moderna and by Pfizer and BioNTech; the advancement of trials studying other experimental shots; and the approval or authorization of coronavirus vaccines in several countries. The welcome news comes as the number of known infections worldwide rises toward 83 million.

title: Confetti falls on a deserted Times Square as New York forges ahead.
first_paragraph: The minute before midnight in Times Square was almost unrecognizable as New York City closed out one of the most difficult and wrenching years in its history.

title: 42 people in West Virginia are mistakenly given a virus treatment instead of the vaccine.
first_paragraph: Forty-two people in Boone County, in southwestern West Virginia, who were scheduled to receive the coronavirus vaccine on Wednesday were mistakenly injected with an experimental monoclonal antibody treatment instead, the West Virginia National Guard said on Thursday.

title: Trump’s Focus as the Pandemic Raged: What Would It Mean for Him?
first_paragraph: It was a warm summer Wednesday, Election Day was looming and President Trump was even angrier than usual at the relentless focus on the coronavirus pandemic.

title: A pharmacist is arrested after he allegedly allowed more than 500 vaccine doses to spoil.
first_paragraph: A pharmacist at a Wisconsin hospital has been arrested and accused of intentionally removing more than 500 doses of coronavirus vaccine from refrigeration last week, knowing that the vaccines would be rendered useless and that the people receiving them would think they were protected against the virus when they were not, the police department in Grafton, Wisconsin, said Thursday.

title: Joy Survives: Your Positive Moments From 2020
first_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has killed more than 1.3 million people around the world. Millions more have lost their jobs, and governments have offered uneven support. In the United States, a reckoning with race and discrimination poured into the streets during the summer, and its effects have rippled into the fall. The country’s presidential election brought record-breaking turnout but led to a debate over the very essence of the democratic process.

title: ‘The Other Half of My Soul’: Widows of Covid-19 Bond Over Sudden Loss
first_paragraph: One Friday evening, Sandra McGowan-Watts, a 46-year-old doctor from suburban Chicago, opened her laptop, stifled her nerves and told strangers on a Zoom call what had happened to her husband, Steven.

title: When the virus variant came to a tiny Colorado town.
first_paragraph: Simla, Colo., an isolated ranching community on the high plains, is the last place locals expect to be first for anything, especially a new, more infectious variant of the coronavirus.

title: Critics Say Nashville Police Could Have Done More With Tip About Bomber
first_paragraph: The woman was clearly in distress, sitting on her front porch with a pair of unloaded pistols beside her when the police arrived in August of last year. The weapons belonged to her boyfriend, Anthony Warner, she told the officers, and she wanted them gone. And, she added, Mr. Warner was building bombs inside the R.V. parked at his house.

title: The Small Colorado Town Felt Insulated From the Pandemic. Then Came the Coronavirus Variant.
first_paragraph: An isolated ranching community on the high plains is the last place its residents expect to be first for anything, especially a new, more infectious variant of the coronavirus. But on Wednesday, state health officials announced that the first known case of the variant in the United States had been confirmed at a nursing home in Simla, Colo.

title: Closing of Air Traffic Control Center for Virus Cleaning Halts Flights in Dallas
first_paragraph: An air traffic control center that serves Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport was closed for several hours on Wednesday for cleaning after an employee tested positive for the coronavirus, grounding flights at one of the world’s busiest hubs.

title: ‘No Realistic Path’ for Quick Vote on $2,000 Stimulus Checks, McConnell Says
first_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell effectively killed off any chance that Congress would increase stimulus checks to $2,000 before President Trump leaves office, saying there was “no realistic path” for the Senate to pass a stand-alone bill.

title: McConnell Blocks Vote on $2,000 Checks Despite G.O.P. Pressure
first_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell blocked an attempt by Democrats on Tuesday to hold an immediate vote on increasing stimulus checks to $2,000 from $600, leaving the fate of the measure unclear as President Trump continued to demand the larger payouts and more Republicans publicly endorsed the idea.

title: Biden Criticizes Trump on Vaccine Distribution and Pledges to Pick Up Pace
first_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Tuesday criticized the speed of vaccine distribution under the Trump administration and promised to step up the pace when he takes office, while delivering a sober warning about the toll of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: When Nashville Bombing Hit a Telecom Hub, the Ripples Reached Far Beyond
first_paragraph: On Christmas morning, emergency officials in the small Alabama town of Cullman found themselves nearly cut off from the outside world.

title: How the Pandemic Has Been Devastating for Children From Low-Income Families
first_paragraph: Since the coronavirus arrived in her neighborhood in Southeast Washington, D.C., this past spring, 11-year-old Grenderline Etheridge has burst into tears many times for reasons she cannot explain. She has crawled into bed with her mother, something she had not done for a very long time.

title: Vaccinations have begun at the nursing home hit by the first U.S. virus cluster.
first_paragraph: A nurse at the suburban Seattle nursing home that was ravaged by the first U.S. cluster of coronavirus cases sat down beside a visiting pharmacist on Monday, pulled up her blue shirtsleeve and received the first dose of the Covid-19 vaccine administered at the facility.

title: A Tornado, a Pandemic and Now a Bombing: ‘Nashville Strong’ Is Tested
first_paragraph: Nashville did not need another test of its grit. Over the years, the city was strong after the Cumberland River surged beyond its banks, and it clawed its way back from tornadoes.

title: Trump’s Veto Threat Did Little to Alter Stimulus Package
first_paragraph: As an exercise in raw presidential power, it was a flop. As a political tactic, it backfired. And as a coda to his final weeks in office, President Trump’s threat to veto a $900 billion Covid relief and government funding bill merely underscored his tumultuous tenure in the Oval Office.

title: What the Vaccine Side Effects Feel Like, According to Those Who’ve Gotten It
first_paragraph: Two and a half hours after being injected with a Covid-19 vaccine, Dr. Taneisha Wilson was hit with the worst headache of her life.

title: A Cheerleader’s Vulgar Message Prompts a First Amendment Showdown
first_paragraph: It was a Saturday in the spring of 2017, and a ninth-grade student in Pennsylvania was having a bad day. She had just learned that she had failed to make the varsity cheerleading squad and would remain on junior varsity.

title: How the Pandemic Is Imperiling a Working-Class College
first_paragraph: Rachel Foor’s grandparents are in their 70s, so when the pandemic hit, its stresses gave her such stomach pains that she could not eat or sleep. She worried she would infect them if she brought the coronavirus home from Indiana University of Pennsylvania, where she is a senior, or from Walmart, where she stocks milk and eggs to help pay tuition.

title: 1 of every 17 people in the U.S. has been infected, and 1 in 1,000 has died. Yet the worst may lie ahead.
first_paragraph: With bubble-enclosed Santas and Zoom-enhanced family gatherings, much of the United States played it safe over Christmas while the coronavirus rampaged across the country.

title: The Treasured Diners and Hidden Haunts That Covid-19 Closed for Good
first_paragraph: We gather today to mourn the 150-year-old restaurant that served up platters of fried chicken and creamed corn to Abilene, Kan. To bid farewell to the New Orleans cafe that was a destination for huge crab omelets and endless conversation. To raise one last glass to the tavern in Cambridge, Mass., where the regulars arrived at 8 a.m. and the Austin diner where Janis Joplin nearly sang the neon lights off the walls.

title: Jobless Benefits Run Out as Trump Resists Signing Relief Bill
first_paragraph: Millions of Americans lost their unemployment coverage on Saturday as President Trump resisted signing a sweeping $900 billion aid package until lawmakers more than tripled the size of relief checks, putting the fate of the measure in limbo.

title: A Stinging Setback in California Is a Warning for Democrats in 2022
first_paragraph: Two years ago, Democrats celebrated a sweep of seven Republican-held congressional seats in California as evidence of the party’s growing ability to compete in swing districts here and across the nation.

title: Unemployment Aid Set to Lapse Saturday as Trump’s Plans for Relief Bill Remain Unclear
first_paragraph: Expanded unemployment benefits were set to lapse for millions of struggling Americans on Saturday, a day after President Trump expressed more criticism of a $900 billion pandemic relief bill that was awaiting his signature and would extend them.

title: Southern California’s Hospitals Are Overwhelmed, and It May Get Worse
first_paragraph: If this were any other year, members of the Los Angeles Opera would have been singing Christmas carols this week in the wards of Martin Luther King Jr. Community Hospital, which serves the largely poor and Latino communities of South Los Angeles. Instead, a street choir from Skid Row stepped in with a video to bring holiday cheer to the growing number of dying coronavirus patients and traumatized staff.

title: In Bethlehem and Jolly and Antlers, an American Christmas
first_paragraph: The roads were icy in Frostburg, Md. In Jolly, Texas, the mood was somber. Still, despite a season filled with challenges at every turn, by the time I got to Snowbird, Utah, it was clear that the holidays were in full swing.

title: U.S. Will Require a Negative Coronavirus Test for All Travelers From U.K.
first_paragraph: The United States will require all airline passengers arriving from Britain to test negative for the coronavirus within 72 hours of their departure, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Thursday.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
first_paragraph: Despite Dr. Anthony Fauci’s claim of having vaccinated Santa Claus and NORAD’s annual wink-wink tracking of his sleigh, this is clearly an interrupted holiday season from pole to pole.

title: Covid-19 Patient Is Bludgeoned to Death in California Hospital
first_paragraph: An 82-year-old man who was being treated for Covid-19 at a hospital north of Los Angeles was bludgeoned to death with an oxygen tank last week by his roommate, the authorities said.

title: Facing Deportation, They Fled to the Safety of a Church. Now They Are Free.
first_paragraph: Hand in hand, Oneita and Clive Thompson danced out of the Tabernacle United Church in Philadelphia, their fists raised in victory. The Jamaican couple had spent nearly two and a half years living in churches to avoid deportation.

title: Disadvantaged Students More Likely to Be Learning Remotely, Study Finds
first_paragraph: Disadvantaged students are much more likely than others to be engaged in remote schooling during the coronavirus pandemic, increasing the risk that less effective instruction will widen the achievement gap, according to the first comprehensive analysis of attendance patterns.

title: On Working With Congress, Biden Predicts Success Where Predecessors Failed
first_paragraph: When he takes office next month, President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. will confront a sharply divided Congress where many Republicans argued that his election was fraudulent.

title: A Christmas Eve ‘Travel Nightmare’: Snow, Flooding, Maybe Tornadoes
first_paragraph: A nasty winter storm slammed the eastern United States on Christmas Eve, pushing drivers off the roads and threatening to spoil the plans of holiday travelers and last-minute shoppers in a season already dampened by the coronavirus.

title: Answering Trump, Democrats Try and Fail to Jam $2,000 Payments Through House
first_paragraph: The fate of $900 billion in pandemic aid will remain in limbo over the Christmas break after House Democrats tried and failed on Thursday to more than triple the size of relief checks, then adjourned the House until Monday, when they will try again.

title: For Christmas, Pastors Offer Comfort and Joy in a Somber Season
first_paragraph: When the Rev. Timothy Cole learned he had Covid-19 in early March, it was the first known case of the virus in Washington. Mr. Cole, the rector of Christ Church Georgetown, was hospitalized for three weeks.

title: In the Rio Grande Valley, Death Has Become a Family Affair
first_paragraph: Days after her Thanksgiving feast was prepared, served and eaten, Maribel Rodriguez tried to muster the will to unpack the tree, lights and decorations of boisterous Christmases past.

title: Trump’s Attack on Coronavirus Relief Divides G.O.P. and Threatens Recovery
first_paragraph: President Trump’s denunciation of the $900 billion coronavirus relief deal drove a wedge through the Republican Party on Wednesday, drawing harsh criticism from House Republicans and threatening the delivery of unemployment checks, a reprieve on evictions and direct payments to struggling Americans.

title: Pfizer Seals Deal With U.S. for 100 Million More Vaccine Doses
first_paragraph: The Trump administration and Pfizer announced a deal on Wednesday for the pharmaceutical company to provide an additional 100 million doses of its coronavirus vaccine by the end of July, easing a potential shortage.

title: How Trump Has Jeopardized Stimulus Relief
first_paragraph: President Trump on Tuesday unexpectedly threatened to reject a far-reaching, catchall spending package that includes $900 billion in coronavirus relief and funding for the government through Sept. 30. The threat in effect dropped a depth charge on the Republican Party, but beyond politics, the coming days will determine whether his actions actually deny or delay relief to struggling Americans and shut down the government.

title: Isolation Helps Homeless Population Escape Worst of Virus
first_paragraph: Under a highway overpass in downtown Oakland, Camilla Everette sleeps on a couch, with a blue-and-white-striped summer parasol offering the only protection from the drops of rainwater that fall from the concrete above her.

title: Passenger Who Had Medical Emergency on Flight Died of Covid-19, Coroner Says
first_paragraph: A coroner in Louisiana confirmed on Tuesday what some had feared: that the death last week of a 69-year-old man who experienced a medical emergency aboard a United Airlines flight bound for Los Angeles had been caused by Covid-19.

title: Buried in Pandemic Aid Bill: Billions to Soothe the Richest
first_paragraph: Tucked away in the 5,593-page spending bill that Congress rushed through on Monday night is a provision that some tax experts call a $200 billion giveaway to the rich.

title: Biden, Calling Stimulus Bill a ‘Down Payment,’ Urges More Relief
first_paragraph: A day after Congress approved a hard-fought $900 billion stimulus package, President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. called the measure a “down payment” on Tuesday and vowed to enter office next month asking lawmakers to return to the negotiating table.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
first_paragraph: Hundreds of dollars in direct payments could begin reaching Americans as early as next week, after Congress overwhelmingly passed a $900 billion pandemic relief package on Monday night.

title: The Second Stimulus Package: Here’s What’s Included
first_paragraph: Unveiling the second major stimulus bill of the pandemic, Congress on Monday approved a $900 billion package aimed at addressing the needs of millions of Americans who have been forced to weather the effects of the coronavirus for months even as many existing federal aid programs ran thin or expired.

title: Pfizer Nears Deal With Trump Administration to Provide More Vaccine Doses
first_paragraph: The Trump administration and Pfizer are close to a deal under which the pharmaceutical company would bolster supply of its coronavirus vaccine for the United States by at least tens of millions of doses next year in exchange for a government directive giving it better access to manufacturing supplies, people familiar with the discussions said.

title: Alex Padilla Will Replace Kamala Harris in the Senate
first_paragraph: Alex Padilla, California’s secretary of state, has been appointed to fill the Senate seat held by Vice President-elect Kamala Harris, Gov. Gavin Newsom announced on Tuesday, capping months of intense political jockeying among Democratic factions in the state.

title: Public schools face a funding ‘death spiral’ as enrollment falls during remote learning.
first_paragraph: Public schools in many parts of the country are headed for a financial cliff, as the coronavirus drives up the costs of education while tax revenue and student enrollment continue to fall.

title: Public Schools Face Funding ‘Death Spiral’ as Enrollment Drops
first_paragraph: In Texas, the Austin public schools might lay off 200 people and still not fill the financial hole created by the coronavirus. Gov. Jay Inslee of Washington has proposed two new taxes to help pay for catching up students who fell behind during remote learning. And in Los Angeles, the costs of virus testing, laptops and free meals for families have mounted to more than $400 million.

title: Biden Picks Latino Chief of Connecticut Schools as Education Secretary
first_paragraph: In August, Connecticut’s schools chief, Miguel A. Cardona, logged on to a virtual meeting of New Haven’s school board, ostensibly to hear why its members had decided not to open the state’s largest school district for in-person classes this fall.

title: A Dinner, a Deal and Moonshine: How the Stimulus Came Together
first_paragraph: A week before Thanksgiving, a small group of moderate senators gathered in the spacious living room of Senator Lisa Murkowski’s home on Capitol Hill to embark on what they considered an urgent assignment.

title: Senate Candidates Duel in Georgia as G.O.P. Voters’ Anger Persists
first_paragraph: Five Republicans spoke at a rally on Monday in suburban Atlanta, including two state lawmakers, Senators Kelly Loeffler and David Perdue, and Ivanka Trump, the president’s daughter and senior adviser.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
first_paragraph: This weekend, Britain imposed a wholesale lockdown on London and most of the country’s southeast, citing fears about a new strain of the coronavirus, which officials say is more contagious..

title: Virus Hits Federal Death Row, Prompting Calls for Delays in Executions
first_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic is sweeping through death row at the federal penitentiary in Terre Haute, Ind., with at least 14 of the roughly 50 men there having tested positive, lawyers for the prisoners and others familiar with their cases said.

title: Pandemic Aid Bolsters Biden and Shows Potential Path for His Agenda in Congress
first_paragraph: Producing it was a torturous, time-consuming affair that did nothing to improve Congress’s reputation for dysfunction. But the agreement on a new pandemic aid package showed the ascendance of moderates as a new force in a divided Senate and validated President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s belief that it is still possible to make deals on Capitol Hill.

title: Biden receives the coronavirus vaccine.
first_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. received the coronavirus vaccine on live television on Monday at Christiana Hospital in Newark, Del., sending a message to Americans across the country that the vaccine is safe to take.

title: Not an Ideal Process or an Ideal Agreement, but, Finally, a Deal
first_paragraph: On the day before Thanksgiving, Dave Query had to close his restaurant for good. For some 26 years, Zolo Grill had been a popular eatery in Boulder offering Southwestern fare. But the slowdown in business, he said, and the cost of complying with state and county safety protocols became too much.

title: Congress Strikes Long-Sought Stimulus Deal to Provide $900 Billion in Aid
first_paragraph: Congressional leaders on Sunday reached a hard-fought agreement on a $900 billion stimulus package that would send immediate aid to Americans and businesses to help them cope with the economic devastation of the pandemic and fund the distribution of vaccines.

title: Devastated long-term care facilities become the next front for Covid-19 inoculations.
first_paragraph: A large swath of nursing homes in the United States are poised to receive Covid-19 vaccines beginning Monday, as the country pushes to inoculate some of its most vulnerable citizens and free them from months of confinement.

title: A President Who Can’t Put Aside Grudges, Even for Good News
first_paragraph: It was among the most consequential weeks of President Trump’s tenure: Across the country, health care workers began receiving a lifesaving coronavirus vaccine. On Capitol Hill, lawmakers closed in on a deal for economic relief aimed at averting a deeper recession. And on Friday, federal regulators authorized a second vaccine.

title: Lawmakers Resolve Fed Dispute as They Race to Close Stimulus Deal
first_paragraph: Senators broke through an impasse late Saturday night over a Republican effort to curtail the powers of the Federal Reserve, clearing away what had been seen as the final hurdle to a deal on a $900 billion stimulus package as lawmakers raced against a Sunday-night deadline to avoid a government shutdown.

title: Americans Scraping By Say They Fear a Second Stimulus Won’t Be Enough
first_paragraph: With millions of Americans out of work and at risk of losing their homes, Congress’s failure to quickly reach a deal that would send more money to struggling families is increasingly frustrating those hit by the economic effects of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Biden Cabinet Leans Centrist, Leaving Some Liberals Frustrated
first_paragraph: His economic and environment teams are a little left of center. His foreign policy picks fall squarely in the Democratic Party’s mainstream. His top White House aides are Washington veterans.

title: Can a Televised Vaccination Undo Months of Skepticism?
first_paragraph: It was the kind of live television event that the reality show star president has often staged himself. Vice President Mike Pence stepped in front of a bank of cameras on the White House campus on Friday to receive the new coronavirus vaccine, hailing it as “safe and effective” no fewer than eight times. He urged people to wear masks, wash their hands and do whatever they can to help defeat a disease that has killed more than 300,000 Americans.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
first_paragraph: No matter how you slice it, the restaurant industry is in trouble. By some estimates, nearly 110,000 restaurants have permanently closed.

title: Trump Claims Credit for Vaccines. Some of His Backers Don’t Want to Take Them.
first_paragraph: Elizabeth Graves, an ardent supporter of President Trump, is not opposed to vaccines. She said she had taken flu shots and pneumonia shots and, having just turned 50, was interested in being vaccinated against shingles.

title: Employers Can Require Workers to Get Covid-19 Vaccine, U.S. Says
first_paragraph: Employers can require workers to get a Covid-19 vaccine and bar them from the workplace if they refuse, the federal government said in guidelines issued this week.

title: United Helps to Contact Passengers After Possible Covid-19-Related Death on Flight
first_paragraph: United Airlines said on Friday that it was working with health officials to contact passengers who might have been exposed to the coronavirus by a male passenger who died after a medical emergency on a recent flight.

title: 8 Catholic Sisters Die of Covid-19 Within a Week at a Wisconsin Home
first_paragraph: They were educators, music teachers and community activists who served tirelessly for those living in poverty.

title: Homeland Security’s Latest Target: Vaccine Scams
first_paragraph: A team of agents from the Department of Homeland Security was combing thousands of websites scouting for evidence of the next phase of fraud schemes: offers of treatments or vaccines for the coronavirus.

title: Christmas Is Coming. Cue the Guilt Trips and Tears.
first_paragraph: They are fraught conversations, some ending with a forlorn “that’s OK” or a vague promise to gather in the new year. Others conclude in frustration, or even in tears.

title: America’s Leaders Begin to Get Vaccinated
first_paragraph: Vaccines are being distributed in Washington, while Congress haggles over the details of the stimulus deal. It’s Friday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
first_paragraph: They may have access to near unlimited testing and a glut of resources, but we’ve learned time and again this year that the world’s top officials are still vulnerable.

title: Pence Will Be Vaccinated on Live TV, Adding to Administration’s Mixed Virus Message
first_paragraph: At 8 a.m. on Friday, Vice President Mike Pence will roll up his sleeve to receive the coronavirus vaccine, a televised symbol of reassurance for vaccine skeptics worried about its dangers. President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is scheduled to receive his injection on camera next week.

title: Closing In on Stimulus Deal, Lawmakers Clash Over Fed’s Role
first_paragraph: As lawmakers pushed to finalize a roughly $900 billion stimulus deal, congressional leaders remained divided on Thursday over a handful of issues whose outcome could help determine the course of a sputtering economic recovery.

title: Supreme Court Rejects Religious School’s Challenge to Kentucky Virus Order
first_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Thursday refused to exempt religious schools in Kentucky from an order from Gov. Andy Beshear that temporarily shut down all elementary, middle and high schools, whether public or private, in an effort to combat the coronavirus pandemic.

title: One of Biden’s closest advisers, Cedric Richmond, tests positive for the virus.
first_paragraph: Representative Cedric L. Richmond, Democrat of Louisiana and one of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s closest advisers, has tested positive for the coronavirus and has started a 14-day quarantine, a spokeswoman for the transition said Thursday evening.

title: Puppy Scams Have Spiked in the Pandemic
first_paragraph: Sylvia Lopez, who was laid off from her job this year because of the pandemic, saw an adorable pug puppy named Ted online. For $400, a price advertised as a promotion, she bought the puppy, and then paid more than $800 to have it flown from Virginia to her home in Texas, where she and her family were in quarantine.

title: At Long Last, a Stimulus Nears
first_paragraph: Are McConnell and Pelosi really close to a deal? Just close your eyes until next week, then ask again. It’s Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

title: Some Health Care Workers Are Getting the Vaccine. Others Aren’t. Who Decides?
first_paragraph: Dr. Biron Baker runs a family medicine clinic in Bismarck, N.D. Every day patients walk through the door, and any number of them could be sick with the coronavirus. Dr. Baker treats them anyway, doing the best he can with his small staff to keep from getting sick.

title: Nursing Homes, Ravaged by Covid-19, Start Vaccinating the Most Vulnerable
first_paragraph: Patricia John was still in her nightgown this week in the West Virginia nursing home where she lives when a nurse hurried her out of her room to join a line that had formed in the hallway.

title: Biden’s Inaugural Will Be Mostly Virtual, but Money From Donors Will Be Real
first_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s allies have begun an ambitious campaign to raise millions of dollars from corporations and individuals by offering special “V.I.P. participation” in reimagined inaugural festivities that will be largely virtual because of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Staring Down Deadline, Congress Nears $900 Billion Stimulus Deal
first_paragraph: After months of stalemate, congressional leaders were on the verge on Wednesday of cementing a roughly $900 billion stimulus deal to deliver emergency aid to individuals and companies devastated by the toll of the worsening pandemic, racing to finish the details and stave off a government shutdown on Friday.

title: After personal threats over a local mask mandate, the Dodge City, Kansas, mayor resigns.
first_paragraph: The emails Joyce Warshaw received as mayor of Dodge City, Kan., were hostile enough last month, when the city was merely considering passing a mask mandate.

title: ‘I Was Stunned’: Big Gifts to Small Colleges From an Unexpected Source
first_paragraph: They came like gifts from a Secret Santa, $20 million here, $40 million there, all to higher education, but not to the elite universities that usually hog all the attention. These donations went to colleges and universities that many people have never heard of, and that tended to serve regional, minority and lower-income students.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
first_paragraph: The U.S. is moving to the next phase of its mass vaccination campaign as nursing home residents and staff are beginning to receive their shots.

title: Number of Executions in U.S. Falls Despite Push by Trump Administration
first_paragraph: In part because of the effects of the pandemic on the criminal justice system, the number of executions in the United States fell this year to the lowest level since 1991 despite the Trump administration’s revival of the federal death penalty, according to a study released on Wednesday.

title: Chicago Girl Raises $22,000 for Children’s Hospital With Friendship Bracelets
first_paragraph: When Hayley Orlinsky of Chicago learned on the news in March that doctors and nurses were running low on masks amid the frantic early weeks of the coronavirus pandemic, she wanted to help.

title: When Will It Be Like 2019 Again?
first_paragraph: Teachers are near the front of the line to receive vaccines. Does that mean schools are close to returning to a pre-Covid normality? Not exactly.

title: Biden formally names Buttigieg as his nominee for transportation secretary.
first_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Wednesday formally introduced Pete Buttigieg as his nominee for transportation secretary, a role that will be key to advancing Mr. Biden’s ambitious agenda on rebuilding the nation’s infrastructure and on climate change.

title: Misinformation messengers pivot from election fraud to peddling vaccine conspiracy theories.
first_paragraph: Sidney Powell, a lawyer who was part of President Trump’s legal team, spread a conspiracy theory last month about election fraud. For days, she claimed that she would “release the Kraken” by showing voluminous evidence that Mr. Trump had won the election by a landslide.

title: Pandemic Leaves More Military Families Seeking Food Assistance
first_paragraph: Fort Bragg, the largest military base in the United States, has all the trappings of a small American city: shopping centers, a barber shop and social clubs. In a sign of the times, it also has a food bank.

title: Senator Jon Tester on Democrats and Rural Voters: ‘Our Message Is Really, Really Flawed’
first_paragraph: President Trump visited Montana four times in 2018 as part of the Republican Party’s attempt at unseating Senator Jon Tester. It didn’t work: Mr. Tester was re-elected that year to a third term.

title: A snowstorm in the Northeast threatens to snarl vaccine deliveries.
first_paragraph: The major winter storm bearing down on the Northeast has the potential to snarl distribution of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine in the region.

title: Santa Tests Positive for Virus After Photo Session With 50 Children
first_paragraph: A Georgia couple who dressed up as Santa and Mrs. Claus for an outdoor photo session that was attended by about 50 children last week learned that they had tested positive for the coronavirus three days after the event, the county’s top elected official said on Tuesday.

title: U.S. and Pfizer Are Negotiating Deal for More Vaccine Doses Next Year
first_paragraph: The Trump administration is negotiating a deal to use its power to free up supplies of raw materials to help Pfizer produce tens of millions of additional doses of its Covid-19 vaccine for Americans in the first half of next year, people familiar with the situation said.

title: Leaders in Congress Meet in Search of Spending and Stimulus Deals
first_paragraph: Congressional leaders scrambled on Tuesday to reach agreement on a stimulus bill and a catchall omnibus funding package to keep government funding flowing, meeting to try to hammer out critical spending deals ahead of a Friday deadline.

title: Drug Makers Are Pulling Back From a Program to Help the Needy
first_paragraph: Some of the nation’s top pharmaceutical companies have stopped giving federally mandated drug discounts to hospitals and clinics that care for the poorest Americans, a move that is prompting bipartisan calls for the health secretary, Alex M. Azar II, to demand reinstatement of the price breaks or punish the firms.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
first_paragraph: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration released new data today confirming that Moderna’s vaccine was 94.1 percent effective in preventing Covid-19. The positive review means the agency is expected to authorize the vaccine for emergency use on Friday.

title: A snowstorm in the Northeast threatens to snarl vaccine deliveries.
first_paragraph: A major winter storm is bearing down on the Northeast, from Virginia to New England, with the potential to snarl distribution of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine in the region.

title: Inauguration planners ask Americans to stay home on Jan. 20 and watch the historic event virtually.
first_paragraph: The committee charged with planning the inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris is asking the public to stay home on Jan. 20 and participate in virtual activities instead.

title: The next vaccine challenge is to reassure older Americans.
first_paragraph: Older Americans are pivotal to the success of the vaccination campaign rolling out across the United States. They are the most likely to be hospitalized and to die from Covid-19, and the least likely to muster a strong immune response to the coronavirus.

title: In a Hard Year, Families Find Joy in Real Christmas Trees
first_paragraph: When Allison Protsko was a child, the arrival of the Christmas season meant driving with her family to pick out a Christmas tree, cutting it down themselves and dragging it home.

title: The first Covid-19 vaccines bring Americans hope in small doses.
first_paragraph: Some of the medical centers that have endured the worst of the coronavirus outbreak in the United States found the gloom that has long filled their corridors replaced by elation and hope on Monday as health care workers became the first to take part in a mass vaccination campaign aimed at ending the pandemic.

title: With First Dibs on Vaccines, Rich Countries Have ‘Cleared the Shelves’
first_paragraph: As a growing number of coronavirus vaccines advance through clinical trials, wealthy countries are fueling an extraordinary gap in access around the world, laying claim to more than half the doses that could come on the market by the end of next year.

title: If Teachers Get the Vaccine Quickly, Can Students Get Back to School?
first_paragraph: States and cities across the country are moving to put teachers near the front of the line to receive a coronavirus vaccine, in an effort to make it safer to return to classrooms and provide relief to struggling students and weary parents.

title: A new survey finds that about a quarter of Americans don’t want to get vaccinated.
first_paragraph: As the United States begins the most ambitious vaccination drive in its history, with images of relieved health care workers getting a shot in the arm flashing across TV screens and news sites, fresh data revealed that more than one-quarter of Americans say they probably or definitely would not take a coronavirus vaccine.

title: ‘A Shot of Hope’: What the Vaccine Is Like for Frontline Doctors and Nurses
first_paragraph: As Dr. Rishi Seth rolled up his left sleeve on Monday to receive one of the United States’ first Covid-19 vaccines, he thought of his patients back in the Special Care Unit.

title: First Coronavirus Vaccines Bring Americans Hope in Small Doses
first_paragraph: Some of the very medical centers that have endured the worst of the coronavirus outbreak in the United States found the gloom that has long filled their corridors replaced by elation and hope on Monday as health care workers became the first to take part in a mass vaccination campaign aimed at ending the pandemic.

title: A Day That Settled an Election and Brought Hope for Defeating a Pandemic
first_paragraph: When future historians close the books on the misery of 2020, a grueling year of disease, death, racial strife, street violence, economic collapse and political discord the likes of which have not been seen in the United States in generations, they may look back on Monday, Dec. 14, as a pivotal juncture.

title: Moderates Pare Back Stimulus Plan in Hopes of Breaking Stalemate
first_paragraph: Lawmakers crept toward a possible consensus on Monday on a stimulus deal to address the toll of the pandemic, as a bipartisan group of centrist members of Congress pared back their compromise plan to omit the most contentious sticking points.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: Vaccinations Begin in the U.S.
first_paragraph: Today an array of frontline health care workers received the first doses of a mass vaccination campaign that could bring an end to the coronavirus pandemic in the United States.

title: The number of people with the virus who died in the U.S. passes 300,000.
first_paragraph: The number of people with the coronavirus in the United States who have died passed 300,000 on Monday, another wrenching record that comes less than four weeks after the nation’s virus deaths reached a quarter-million.

title: Schools Will Close in Germany as Cases Surge
first_paragraph: This fall, even as cases surged across Europe, Germany worked hard to keep schools open, prioritizing them over other aspects of daily life like restaurants and bars.

title: In Iowa, an emergency room nurse is first in line for vaccination.
first_paragraph: The vaccine arrived at the University of Iowa Hospital at 7:30 a.m. in a refrigerated FedEx truck, and it was not long before the first dose was injected into the arm of David Conway, 39, an emergency-room nurse.

title: In many Covid-19 obituaries, personal details are accompanied by virus pleas.
first_paragraph: By Sunday, deaths from the coronavirus were approaching 300,000 in the United States, a toll comparable to losing the entire population of Pittsburgh or St. Louis. Reports of new deaths have more than doubled in the last month to an average of nearly 2,400 each day, more than at any other point in the pandemic.

title: As U.S. Deaths Surpass 300,000, Obituaries Force Reckoning with Covid
first_paragraph: When Kim Miller sat down in her Illinois house to compose her husband’s obituary, she could not hold back.

title: Trump Rescinds Plan for White House Staff to Be Quickly Vaccinated
first_paragraph: President Trump said on Sunday night that he would delay a plan for senior White House staff members to receive the coronavirus vaccine in the coming days, hours after The New York Times reported that the administration was planning to rapidly distribute the vaccine to its staff at a time when the first doses are generally being reserved for high-risk health care workers.

title: Trump Administration Plans a Rushed Effort to Encourage Americans to Be Vaccinated
first_paragraph: The Trump administration, scrambling to make up for lost time after a halting start, is rushing to roll out a $250 million public education campaign to encourage Americans to take the coronavirus vaccine, which will reach the first patients in the United States this week.

title: Hospitals Prepare for First Shots as Virus Vaccine Shipments Blanket U.S.
first_paragraph: Trucks and cargo planes packed with the first of nearly three million doses of coronavirus vaccine fanned out across the country on Sunday as hospitals rushed to set up injection sites and their anxious workers tracked each shipment hour by hour.

title: Jerrold M. Post, Specialist in Political Psychology, Dies at 86
first_paragraph: In August 1978, shortly before the opening of negotiations between Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel and President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt at Camp David, President Jimmy Carter paid a visit to C.I.A. headquarters in Langley, Va.

title: Young People Have Less Covid-19 Risk, but in College Towns, Deaths Rose Fast
first_paragraph: When college students returned to campuses around the country this fall, spurring a spike in new coronavirus infections nationwide, people like Phyllis Baukol seemed at little risk.

title: What Will D.J.T. Do?
first_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your wrap-up of the week in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

title: Los Angeles County could face ‘catastrophic suffering and death,’ a health official warns.
first_paragraph: Los Angeles County could see “catastrophic suffering and death” in the coming weeks, public health officials warn, as the nation’s most populous county reported another record day of new coronavirus cases.

title: What Happens When a Superspreader Event Keeps Spreading
first_paragraph: When it was disclosed last spring that the coronavirus had stealthily infected 99 people after the Cambridge, Mass., pharmaceutical company Biogen held a two-day conference in February, it helped add the term “superspreader” to the pandemic lexicon.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
first_paragraph: a historic turning point in a pandemic that has taken more than 294,000 lives in the United States alone.

title: Supreme Court Rejects Texas Suit Seeking to Subvert Election
first_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Friday rejected a lawsuit by Texas that had asked the court to throw out the election results in four battleground states that President Trump lost in November, ending any prospect that a brazen attempt to use the courts to reverse his defeat at the polls would succeed.

title: With the Virus Surging, Arizona Teachers Protest by Calling In Sick
first_paragraph: In a reflection of debates nationwide over whether to keep classrooms open during the current surge in coronavirus cases, about 100 teachers in Arizona’s third-largest school district staged a sickout on Friday, demanding that schools close after winter break and stay remote until the region’s infection rate declines.

title: Businessman Pays Overdue Utility Bills for Dozens of Floridians, Again
first_paragraph: Mike Esmond walked into City Hall in Gulf Breeze, Fla., in November 2019 and cut a check for $4,300 to pay for 36 local residents whose gas and water bills were overdue and at risk of being disconnected.

title: The Vaccines Are Coming. A Divided and Distrustful America Awaits.
