first_paragraph: The coronavirus itself was slow to arrive in Bristol, a lakeside town of 3,300 people. The economic destruction came swiftly.

title: How Bad Will the Economy Get? Companies Will Provide Clues
first_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has pushed the economy into a slowdown of unknown severity. It could be a long, drawn-out recession, or a sharp dip followed by a swift recovery.

title: U.S. Food Supply Chain Is Strained as Virus Spreads
first_paragraph: The nation’s food supply chain is showing signs of strain, as increasing numbers of workers are falling ill with the coronavirus in meat processing plants, warehouses and grocery stores.

title: The Big Deal to Cut Oil Production May Not Be Big Enough
first_paragraph: The agreement by major oil producers on Sunday to reduce their daily production by 9.7 million barrels was the largest cutback in history and a feat of remarkable coordination by more than 20 nations led by Saudi Arabia and Russia with unusual mediation from the United States.

title: Economic Pain Will Persist Long After Lockdowns End
first_paragraph: Walter Isenberg is the sort of business owner President Trump has in mind when he talks about the need to start lifting coronavirus lockdowns and reopen the American economy. Mr. Isenberg’s hotel and restaurant group in Denver has seen its revenues drop from $3 million a day last year to $40,000 a day now.

title: Pay Cuts Come to Condé Nast, the Glossy Publisher of Vogue and Vanity Fair
first_paragraph: Condé Nast, the most glittering of all magazine publishers, is the latest media casualty of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Big Business Pledged Gentler Capitalism. It’s Not Happening in a Pandemic.
first_paragraph: Last August, the chief executives of 181 of America’s largest corporations signed a document pledging their commitment to run their companies for the benefit of workers and communities, and not just for shareholders.

title: Bob Iger Thought He Was Leaving on Top. Now, He’s Fighting for Disney’s Life.
first_paragraph: The Walt Disney Company turned franchises like Marvel and “Star Wars” into the biggest media business in the world, and last fall it was putting the finishing touches on the image of a storied character: its chief executive, Bob Iger.

title: Flight Attendants and Pilots Ask, ‘Is It OK to Keep Working?’
first_paragraph: Molly Choma, a flight attendant for Alaska Airlines, had worked nearly every day since mid-March, even as the coronavirus outbreak devastated her industry. But last Sunday, she woke up alone in a room in a nearly empty hotel and wondered if it was time to stop.

title: Disney World Furloughing 43,000 Workers
first_paragraph: Walt Disney World in Florida plans to furlough about 43,000 workers after it closed last month because of the coronavirus pandemic, the company and a union coalition representing the workers said.

title: Oil Nations, Prodded by Trump, Reach Deal to Slash Production
first_paragraph: Oil-producing nations on Sunday agreed to the largest production cut ever negotiated, in an unprecedented coordinated effort by Russia, Saudi Arabia and the United States to stabilize oil prices and, indirectly, global financial markets.

title: Nursing Home Residents, Families and Workers: How is the Coronavirus Crisis Affecting You?
first_paragraph: Across the nation, nursing homes and long-term care facilities for the elderly have been hit hard by the coronavirus crisis. The virus has sickened and killed thousands of residents and staff members at these facilities. At least 43 deaths have been linked to an outbreak at the Life Care nursing facility in Kirkland, Wash. And at least 35 people have died from the virus at the Canterbury Rehabilitation & Healthcare Center, a nursing facility in Richmond, Va.

title: Dumped Milk, Smashed Eggs, Plowed Vegetables: Food Waste of the Pandemic
first_paragraph: In Wisconsin and Ohio, farmers are dumping thousands of gallons of fresh milk into lagoons and manure pits. An Idaho farmer has dug huge ditches to bury 1 million pounds of onions. And in South Florida, a region that supplies much of the Eastern half of the United States with produce, tractors are crisscrossing bean and cabbage fields, plowing perfectly ripe vegetables back into the soil.

title: China Delays Mask and Ventilator Exports After Quality Complaints
first_paragraph: Chinese officials have begun inspecting every shipment of N95 respirators, ventilators and other medical supplies for quality issues before export, a policy likely to delay the arrival of critical gear at hospitals around the world that are struggling to cope with the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Where Thousands of Masks a Day Are Decontaminated to Battle the Virus
first_paragraph: Inside the rural Ohio labs run by Battelle, a nonprofit research and development firm, scientists have tested explosives, experimented with atomic energy and worked with chemical nerve agents. But some of the group’s most critical work is now happening outside, in a parking lot.

title: Keep Workers On, or Lay Them Off? Small Businesses Face Hard Choices
first_paragraph: When Joseph Levey logged in to Chase Bank’s lending portal early Tuesday, he hoped he would finally be able to submit his law firm’s application for a federal stimulus loan. He had been trying since the previous Friday.

title: Black-Owned Businesses Could Face Hurdles in Federal Aid Program
first_paragraph: Four years ago, Yasmine Young walked down the street from Diaspora Salon, the business she owns in Baltimore, to the Bank of America branch where she has a business checking account. She was thinking of getting a credit card, but when a banker there described the requirements she would have to meet to qualify for one, Ms. Young says she left feeling too discouraged to apply.

title: News Media Outlets Have Been Ravaged by the Pandemic
first_paragraph: The news media business was shaky before the coronavirus started spreading across the country last month. Since then, the economic downturn that put 30 million Americans out of work has led to pay cuts, layoffs and shutdowns at many news outlets, including weeklies like The Stranger in Seattle, digital empires like Vox Media and Gannett, the nation's largest newspaper chain.

title: Global Trade Sputters, Leaving Too Much Here, Too Little There
first_paragraph: Factories are idled. Workers are in lockdown. Goods are piling up at some ports, while elsewhere container ships sail empty. Dairy farmers are dumping their milk, while toilet paper aisles at the grocery store have been picked bare.

title: A ‘Car Wreck’ Puts the Business of Bringing People Together on Hold
first_paragraph: As the coronavirus spread across the United States last month, conferences large and small were quick to cancel. There was one notable exception.

title: A New Front for Nationalism: The Global Battle Against a Virus
first_paragraph: As they battle a pandemic that has no regard for borders, the leaders of many of the world’s largest economies are in the thrall of unabashedly nationalist principles, undermining collective efforts to tame the novel coronavirus.

title: Robots Welcome to Take Over, as Pandemic Accelerates Automation
first_paragraph: The recycling industry was already struggling before the pandemic. Now, an increasing number of cities are suspending recycling services, partly out of fear that workers might contract the coronavirus from one another while sorting through used water bottles, food containers and boxes.

title: Virus Throws Millions More Out of Work, and Washington Struggles to Keep Pace
first_paragraph: When the federal government began rushing trillions of dollars of assistance to Americans crushed by the coronavirus pandemic, the hope was that some of the aid would allow businesses to keep workers on the payroll and cushion employees against job losses.

title: OPEC and Russia Agree to Cut Oil Production
first_paragraph: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, Russia and other countries reached a tentative agreement on Thursday to temporarily cut production.

title: A Wall Street Bank’s Hard-Driving Culture Pushes Traders Into the Office
first_paragraph: When a group of Bank of America employees dialed into a call with their boss, Soofian Zuberi, late last month, they were expecting to hear that they could continue doing their jobs from the safety of their homes. The coronavirus had ravaged New York City and was tearing across the country, leaving well more than a thousand dead. Most firms, including those on Wall Street, were already recommending that people work from home.

title: Small Businesses Wait for Cash as Disaster Loan Program Unravels
first_paragraph: Flooded by requests for help like never before, a federal disaster loan program that was supposed to deliver emergency relief to small businesses in just three days has run low on funding and nearly frozen up entirely. Now, business owners who applied are desperate for cash and answers about what aid, if any, they are going to receive.

title: Nurses and Doctors Speaking Out on Safety Now Risk Their Job
first_paragraph: It was the fliers bearing his photo that made Adam Witt suspect something had gone deeply wrong. Last week, Jersey Shore University Medical Center, where he worked as a nurse, posted the fliers at two security stations, declaring that he was persona non grata.

title: ‘Sudden Black Hole’ for the Economy With Millions More Unemployed
first_paragraph: With the coronavirus outbreak shutting businesses in every state, fresh evidence of the economic devastation was delivered Thursday as a government report showed that 6.6 million more workers had lost their jobs.

title: With $2.3 Trillion Injection, Fed’s Plan Far Exceeds Its 2008 Rescue
first_paragraph: The Federal Reserve said it could pump $2.3 trillion into the economy through new and expanded programs it announced on Thursday, ramping up its efforts to help companies and state and local governments suffering financial damage from the coronavirus.

title: For Workers Over 50, a Job Without Benefits Spells Long-Term Trouble
first_paragraph: When the retirement expert Alicia H. Munnell finished gathering data for a study on American workers ages 50 to 62 in jobs without benefits, she was stunned.

title: While the World Spends on Coronavirus Bailouts, China Holds Back
first_paragraph: The world is opening its wallet to fight the effects of the coronavirus outbreak. The United States unveiled a $2 trillion rescue package. European countries have announced their own spending blitz, and Japan approved a nearly $1 trillion economic stimulus plan.

title: Disney Plus Racks Up 50 Million Subscribers in 5 Months
first_paragraph: Disney has taken an especially hard hit from the pandemic, with its theme parks shuttered, movies postponed and ESPN cable channel without live sports to televise.

title: Oil Markets Are a Mess. Can World Leaders Straighten Them Out?
first_paragraph: Usually it’s the world’s major oil-producing countries that step in when a big drop in prices roils the oil market. But these are not normal times.

title: Zoom Rushes to Improve Privacy for Consumers Flooding Its Service
first_paragraph: Over the last month, the Zoom videoconferencing service has emerged as the communication lifeline of the coronavirus pandemic. But the convenience fueling Zoom’s explosive popularity has come at a price.

title: Fed Emergency Rate Cuts Came as Economy Turned ‘Profoundly Uncertain’
first_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials found themselves staring down a “profoundly uncertain” economic outlook, on top of a financial market meltdown, when they chose to slash interest rates to near zero in mid-March.

title: Wells Fargo’s Growth Cap Eased to Aid Small-Business Crisis
first_paragraph: The Federal Reserve made another move to try to expand small business owners’ access to emergency loans on Wednesday when it temporarily lifted a growth restriction it had imposed on Wells Fargo two years ago after the bank’s fake-account scandal.

title: Europe’s Big Economies Brace for Sharpest Drop Since World War II
first_paragraph: Cavernous factories devoid of workers. Cranes frozen in midair over construction sites. Millions of people confined to their homes, spending a fraction of what they used to before the coronavirus hit.

title: ‘Never Seen Anything Like It’: Cars Line Up for Miles at Food Banks
first_paragraph: In Omaha, a food pantry that typically serves as few as 100 people saw 900 show up on a single day. In Jonesboro, Ark., after a powerful tornado struck, a food bank received less than half the donations it expected because nervous families held on to what they had. And in Washington State and Louisiana, the National Guard has been called in to help pack food boxes and ensure that the distributions run smoothly.

title: Uber and Lyft Drivers Face Hurdles to Stimulus Bill Benefits
first_paragraph: Shortly after the Senate approved a huge stimulus bill in late March that made gig workers and other contractors eligible for unemployment assistance during the coronavirus pandemic, Uber’s chief executive, Dara Khosrowshahi, rejoiced on Twitter.

title: 31% Can’t Pay the Rent: ‘It’s Only Going to Get Worse’
first_paragraph: First it was the waitress whose restaurant closed. Then the waiter, the bartender, the substitute teacher, the hairdresser, the tattoo artist and the Walgreens manager.

title: Here’s How Those Hot Jigsaw Puzzles Are Made
first_paragraph: Patrick Stewart once called the world of jigsaw puzzles a “secret society.” There were always high-profile fans, like Hugh Jackman, but most only whispered about their passion.

title: ‘I Just Need the Comfort’: Processed Foods Make a Pandemic Comeback
first_paragraph: Just a few months ago, Sue Smith considered herself a healthy eater. She ate salads with kale and quinoa. She counted calories. She eliminated processed sugar from her diet. She avoided dairy products.

title: F.A.Q. on Coronavirus Relief for Small Businesses, Freelancers and More
first_paragraph: The federal stimulus bills enacted last month, including a bipartisan $2 trillion economic relief plan, offer help for the millions of American small businesses affected by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: What Will Tomorrow’s Workplace Bring? More Elbow Room, for Starters
first_paragraph: Many Americans are weeks, if not months, from returning to their offices and regaining a semblance of a normal workday. Given the recent layoff and furlough announcements, many are wondering whether they will even have a job after the dust settles.

title: Oil Companies Are Collapsing, but Wind and Solar Energy Keep Growing
first_paragraph: A few years ago, the kind of double-digit drop in oil and gas prices the world is experiencing now because of the coronavirus pandemic might have increased the use of fossil fuels and hurt renewable energy sources like wind and solar farms.

title: Cruise Industry, a Symbol of the Pandemic, Scrambles to Survive
first_paragraph: First, there was the Diamond Princess, stranded off the coast of Japan as the coronavirus infected hundreds of passengers. Then the Westerdam, circling in the sea for days with nowhere to dock. Then the Grand Princess, the Costa Luminosa and the Zaandam.

title: PG&E Deal With Wildfire Victims Challenged Over Share Price
first_paragraph: Four months ago, Pacific Gas & Electric seemed poised to emerge from bankruptcy after reaching a $13.5 billion settlement with tens of thousands of people who lost homes in wildfires started by the utility’s equipment.

title: Peter Navarro Has Antagonized Multinational Companies. Now He’s in Charge.
first_paragraph: For three years, Peter Navarro has been corporate America’s biggest nemesis, punishing multinational companies for moving jobs offshore by advocating tariffs and other trade barriers in pursuit of President Trump’s “America First” strategy.

title: Young Adults, Burdened With Debt, Are Now Facing an Economic Crisis
first_paragraph: The last time a serious economic downturn hit in 2008, Evan Schade was in high school and the crisis seemed like a news event that happened to other people. This time, as the coronavirus has brought the economy to its knees, it has become a personal affair.

title: European Banks Prepared for a Crisis. But Not This One.
first_paragraph: It was supposed to be a drill. Government overseers would test whether European banks could survive a hypothetical perfect storm that included a steep economic downturn, plunging stock prices and a collapse in consumer spending.

title: Americans Don’t Trust the Media Anymore. So Why Do They Trust the Cuomos?
first_paragraph: At the end of 2013, CNN executives sent word to Chris Cuomo: No more interviewing your brother on television.

title: How Economists Are Trying to Answer Coronavirus Questions
first_paragraph: Ernesto Stein, an economist at the Inter-American Development Bank, normally spends his time thinking about industrial policy in Latin America. But recently, a map in The New York Times caught his eye. It illustrated how hospital systems in some regions of the United States would be quickly overwhelmed by the spread of the coronavirus while others still had resources to spare.

title: Two Veteran C.E.O.s Risk $1.8 Billion on a Streaming App. In a Pandemic.
first_paragraph: They had to cancel the premiere party. But Jeffrey Katzenberg and Meg Whitman have stuck with the April 6 start date of Quibi, the short-form video app for smartphones that they hope will attract millions of subscribers.

title: Private Equity Firm Pushes for Broader Access to Fed Lending Program
first_paragraph: As government officials fight to prevent an economic depression by setting up emergency lending programs to keep credit flowing to taxpayers and small businesses, a prominent private equity firm is pushing to ensure that a broader spectrum of investments are included.

title: A Quarantined Uber Driver’s Quest for Paid Sick Leave
first_paragraph: Zachary Frenette likes working as an Uber driver in Phoenix. He is a top-rated driver who often chats with his customers on their trips.

title: OPEC Meeting Is Delayed as Saudi and Russian Tensions Flare
first_paragraph: A meeting planned for Monday between officials of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, Russia and other oil producers, which had buoyed hopes for a deal to end the turmoil in energy markets, has been put off, according to two OPEC delegates.

title: Photos: In Rural Towns and on Remote Farms, the Virus Creeps In
first_paragraph: John Maley’s 28,000-acre ranch sits on the eastern edge of Steens Mountain Wilderness, a sprawling high desert in a remote corner of southeastern Oregon that’s thick in season with sagebrush, juniper and mountain mahogany.

title: The Fed Got a Big Pile of Cash to Help the Economy. Who Will Benefit?
first_paragraph: As unemployment skyrockets and businesses struggle to cover rent and payroll, the odds are rising that short-term layoffs turn into long-term joblessness as employers shut down. At its worst, the United States could fall into an economic depression.

title: A Coffee C.E.O.’s Pandemic Diary: ‘We Want to Still Provide an Escape’
first_paragraph: A month ago, Nick Stone had a $50 million coffee business, with dozens of cafes in bustling downtowns.

title: Decade of Job Growth Comes to an End, Undone by a Pandemic
first_paragraph: The longest stretch of American job creation on record came to a halt last month, the Labor Department reported Friday, another reflection of the coronavirus pandemic that has brought the economy to a virtual standstill.

title: ‘This Isn’t a Dry Run’: How to Be Ready for More Financial Pain
first_paragraph: When thousands of people are sick and dying, the stock market isn’t the world’s most pressing problem. It may even be unseemly to worry about it at all.

title: Take Government Aid? We’ll See, Some Businesses Say
first_paragraph: Grants, low-interest loans and other government support might seem like manna for businesses under financial strain. But some chief executives and corporate boards might balk at the offer of billions of dollars in aid to help them ride out the coronavirus pandemic and keep the economy from sliding into a deep recession.

title: Labor Fight Collides With the Pandemic at Trader Joe’s
first_paragraph: On March 23, as the coronavirus pandemic put grocery workers on the front lines of a public health crisis, Trader Joe’s sent a memo to store managers encouraging them to relay a message to employees: Joining a union might be a bad idea.

title: Trump’s Company Seeks to Ease Financial Crunch as Coronavirus Takes Toll
first_paragraph: All over the country, businesses large and small are seeking breathing room from their lenders, landlords and business partners as they face the financial fallout from the coronavirus crisis.

title: Predictions for the Coronavirus Stock Market
first_paragraph: One prediction seems solid: The coronavirus epidemic will get much worse in the United States in coming weeks. But where the stock market is heading is much less certain.

title: A Widening Toll on Jobs: ‘This Thing Is Going to Come for Us All’
first_paragraph: A staggering 6.6 million people applied for unemployment benefits last week as the coronavirus outbreak ravaged nearly every corner of the American economy, the Labor Department reported Thursday.

title: How to Make Your Work-Neighbors Be Quiet (In 3 Lies or Less)
first_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, even if you want them withheld. Letters may be edited.

title: Coronavirus Is Making the Public Pension Crisis Even Worse
first_paragraph: For years, the country’s public pension plans have faced a yawning gap between what they owe and what they can pay.

title: Home Depot Halts Sales of N95 Masks Amid Shortage, Company Says
first_paragraph: Home Depot has ordered all 2,300 of its stores in North America to stop sales of N95 masks to try to free them up for those on the front lines of the coronavirus emergency response, the company said on Wednesday.

title: Retailers Under Growing Pressure to Let Workers Wear Masks
first_paragraph: At Office Depot, employees have been told that they cannot wear masks in the store. Some Walgreens workers say they were also discouraged from wearing them. Many other large retailers, including Target, have started to allow masks, but are leaving it up to employees to procure their own supplies.

title: Trump Rebuffs Demands to Lift Tariffs as Economy Falters
first_paragraph: President Trump continues to resist calls from hundreds of companies to drop tariffs he has placed on foreign goods, arguing that the levies do not impose costs on American companies, despite economic evidence to the contrary.

title: Needy Will Face Hurdles to Getting Coronavirus Stimulus
first_paragraph: In the sweeping economic recovery package that Congress passed last week, the federal government promised payments of up to $1,200 to most American adults, including those with little income or none at all.

title: Auto Sales Plummet in First Quarter as Coronavirus Keeps Buyers Away
first_paragraph: Automakers reported a plunge on Wednesday in new-vehicle sales as fear of the coronavirus and stay-at-home orders kept consumers from dealerships, adding to the troubles of the country’s largest manufacturing sector.

title: Are You Unemployed Because of the Coronavirus Outbreak?
first_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic, and the shutdowns it has caused, has already led to millions of unemployment claims across the U.S. Economists expect millions more in the weeks ahead.

title: France Tries Limiting Joblessness to Confront Coronavirus Recession
first_paragraph: When France started shutting down a few weeks ago as the coronavirus marched relentlessly into the country, Dominique Paul feared disaster. His family’s white-glove catering company, Groupe Butard, halted operations, putting 190 jobs at risk.

title: Why the Global Recession Could Last a Long Time
first_paragraph: The world is almost certainly ensnared in a devastating recession delivered by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Coronavirus Battle Creates a Global ‘Free-for-All’ to Find Masks
first_paragraph: Million-dollar wire transfers to strangers. Rumors of hidden supplies in forgotten warehouses. Wheeler-dealers trying to talk regulators and customs officials into letting that one precious shipment through.

title: White House Economists Warned in 2019 a Pandemic Could Devastate America
first_paragraph: White House economists published a study last September that warned a pandemic disease could kill a half million Americans and devastate the economy.

title: Airlines Refused to Collect Passenger Data That Could Aid Coronavirus Fight
first_paragraph: For 15 years, the U.S. government has been pressing airlines to prepare for a possible pandemic by collecting passengers’ contact information so that public-health authorities could track down people exposed to a contagious virus.

title: CNN’s Chris Cuomo, Brother of Governor, Tests Positive for Coronavirus
first_paragraph: Chris Cuomo, the CNN anchor and younger brother of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, has tested positive for the coronavirus, the network said on Tuesday.

title: Unease at Kentucky Project Mirrors Construction Industry’s Fears
first_paragraph: Until the coronavirus pandemic, Gill Holland spent six years and $35 million constructing new residences and renovating 19th- and 20th-century warehouses in Portland, a historic neighborhood on the Ohio River that is Louisville’s oldest and one of its poorest.

title: Fracking Once Lifted Pennsylvania. Now It Could Be a Drag.
first_paragraph: The last time the global economy was in free fall, an economic savior showed up in southwestern Pennsylvania. Energy companies, which had discovered a way to get at the state’s vast natural-gas reserves, invested billions of dollars in the region, cushioning the blow of the Great Recession.

title: A Loyal Chinese Critic Vanishes, in a Blow to the Nation’s Future
first_paragraph: Weeks before Ren Zhiqiang disappeared, leading to fears among his friends and fans that he had been picked up by the Chinese authorities, the 69-year-old former property mogul locked himself up.

title: Strikes at Instacart and Amazon Over Coronavirus Health Concerns
first_paragraph: Signaling both growing anxiety and growing solidarity brought on by the coronavirus pandemic, workers in a variety of occupations across the country are protesting what they see as inadequate safety measures and insufficient pay for the risks they are confronting.

title: Pelosi Floats New Stimulus Plan: Rolling Back SALT Cap
first_paragraph: As lawmakers prepare for another round of fiscal stimulus to address economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic, Speaker Nancy Pelosi suggested the next package include a retroactive rollback of a tax change that hurt high earners in states like New York and California.

title: U.S. Retail Crisis Deepens as Hundreds of Thousands Lose Work
first_paragraph: Macy’s and Gap said on Monday that they planned to furlough much of their work forces, a stark sign of how devastating the coronavirus will be for major retailers and their workers who sell clothing, accessories and other discretionary goods.

title: The Medical News Site That Saw the Coronavirus Coming Months Ago
first_paragraph: On New Year’s Eve, Helen Branswell, a reporter at the science and medical news website Stat, was finishing an article about the development of an elusive Ebola vaccine when she got an inkling of her next big story.

title: Can Japan’s Economy Get Any Worse? It May Soon Find Out
first_paragraph: Even before the new coronavirus, Japan’s economy was in trouble. Exports were plummeting on slowing demand from China, and a tax increase at home was keeping shoppers out of stores. The numbers were stark: Economic output contracted 7.1 percent in the last quarter of 2019.

title: Facebook Aims $100 Million at Media Hit by the Coronavirus
first_paragraph: Facebook announced on Monday that it would dole out $25 million in grants to local news outlets and spend $75 million in a marketing drive aimed at news organizations internationally in response to the coronavirus-prompted economic downturn, which has caused advertising to plummet and has threatened media industry revenues.

title: These Days, Even a Michelin Star Chef Has to Sell Takeout
first_paragraph: For nearly three years, the chef T.J. Steele refused to offer delivery at Claro, his Michelin star restaurant in the Gowanus neighborhood of Brooklyn.

title: Inside G.M.’s Race to Build Ventilators, Before Trump’s Attack
first_paragraph: While much of the U.S. economy has ground to a halt because of the coronavirus outbreak, several dozen workers in orange vests and hard hats were hauling heavy equipment on Sunday at a General Motors plant in Kokomo, Ind.

title: Scary Times for U.S. Companies Spell Boom for Restructuring Advisers
first_paragraph: Freedom Mortgage, one of the nation’s largest mortgage lenders, is looking for additional financing as millions of homeowners are expected to stop making mortgage payments. The Cheesecake Factory said this past week it wouldn’t be able to make rent payments on its leases because of lost business. And giant companies from Kraft Heinz to Ford have tapped billions of dollars in credit from banks in preparation for an uncertain future.

title: White House Airlifts Medical Supplies From China in Coronavirus Fight
first_paragraph: A commercial aircraft carrying 80 tons of gloves, masks, gowns and other medical supplies from Shanghai touched down in New York on Sunday, the first of 22 scheduled flights that White House officials say will funnel much-needed goods to the United States by early April as it battles the world’s largest coronavirus outbreak.

title: The U.S. Tried to Build a New Fleet of Ventilators. The Mission Failed.
first_paragraph: Thirteen years ago, a group of U.S. public health officials came up with a plan to address what they regarded as one of the medical system’s crucial vulnerabilities: a shortage of ventilators.

title: National Enquirer Publisher Is Cutting Employees’ Pay
first_paragraph: American Media Inc., the publisher of The National Enquirer, Men’s Journal, Us Weekly and other titles, is cutting the pay of its employees by more than 20 percent, a spokesman said on Saturday, as the coronavirus has shaken the economy and the advertising market.

title: Instacart Shoppers Plan to Strike Over Coronavirus Protections
first_paragraph: Workers for Instacart, a tech company that delivers groceries and other household items ordered through an app, plan a nationwide strike on Monday, maintaining that the company has not provided them with supplies to protect them from being infected during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: April Bills Loom. The Economy Hangs on How Many Are Left Unpaid.
first_paragraph: On Wednesday, as on the first day of any month, many companies and households will have bills to pay. This time, a lot will simply pile up.

title: The Nordic Way to Economic Rescue
first_paragraph: in gargantuan form. The $2 trillion package of spending expands the standard unemployment insurance system, while setting aside a pool of money that is supposed to aid distressed companies.

title: Trish Regan, Fox Business Host Who Dismissed Virus Concerns, Departs
first_paragraph: The Fox Business anchor Trish Regan has departed the cable news network, two weeks after she was benched following an on-air monologue in which she dismissed concerns about the coronavirus as a “scam” fueled by enemies of President Trump.

title: China Pushes to Churn Out Coronavirus Gear, Yet Struggles to Police It
first_paragraph: One man made fake Honeywell N95 respirators at a makeshift factory on a farm. Pharmacies sold ineffective knockoffs of a Chinese version of Clorox. In one Chinese province, authorities seized more than seven million masks that were substandard, mislabeled or counterfeited.

title: ‘White-Collar Quarantine’ Over Virus Spotlights Class Divide
first_paragraph: For about $80,000, an individual can purchase a six-month plan with Private Health Management, which helps people with serious medical issues navigate the health care system.

title: For the Class of 2020, a Job-Eating Virus Recalls the Great Recession
first_paragraph: They hoped to secure jobs on political campaigns, at fashion brands and law offices, and in sales and finance. Instead, they’ve had internships canceled and interviews postponed, wandered through empty job fairs and seen recruiters ignore their anxious emails.

title: A New Mission for Nonprofits During the Outbreak: Survival
first_paragraph: It took Stephanie Cartier nearly three years to open No Limits, a central New Jersey cafe operated by people with intellectual disabilities. That was early February. It took only a few days in March to close the 65-seat restaurant indefinitely.

title: The Toilet Paper Had Armed Guards, and Other Coronavirus Stories
first_paragraph: The Covid-19 pandemic is gutting the global economy and forcing entire nations into quarantine. While reporting on devastation that is incomprehensibly big, our reporters have been accumulating in their notebooks some moments that are compelling because they are small.

title: I Became a Disciplined Investor Over 40 Years. The Virus Broke Me in 40 Days.
first_paragraph: four weeks into the coronavirus crash of 2020. The Dow Jones industrial average has opened down another 700 points, after plunging below 20,000 a day before. It’s down 30 percent in a month, the steepest drop ever, even worse than during the Great Depression.

title: Migrant Farmworkers Whose Harvests Feed Europe Are Blocked at Borders
first_paragraph: When Europe tightened its borders to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, France’s biggest farmers sounded an alarm: The workers they rely on from other countries to harvest much of the nation’s food could no longer make the trip.

title: The Coronavirus Economy: When Washington Takes Over Business
first_paragraph: The $2 trillion coronavirus rescue package that the Senate passed on Wednesday will fundamentally transform the U.S. government by placing thousands of businesses and millions of workers on federally funded life support.

title: Bonanza for Rich Real Estate Investors, Tucked Into Stimulus Package
first_paragraph: The federal government’s planned $2 trillion economic rescue package includes financial aid for individuals and industries that are struggling to survive the coronavirus pandemic.

title: What to Know About Making a Will in the Age of Coronavirus
first_paragraph: When Joel Solomon sold his financial services firm in mid-January, he had been planning to call his estate lawyer to update his will and trusts. But with coronavirus cases spiking, Mr. Solomon and his wife, Nancy, decided to act immediately.

title: How the Fed’s Magic Money Machine Will Turn $454 Billion Into $4 Trillion
first_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has a favorite talking point: With the Federal Reserve’s help, the government will turn a $500 billion spending package working its way through Congress into a $4 trillion booster shot for the United States economy.

title: ‘It’s a Wreck’: 3.3 Million File Unemployment Claims as Economy Comes Apart
first_paragraph: More than three million people filed for unemployment benefits last week, sending a collective shudder throughout the economy that is unlike anything Americans have experienced.

title: Fed’s Powell Says U.S. Must Get Virus Under Control Before Economy Restarts
first_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, said during a rare television interview on Thursday that the United States “may well” be in a recession already, but that it should get the coronavirus under control before getting back to work.

title: Surging Traffic Is Slowing Down Our Internet
first_paragraph: In late January, as China locked down some provinces to contain the spread of the coronavirus, average internet speeds in the country slowed as people who were stuck inside went online more and clogged the networks. In Hubei Province, the epicenter of infections, mobile broadband speeds fell by more than half.

title: Europe’s Leaders Ditch Austerity and Fight Pandemic With Cash
first_paragraph: A British prime minister from the party of Margaret Thatcher has effectively nationalized the national railway system, while forsaking budget austerity in favor of aggressive public spending. Germany has set aside its traditional detestation for debt to unleash emergency spending, while enabling the rest of the European Union to breach limits on deficits.

title: White House Weighs Tariff Delay
first_paragraph: The Trump administration is considering postponing tariff payments on some imported goods for 90 days, according to people familiar with the matter, as it looks to ease the burden on businesses hurt by the pandemic.

title: Essential? Retailers Like Guitar Center and Michaels Think They Are
first_paragraph: At some Guitar Center stores, employees are still allowing customers to try out models of guitars. Dillard’s, a department store chain popular in the South, is still welcoming shoppers looking for clothing and makeup. And Michaels, the arts and crafts chain, says it is keeping many of its stores open to provide supplies to parents teaching their homebound children. “We are here for the makers,” the retailer said in an email to one concerned customer.

title: A Sewing Army, Making Masks for America
first_paragraph: They are scrounging for fabric, cutting it up, stitching it together. They are repurposing drapes, dresses, bra straps, shower curtains, even coffee filters. They are building supply chains, organizing workers, managing distribution networks.

title: Trump’s Briefings Are a Ratings Hit. Should Networks Cover Them Live?
first_paragraph: President Trump is a ratings hit, and some journalists and public health experts say that could be a dangerous thing.

title: Nurses Share Coronavirus Stories Anonymously in an Online Document
first_paragraph: More than 1,200 health care workers have used a private online document to share their stories of fighting the coronavirus pandemic on the front lines.

title: A $2 Trillion Lifeline Will Help, but More May Be Needed
first_paragraph: If you want to shut down an economy to fight a pandemic without driving millions of people and businesses into bankruptcy, you need the government to cut some checks. The coronavirus response deal that the Senate passed late Wednesday will get a lot of checks into the mail, but it will soothe only a few months of financial pain.

title: ‘A Week of Snow Days’? Ha! Families Deal With Cabin Fever
first_paragraph: Anita Tandon and Sujit Chakravarthy, parents of three young children, ages 3 months to 7 years old, have taken extreme measures to keep order in their home during quarantine.

title: Inside American Airlines’ Scramble as Virus Grounds Jets by Hundreds
first_paragraph: On Monday morning, American Airlines Flight 1 departed John F. Kennedy Airport in New York, bound for Los Angeles. It had six passengers.

title: Drivers Say Uber and Lyft Are Blocking Unemployment Pay
first_paragraph: In a typical week, Jerome Gage, a Lyft driver in Los Angeles, makes $900 to $1,000 before expenses during roughly 50 hours on the road. This week, with most of the state holed up and demand for rides evaporating, he expects to work even longer to make far less than half that amount.

title: Medicare Is Updating Coverage to Help in the Coronavirus Crisis
first_paragraph: Older Americans are at a high risk for serious illness from the coronavirus, and most who are over age 65 are covered by Medicare.

title: The Stock Buyback Binge May Be Over. For Now.
first_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has brought a sudden halt to one of corporate America’s favorite pursuits: the share buyback.

title: As Businesses Close, WeWork Tries to Lure Workers Back
first_paragraph: In the fight against the spreading coronavirus, countless businesses, restaurants and bars have temporarily shuttered to stop people from congregating.

title: To Fight the Coronavirus, Cut the Red Tape
first_paragraph: These are scary times. The world is living through the double whammy of a pandemic health care crisis and a possible global economic depression.

title: States Say Some Doctors Stockpile Trial Coronavirus Drugs, for Themselves
first_paragraph: Doctors are hoarding medications touted as possible coronavirus treatments by writing prescriptions for themselves and family members, according to pharmacy boards in states across the country.

title: The Evening News Is Back
first_paragraph: Ten million people watched “The Voice” last week, the biggest audience for the NBC reality show in a year.

title: Coronavirus Spurs a Wave of Suspect Websites Looking to Cash In
first_paragraph: A popular technology company that has helped launch thousands of online retail sites has become a favorite tool for fly-by-night businesses looking to cash in on the coronavirus pandemic.

title: In World’s Most Vulnerable Countries, the Pandemic Rivals the 2008 Crisis
first_paragraph: In New Delhi, a fruit vendor whose sales have dropped by half now dilutes the milk she serves to her five children. In central Turkey, a company that runs hot air balloon rides for tourists has banished its 49 employees to indefinite leave while cutting their wages by half.

title: Trump Considers Reopening Economy, Over Health Experts’ Objections
first_paragraph: As the United States entered Week 2 of trying to contain the spread of the coronavirus by shuttering large swaths of the economy, President Trump, Wall Street executives and many conservative economists began questioning whether the government had gone too far and should instead lift restrictions that are already inflicting deep pain on workers and businesses.

title: Whatever It Takes: How the Fed Aims to Rescue the Economy
first_paragraph: The Federal Reserve on Monday pledged to do, in essence, whatever it takes to keep the economy from collapsing under the weight of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: The Fed Goes All In With Unlimited Bond-Buying Plan
first_paragraph: The Federal Reserve, determined to try to keep the spread of the coronavirus from devastating the American economy, rolled out a series of sweeping new programs on Monday meant to shore up large and small businesses and keep markets functioning.

title: SoftBank Says It Will Sell $41 Billion in Assets to Buy Back Shares
first_paragraph: SoftBank, operator of the world’s largest tech fund, said on Monday that it would sell as much as $41 billion in assets as it seeks to vacuum up its own shares, which have dropped precipitously in the last month amid investor concerns about the coronavirus outbreak.

title: Logged On From the Laundry Room: How the C.E.O.s of Google, Pfizer and Slack Work From Home
first_paragraph: On Thursday morning, Chuck Robbins, the chief executive of Cisco, signed on to an companywide video conference from his home office in Silicon Valley. The connection was stable, but the quality was not great.

title: The U.S. Needs China’s Masks, as Acrimony Grows
first_paragraph: American front-line medical personnel are running desperately short of masks and protective equipment as they battle the coronavirus outbreak. China, already the world’s largest producer of such gear by far, has ramped up factory output and is now signaling that it wants to help.

title: Rupert Murdoch Put His Son in Charge of Fox. It Was a Dangerous Mistake.
first_paragraph: The chief executive of Fox News, Suzanne Scott, reacted swiftly to the threat of the coronavirus in late February: She ordered the bright, open new offices disinfected, installed hand sanitizer stations around the office and boldly canceled the company’s major ad sales event.

title: Governments and Companies Race to Make Masks Vital to Virus Fight
first_paragraph: President Trump on Saturday sought to assure an anxious American public that help was on the way to overwhelmed hospitals, and that private companies had agreed to provide desperately needed medical supplies to fight the fast-spreading coronavirus.

title: Freezers Sell Out as Consumers Stock Up
first_paragraph: The calls come every five minutes, Chris Rouse said, all asking for the same thing: a small chest freezer. That’s a problem for Mr. Rouse, an appliance salesman in the Town of Wallkill, N.Y. He has no more to sell.

title: ‘Terrified’ Package Delivery Employees Are Going to Work Sick
first_paragraph: Hour after hour, day after day, the packages keep arriving: food, medicine, clothes, toys and a million other items brought to the doorsteps and building lobbies of Americans who are hunkering down as the coronavirus sweeps the land.

title: As Crisis Deepens, Companies Hand Out Cash to Workers
first_paragraph: A thousand dollars here, $200 there, free lunch once a week, stipends for electronic equipment: Those are some of the ways the biggest companies in the United States have come up with to help their employees get through the coronavirus crisis.

title: Fed Backstops Corner of Municipal Debt Markets Amid Calls for Support
first_paragraph: The Federal Reserve tiptoed into the market for municipal debt on Friday, a small move that economists, lawmakers and state treasurers say should be expanded as the coronavirus places huge financial pressure on local governments.

title: American Oil Drillers Were Hanging On by a Thread. Then Came the Virus.
first_paragraph: Wall Street supercharged America’s energy boom of the past decade by making it easy for oil companies to finance growth with cheap, borrowed money. Now, that partnership is in tatters as the coronavirus pandemic has driven the fastest collapse of oil prices in more than a generation.

title: Stock Market’s Gain Under Trump Vanishes
first_paragraph: Before he was sworn in as president, Donald J. Trump made clear that he would treat the stock market as a crucial yardstick of his success in office.

title: How Marie Kondo Declutters During a Pandemic
first_paragraph: The tidying guru Marie Kondo built her global lifestyle brand by developing a system for how to impose order over relentless chaos. “My dream is to organize the world,” Ms. Kondo has said.

title: When Stocking Grocery Shelves Turns Dangerous
first_paragraph: They are a new class of emergency medical workers: the more than two million Americans reporting to work each day to sell food and other household staples to a country in the midst of a coronavirus pandemic.

title: Coronavirus Brings a Surge to News Sites
first_paragraph: They Slack. And the journalists stuck working from home also plan their coverage through videoconferencing applications like Google Hangouts, Zoom, UberConference, BlueJeans and Nexi.

title: The Most Crucial Tools for WFH: Kindness, and a Piece of Tape
first_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, even if you want them withheld. Letters may be edited.

title: Chinese Copper, Italian Marble: Coronavirus Shipping Delays Hurt Developers
first_paragraph: When it comes to obtaining building materials, real estate developers often buy globally, not locally. But as the coronavirus spreads across the world, bringing countries to a standstill, the lack of access to overseas supplies is sending jitters through the construction industry.

title: Starbucks Is Closing Cafes and Boeing Says Executives Will Forgo Pay
first_paragraph: Starbucks informed staff that it would close its cafes in the United States in response to the coronavirus crisis, though it will remain open for delivery and drive-through customers, the company said in an emailed statement on Friday.

title: Will ‘Helicopter Money’ and the ‘Big Bazooka’ Help Rescue Europe?
first_paragraph: Don’t worry about government deficits so much and start spending. Get ready to use the “big bazooka” by issuing eurobonds. Drop cash from the sky.

title: A Torrent of Job Losses Threatens to Overwhelm the U.S. Economy
first_paragraph: In an early sign of the coronavirus pandemic’s devastating impact on American workers, the Labor Department on Thursday reported a 30 percent increase in unemployment claims last week, one of the largest spikes on record.

title: After Mounting Criticism, Tesla Will Shut Down California Factory
first_paragraph: Tesla, the luxury electric carmaker, said on Thursday that it would shut down production at its San Francisco Bay Area factory, which has remained open for several days in apparent defiance of a local county order.

title: ‘Today’ Show Goes On, With a Homebound Savannah Guthrie
first_paragraph: On Thursday at 7 a.m., Hoda Kotb welcomed viewers to NBC’s “Today” show, as she does every weekday morning. This time, however, she was alone at the desk, without her co-anchor.

title: How Trump’s Attacks on the Fed Have Made Its Job Harder
first_paragraph: President Trump has spent two years publicly attacking the Federal Reserve and undercutting its chair, Jerome H. Powell. That animosity is making it difficult for Washington to project a united front as it stares down the most significant economic threat since the Great Recession.

title: Witnessing the Birth of the Coronavirus Economy
first_paragraph: stunned by its emptiness, the usual din quieted by stay-at-home orders from companies and the government. For the first time, the vast, star-covered ceiling seemed appropriate.

title: Amid Virus and Market Tumult, Wall Street Lives a New Reality
first_paragraph: Investors, corporations and trading clients are turning to Wall Street amid one of the most tumultuous periods in market history to borrow money, buy or sell assets, and limit losses on existing holdings. But Wall Street itself is grappling with a challenge it had never faced: how to protect employees from a worsening public-health threat while managing clients who need their services around the clock.

title: Fed Faces Pressure to Do More as Virus Demands a Response
first_paragraph: Over a frenetic two weeks, as the coronavirus has upended American capitalism and changed every aspect of life, the Federal Reserve has taken drastic steps to keep money flowing throughout the financial system.

title: Some Countries Are Better Armored for Epidemics Than Others
first_paragraph: No European country is escaping the economic consequences of the coronavirus, but the pain won’t be divided equally.

title: Federal Reserve Gives Emergency Aid to Mutual Funds
first_paragraph: The Federal Reserve said late Wednesday night that it would offer emergency loans to money market mutual funds, its latest in a series of steps to keep the financial system functioning and prop up the economy as it spirals toward recession during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Europe’s Central Bank Vastly Expands Stimulus Measures
first_paragraph: The European Central Bank will begin an enormous new wave of bond purchases meant to counteract the “serious risks” to the eurozone caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Washington Weighs Big Bailouts to Help U.S. Economy Survive Coronavirus
first_paragraph: Entire sectors of the American economy are shutting down, threatening to crush businesses, put millions of people out of work and forcing lawmakers to consider a vast financial bailout that would dwarf the federal government’s response to the 2008 crisis.

title: Automakers to Close Factories in North America
first_paragraph: With fear of infection rising among factory workers, and few customers shopping for cars, several automakers on Wednesday decided to idle their plants in the United States, Canada and Mexico for at least a week. The decisions will put tens of thousands of people out of work and add to the coronavirus outbreak’s growing economic toll.

title: Movie Theater Owners: We Need a Bailout, Too
first_paragraph: With movie theaters across the country shutting their doors and furloughing the majority of their hourly workers, the National Association of Theater Owners asked Congress and the Trump administration on Wednesday for relief measures meant to help multiplexes stay solvent until business can resume.

title: Plight of Retail Workers: ‘I’m Scared to Go to Work’
first_paragraph: The Macy’s in Manhattan’s Herald Square opened its doors to customers at 10 a.m. on Tuesday, as planned.

title: There Aren’t Enough Ventilators to Cope With the Coronavirus
first_paragraph: As the United States braces for an onslaught of coronavirus cases, hospitals and governments are confronting a grim reality: There are not nearly enough lifesaving ventilator machines to go around, and there is no way to solve the problem before the disease reaches full throttle.

title: This Is the Only Way to End the Coronavirus Financial Panic
first_paragraph: The Covid-19 crisis will take time to be solved by science. The economic crisis can be solved right now.

title: SoftBank May Not Buy $3 Billion in WeWork Shares
first_paragraph: SoftBank, the Japanese conglomerate, is threatening to withdraw an offer to acquire a much larger stake in WeWork, according to a person familiar with the matter. The surprise move comes as the coronavirus outbreak diminishes demand for the troubled company’s shared office space.

title: Mortgage Lenders Consider Plan to Suspend Payments Amid Crisis
first_paragraph: Businesses across the country have ground to a halt because of the coronavirus outbreak, leaving millions of Americans wondering how they will make their next mortgage payments.

title: Boeing Mirrors the Economy. It Doesn’t Look Good.
first_paragraph: As the crisis caused by the coronavirus continues to spiral out of control, the vast ramifications of the global economy’s screeching to a halt are already on display at one of most important companies in the United States: Boeing.

title: U.A.W. Says Automakers Will Address Coronavirus Concerns at Car Plants
first_paragraph: The United Automobile Workers union said Tuesday night that the three Detroit automakers had agreed to address concerns about coronavirus hazards to factory workers by taking steps short of shutting down U.S. production.

title: Coronavirus Is Closing Social Security Offices. Here’s How to Get Benefit Help.
first_paragraph: The Social Security Administration operates a vast network of more than 1,200 offices around the country that help thousands of Americans every day with applications for retirement, disability and Medicare benefits.

title: China Announces That It Will Expel American Journalists
first_paragraph: In a sharp escalation of tensions between the two superpowers, China announced on Tuesday that it would expel American journalists working for The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post. It also demanded that those outlets, as well as the Voice of America and Time magazine, provide the Chinese government with detailed information about their operations.

title: Glued to TV for Now, but When Programming Thins and Bills Mount …
first_paragraph: It happened around the world, and now it’s happening in the United States: The more people stay home to avoid the coronavirus pandemic, the more they find themselves glued to their screens.

title: Fed Unveils Emergency Lending Programs as Companies Struggle to Raise Cash
first_paragraph: The Federal Reserve took a series of steps on Tuesday to prop up the American economy, saying first that it would begin buying up a type of debt that companies issue for short-term cash and then, later in the day, establishing a lending program meant to help the banks at the core of the financial system function smoothly.

title: As Market Convulses, Big Banks Plan to Borrow Funds From Fed
first_paragraph: Eight major financial-services firms are borrowing money from the Federal Reserve, a day after the central bank urged them to tap its short-term funding facility to make it easier for credit to continue flowing through the economy, as the coronavirus pandemic continues to roil markets.

title: America’s Economy Begins to Shut Down as Pandemic Measures Take Hold
first_paragraph: In some places, public officials and private business owners moved with stunning speed. In others, paralyzing hesitancy, defiant bravado or blithe disregard dominated. But by Monday, it was clear everywhere that most of the American economy was grinding to an unparalleled halt and would remain that way for months.

title: Businesses Face a New Coronavirus Threat: Shrinking Access to Credit
first_paragraph: Jeffrey Albrecht, who owns three Holiday Inn hotels in southern Ohio, watched as $200,000 disappeared from his books in just three days as people began canceling bookings.

title: Markets Plunge as a Global Recession Appears Almost Inevitable
first_paragraph: Financial markets imploded again on Monday, as increasingly alarmed investors feared that the global economy could experience a downturn rivaling the cataclysmic recession after the financial crisis a decade ago.

title: ‘People Need Immediate Relief,’ and Online Donors Make It Happen
first_paragraph: Shortly before midnight on Thursday, the author Shea Serrano was at his home in San Antonio, lying comfortably on his sofa watching television. He could not shake a bad feeling about all the low-wage and hourly workers losing desperately needed tips and shifts because of the coronavirus outbreak.

title: France’s Bistros Close, in a Frenzy of Donated Cheese and Pâté
first_paragraph: Xavier Denamur is used to bustling between the five popular bistros he owns in the Marais neighborhood of central Paris, managing a team of nearly 70 waiters and chefs and keeping tabs on the phalanx of patrons who crowd his tables, elbow-to-elbow, year round.

title: Hotels Were Rolling Out Tools to Help Calm Travelers. Then Coronavirus Hit.
first_paragraph: Hotels have always been in the business of providing a good night’s rest, but a growing number of brands are adding tools to help guests chill out and get to sleep.

title: How Big Businesses Get a ‘Deep Clean’
first_paragraph: On a recent day on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, traders were cheek-to-cheek as stock prices flashed above them. They stood in clusters shouting, sharing screens, sharing pizza, sharing pens. They shook hands, leaned over shoulders, patted each others’ backs, hugged. There were no windows open.

title: Coronavirus Could End China’s Decades-Long Economic Growth Streak
first_paragraph: China’s growth streak has lasted for decades, surviving the crackdown at Tiananmen Square, the global financial crisis and the trade war with the United States. But it might not endure the coronavirus epidemic, making it nearly impossible for the rest of the world to escape a slowdown.

title: Coronavirus Outrage Spurs China’s Internet Police to Action
first_paragraph: As China tries to reshape the narrative of its fumbled response to the coronavirus outbreak, it is turning to a new breed of police that carry out real-world reprisals for digital misdeeds.

title: When Facebook Is More Trustworthy Than the President
first_paragraph: For some Americans, reality arrived Jan. 25, when a Harvard epidemiologist tweeted “HOLY MOTHER OF GOD.” Or on Feb. 29, when researchers announced they had found cases in Seattle.

title: Fed Slashes Rates to Near-Zero and Unveils Sweeping Program to Aid Economy
first_paragraph: With the fast-spreading coronavirus posing a dire threat to economic growth, the Federal Reserve on Sunday night took the dramatic step of slashing interest rates to near-zero and unveiled a sweeping set of programs in an effort backstop the United States economy.

title: ‘There Is Plenty of Food in the Country’
first_paragraph: The aisles and aisles of empty store shelves give the appearance that the United States, improbably and alarmingly, is running out of food.

title: Saudi Aramco’s Profits Slip as Oil Prices Fall
first_paragraph: Saudi Aramco, the world’s largest oil company, said on Sunday that its profit last year fell more than 20 percent, primarily because of lower oil prices.

title: Coronavirus Cost to Businesses and Workers: ‘It Has All Gone to Hell’
first_paragraph: A week ago, Mark Canlis’s restaurant in Seattle was offering a $135 tasting menu to a bustling dining room every night. Eileen Hornor’s inn on the Maine coast was booking rooms for the busy spring graduation season. And Kalena Masching, a real estate agent in California, was fielding multiple offers on a $1.2 million home.

title: U.S. Weighs Tariff Relief but Some Fear China Will Take Advantage
first_paragraph: The coronavirus outbreak is prompting a heated debate among lawmakers and the White House over whether the Trump administration should remove the tariffs it has imposed on China and other nations to provide some economic relief.

title: Trump Administration Is Relaxing Oversight of Nursing Homes
first_paragraph: The Trump administration has been working to relax regulations governing America’s nursing homes, including rules meant to curb deadly infections among elderly residents.

title: Trump Says He Could Demote Fed Chair Powell, Risking More Market Turmoil
first_paragraph: President Trump said on Saturday that he had the power to remove or demote Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, renewing a long-running threat against the central bank’s leader at a time when it could further roil volatile markets.

title: Ticketholders Seek Refunds as Coronavirus Prompts Mass Cancellations
first_paragraph: With governments and health officials trying to limit the spread of the coronavirus by discouraging or banning large gatherings, the highly contagious virus has had a palpable impact on the plans of would-be vacationers, theatergoers, sports fans and others.

title: Internet Providers Won’t Cut Off Users Over Unpaid Bills for 60 Days
first_paragraph: AT&T, Comcast and dozens of other telecommunications firms have committed to not disconnecting service to residential and small business customers who can’t pay their bills because of the coronavirus outbreak, the Federal Communications Commission said on Friday.

title: Trump Is Losing Money in the Markets, Too
first_paragraph: President Trump, the first self-proclaimed billionaire to occupy the White House, has long asserted that he is one of the world’s best businessmen and investors.

title: As China Cracks Down on Coronavirus Coverage, Journalists Fight Back
first_paragraph: When Jacob Wang saw reports circulating online recently suggesting that life was getting better in Wuhan, the center of the coronavirus outbreak, he was irate.

title: Fox Business Benches Trish Regan After Outcry Over Coronavirus Comments
first_paragraph: The Fox Business anchor Trish Regan, whose on-air dismissal of the coronavirus as “another attempt to impeach the president” left her cable network facing a firestorm of criticism this week, has been removed from her prime-time slot for the foreseeable future, the network said on Friday.

title: Is There Really a Toilet Paper Shortage?
first_paragraph: If there’s one image that captures the panic seeping through the United States this week, it might be the empty store shelves where toilet paper usually sits.

title: Europe Pledges Billions in Economic Aid in Rare Sign of Unity
first_paragraph: In an unusual show of unity and resolve, European leaders said they would spend hundreds of billions of euros to prevent the coronavirus outbreak from provoking a deep recession or financial crisis.

title: Buying a Home During a Pandemic
first_paragraph: Your down payment fund was safely in cash. You’d planned, perhaps for years, for the 2020 home-buying season. Then, just as the perfect home hit the market, the coronavirus turned the world on its head.

title: The World Needs Masks. China Makes Them, but Has Been Hoarding Them.
first_paragraph: As hospitals and governments hunt desperately for respirators and surgical masks to protect doctors and nurses from the coronavirus pandemic, they face a difficult reality: The world depends on China to make them, and the country is only beginning to share.

title: Markets Plunge. Economies Stall. Panic Spreads. It All Feels Very 2008.
first_paragraph: The last time the world seized with panic over an economic catastrophe, those given the job of limiting the damage knew what to do. The global financial crisis of 2008 presented a textbook case of what happens when people lose faith in the banking system all at once. World leaders could rely on lessons gleaned from history to forge a plan: They flooded the markets with money and waited for calm to return.

title: Stocks Rally as Trump and Business Leaders Pledge Support
first_paragraph: Stocks rallied Friday, rebounding from their worst day in more than 30 years, after President Trump said leaders of private companies in the United States had agreed to help with efforts to test for the coronavirus, and declared a national emergency that would free billions in funding to fight the epidemic.

title: Congress Nears Stimulus Deal With White House as Wall Street Suffers Rout
first_paragraph: Financial markets plunged on Thursday in the biggest one-day drop since the Black Monday stock market crash of 1987, and Congress neared a deal with the White House on a sweeping economic rescue package to respond to the colossal effect of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Disney Parks and Cruise Line Will Close in Response to Coronavirus
first_paragraph: Every Disney theme park worldwide will be closed starting this weekend, including Disney World in Florida and the Disneyland Resort in California, because of the coronavirus pandemic, the company said on Thursday. Disney Cruise Line will also close.

title: Starbucks’ Gathering-Spot Model Is Threatened by Coronavirus
first_paragraph: For millions of people, visiting Starbucks is a daily ritual. But these are extraordinary times for one of the world’s most popular brands.

title: Europe’s Central Bank’s Steps to Stem Coronavirus Damage Leave Investors Cold
first_paragraph: The European Central Bank joined other central banks Thursday in taking forceful action to prevent the spread of the coronavirus from undermining the global economy. But the bank disappointed expectations it would cut interest rates as the eurozone hurtles toward recession.

title: Airlines Cancel Flights and Lay Off Workers as Stocks Plummet
first_paragraph: Airlines around the world on Thursday scrambled to cancel flights, lay off workers and reassure anxious travelers, capping a dizzying period of weeks in which bookings have evaporated and investors have lost confidence in the industry.

title: Halting China’s Economy Was Hard. Restarting It Is Harder.
first_paragraph: China is starting to get back to work. More than six weeks after its leaders virtually shut down the world’s second-largest economy to stop a relentless coronavirus outbreak, factories are reopening and offices are starting to fill.

title: Trump’s Payroll Tax Cut Would Dwarf the 2008 Bank Bailout
first_paragraph: Almost overnight, President Trump has gone from insisting the economy would not need fiscal help to weather the coronavirus to proposing a stimulus plan that would cost more than the 2008 Wall Street bank bailout or the 2009 stimulus bill aimed at digging the United States out of a deep recession.

title: ‘Massive Shock’ and Battered Airline Stocks in Europe With Trump’s Travel Ban
first_paragraph: President Trump’s abrupt decision to shut America’s borders to most European travelers sowed chaos at the Continent’s airports and at travel-related businesses Thursday, as airlines scrambled to figure out how to halt flights to the United States and governments warned of potentially devastating financial costs.

title: Walmart, Uber and Others Tweak Sick-Leave Policies as Coronavirus Spreads
first_paragraph: Walmart, Uber and other major companies announced new policies this week to grant paid leave or other compensation to workers who contract the new coronavirus or are quarantined by order of the government or their companies.

title: Dow Ends 11-Year Bull Market as Coronavirus Defies Economic Remedies
first_paragraph: The coronavirus outbreak ended one of the longest winning streaks in market history on Wednesday as the Dow Jones industrial average plunged and global policymakers grappled with the growing economic crisis.

title: TV Talk Shows Throw Out the Audience
first_paragraph: “It feels like we’re auditioning,” a dazed Ryan Seacrest said on live television Wednesday morning, before a sea of empty seats.

title: Coronavirus Spurs U.S. Efforts to End China’s Chokehold on Drugs
first_paragraph: The global spread of the coronavirus is reigniting efforts by the Trump administration to encourage more American manufacturing of pharmaceuticals and reduce dependence on China for the drugs and medical products that fuel the federal health care system.

title: U.S. Airlines Say They Can Absorb Impact of Coronavirus on Travel
first_paragraph: The coronavirus has pummeled airlines in the United States, especially in recent weeks, but the industry is prepared to suffer the blows.

title: Trump to Meet Bank Executives Amid Market Turmoil
first_paragraph: As the markets rage and more businesses reel from the impact of the spreading coronavirus, President Trump plans to meet with officials from the nation’s banks at the White House on Wednesday afternoon.

title: Cruise Line Ads Get Caught in a Coronavirus News Cycle
first_paragraph: The CNN show “Erin Burnett OutFront” spent much of its time on Friday focused, like many other news programs, on the coronavirus outbreak and the thousands of people isolated on the Grand Princess cruise ship near California.

title: Trump Pitches Coronavirus-Related Stimulus Package on Capitol Hill
first_paragraph: President Trump took his pitch for a coronavirus-related economic stimulus package to Capitol Hill on Tuesday, joining Senate Republicans over lunch to discuss cutting payroll taxes, offering targeted relief to tourism and hospitality industries, and other possible steps to lift economic growth.

title: European Carmakers Worry Coronavirus Outbreak May Hurt Sales
first_paragraph: European auto manufacturers have so far defied expectations that supply chain chaos would bring their assembly lines to a standstill.

title: Economy Faces ‘Tornado-Like Headwind’ as Financial Markets Spiral
first_paragraph: The fast-spreading coronavirus and a plunge in oil prices set off a chain reaction in financial markets on Monday, a self-perpetuating downward cycle that could inflict serious harm on the global economy.

title: Saudi Oil Price Cut Is a Market Shock With Wide Tremors
first_paragraph: The sudden upheaval in the oil markets may claim victims around the world, from energy companies and their workers to governments whose budgets are pegged to the price of crude.

title: How a Saudi-Russian Standoff Sent Oil Markets Into a Frenzy
first_paragraph: For the last three years, two factors have been hugely influential in the oil markets. The first has been the surge of shale oil production in the United States, which has turned the country from a large oil importer to an increasingly important exporter. The second is the alliance between Saudi Arabia and Russia, which recently have cooperated in trimming production to try to counter shale’s impact.

title: Europe Is Probably in Recession. Can Its Leaders Move Fast and Deliver Relief?
first_paragraph: Europe had already been teetering toward trouble. Even before the coronavirus outbreak quarantined the industrial heart of Italy and emptied the teeming streets of Venice, before France banned public gatherings and major trade shows were canceled in Germany and Spain, economists were openly warning about the prospect of an economic downturn across the continent.

title: As Stock Markets Plunge, Trump Calls for Economic Response to Coronavirus
first_paragraph: President Trump has spent the past several weeks dismissing concerns about any economic effects from the coronavirus and insisting that American companies and consumers are in no danger.

title: In Coronavirus Fight, China’s Vulnerable Fall Through the Cracks
first_paragraph: Lucifer Zhang, who is deaf and cannot speak, was able to get by on her $140 monthly stipend from the government. Then China locked down her home city, Wuhan, in late January to contain the coronavirus outbreak.

title: Oil Prices Dive as Saudi Arabia Takes Aim at Russian Production
first_paragraph: Saudi Arabia slashed its export oil prices over the weekend in what is likely to be the start of a price war aimed at Russia but with potentially devastating repercussions for Russia’s ally Venezuela, Saudi Arabia’s enemy Iran and even American oil companies.

title: Wall Street Had 2 Terrible Weeks. Here’s How 7 Traders Dealt With It.
first_paragraph: The past two weeks were among the worst in recent Wall Street history, as anxiety about the coronavirus outbreak gave way to alarm and drove panicked investors to sell their stock holdings, obliterating roughly $2 trillion in wealth.

title: E.U. Seeks Solidarity as Nations Restrict Medical Exports
first_paragraph: Top European Union officials called on Friday for solidarity among member countries in the face of the coronavirus, responding to moves by some nations to restrict exports on equipment that could be used to combat the outbreak.

title: Oil Prices Nose-Dive as OPEC and Russia Fail to Reach a Deal
first_paragraph: Oil prices plummeted on Friday after major producers failed to reach an agreement to reduce production, as concerns about coronavirus’s impact on the economy spread across the globe.

title: Paid to Stay Home: Europe’s Safety Net Could Ease Toll of Coronavirus
first_paragraph: Keeping your salary while caring for a quarantined child. Exercising the right to not work if you are afraid of getting ill. Sick-leave pay for up to six months.

title: Bonds Hit Historic Lows, Prompting Fed to Ponder: What More Can We Do?
first_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, watched warily as diagnosed cases of coronavirus ticked higher and the stock market sank lower through the final week of February.

title: U.S. Added 273,000 Jobs in February Before Coronavirus Spread Widely
first_paragraph: For the second month in a row, the economy churned out a blockbuster number of jobs, the government reported Friday, an impressive performance in an era of slow-and-steady employment growth.

title: Why the Coronavirus Could Threaten the U.S. Economy Even More Than China’s
first_paragraph: After a string of deaths, some heart-stopping plunges in the stock market and an emergency rate cut by the Federal Reserve, there is reason to be concerned about the ultimate economic impact of the coronavirus in the United States.

title: Stocks and Bond Yields Sink, Capping a Week of Wild Trading
first_paragraph: Wall Street was gripped by another wave of worry over the spreading coronavirus on Friday. Stocks tumbled, investors rushed into the safety of government bonds, and oil prices nose-dived.

title: Fed Official Says Central Bankers Are Aligned in Coronavirus Response
first_paragraph: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York president, John C. Williams, made clear on Thursday evening that officials viewed the emergency rate cut they approved earlier this week as part of an international push to cushion the economy as the coronavirus threatens global growth.

title: Coronavirus Will Cost Businesses Billions. Insurance May Not Help.
first_paragraph: one that would make a company whole if its business tanked in an epidemic. For months, there were no takers.

title: ‘Almost Without Precedent’: Airlines Hit Hard by Coronavirus
first_paragraph: Empty jumbo jets arriving at deserted airports. Masked passengers disinfecting their own seats. Stone-faced airline executives huddling with President Trump.

title: OPEC Proposes a Large Cut in Oil Output
first_paragraph: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries proposed Thursday that oil output be curbed by 1.5 million barrels a day, or 1.5 percent of world oil supplies, to deal with the effects of the spreading coronavirus outbreak on demand.

title: A Global Outbreak Is Fueling the Backlash to Globalization
first_paragraph: Well before a deadly virus began spreading across multiple borders, a world defined by deepening interconnection appeared to be reassessing the merits of globalization.

title: Flybe, a British Regional Airline, Stops Flying
first_paragraph: Flybe, an ailing regional airline in Britain that was praised for flying into underserved corners of the country, ceased operations on Thursday after financial strains caused by coronavirus.

title: Airlines Feel Deepening Impact as Coronavirus Upends Travel
first_paragraph: Since the financial crisis a decade ago, airlines in the United States have consolidated and tightened operations, taken advantage of changing travel habits and created new offerings for passengers, engineering an extended stretch of profitability.

title: With Oil Prices Down 20%, OPEC Pushes for Stability
first_paragraph: A 20 percent plunge in oil prices this year since the coronavirus outbreak took hold has alarmed the world’s top oil officials, and their challenge to prop up prices keeps getting harder.

title: NBC Plans for Tokyo Olympics as Coronavirus Worries Advertisers
first_paragraph: If NBCUniversal is anxious about how coronavirus may affect its plans for the Olympic Games, it is trying not to show it.

title: ‘Contagion,’ Steven Soderbergh’s 2011 Thriller, Is Climbing Up the Charts
first_paragraph: One of the hottest movies in the Warner Bros. library is a nine-year-old drama that kills off Gwyneth Paltrow in its first 15 minutes.

title: Stocks Surge as Biden Leads Super Tuesday Results
first_paragraph: Shares on Wall Street rose on Wednesday, bouncing back from a steep drop the day before, as investors responded to Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s strong showing in the Democratic Party’s primaries and congressional efforts to combat the spread of the coronavirus.

title: What Happens in Vegas if No One Stays in Vegas?
first_paragraph: This week, thousands of people will travel to Las Vegas for business conferences. The annual South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex., is scheduled for this month.

title: Global Health Crisis 1, Economic Policymakers 0
first_paragraph: The people who control money had hoped for so much more. The news that the world’s wealthiest countries were convening to orchestrate a response to the deadly coronavirus outbreak had resonated across economies like the sound of whirring helicopters bringing relief to a disaster zone.

title: As Coronavirus Disrupts Factories, India Curbs Exports of Key Drugs
first_paragraph: The spreading coronavirus may soon affect people’s health in a different way: The outbreak is now starting to hurt the supply of essential drugs.

title: Economic Powers Vow to Fight Crisis
first_paragraph: Central bankers and political leaders of the United States and other economic powers expressed their resolve to combat economic damage from the coronavirus on Tuesday, but stopped short of promising interest rate cuts or other immediate rescue measures.

title: Will the Coronavirus Cause a Recession? Keep Your Eye on the Barbershops
