first_paragraph: Europe is emerging from a monthslong lockdown. But the universe in which Europeans are resurfacing is neither the reality they knew, nor an entirely new one.

title: As Prime Minister, Boris Johnson Struggles to Find His Voice
first_paragraph: After a week when protesters battled with police outside his residence, spray-painted “racist” on a memorial to Winston Churchill and dumped the statue of a 17th-century slave trader into Bristol harbor, Prime Minister Boris Johnson knew he was going to face questions about race and justice in Parliament.

title: ISIS Attacks Surge in Iraq Amid Debate on U.S. Troop Levels
first_paragraph: The assailants came at dusk, creeping on foot through the dusty palm groves near the Tigris River, armed only with a rocket-propelled grenade, a light machine gun and Kalashnikovs. They had laid roadside bombs to kill anyone who rushed to help the unsuspecting local guards, who were in their sights.

title: I.M.F. Approves Critical Loan for Ukraine
first_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has won an important vote of confidence in his promised anti-corruption efforts as the International Monetary Fund has approved a multibillion-dollar lending program for the country.

title: Ukraine’s Backlog of Babies Born to Surrogates Begins to Ease
first_paragraph: For weeks, more than 100 foreign genetic parents of babies born to surrogate mothers in Ukraine have been waiting nervously, prevented by Ukraine’s rigid coronavirus restrictions from entering the country to pick up their newborns.

title: Indonesia’s New Coronavirus Concern: A Post-Pandemic Baby Boom
first_paragraph: The government vehicles began appearing in Indonesian towns and cities in May, equipped with loudspeakers blaring a blunt message.

title: In a Province No Stranger to War, Preparing to Battle a New Enemy
first_paragraph: An activist who has supported the democracy protests against Syria’s authoritarian president since they began nine years ago knows a thing or two about battling adversity. But Hosam al-Ali, 35, is more than a little worried about his new adversary: the coronavirus.

title: The World Reopens, Despite Skyrocketing Coronavirus Cases
first_paragraph: Two months ago, when there were roughly one million confirmed coronavirus cases and the primal politics of survival was sweeping the world, shutting down was the order of the day.

title: Its Defenses Undone by a Virus, France Seeks Lessons From a Lost War
first_paragraph: It became the indispensable book of the pandemic, its French author revealing how society’s weaknesses and human frailties gave way to disaster. As the coronavirus tore through France, intellectuals, historians and journalists cracked open their old copies in search of eternal truths in an unsettling time.

title: ‘Get Rid of Them’: A Statue Falls as Britain Confronts Its Racist History
first_paragraph: With a mix of pent-up fury and sudden elation, the protesters who toppled a bronze statue of the 17th-century slave trader Edward Colston in Bristol, England, on Sunday recalled the angry crowds that brought down statues of Saddam Hussein, Stalin and even King George III.

title: Just as Air Travel Is Picking Up, U.K. Imposes a Quarantine
first_paragraph: When the coronavirus was spreading at breakneck speed this spring, Britain’s government flatly refused to quarantine travelers, even those arriving from virus hot spots like Spain or Iran.

title: Mexico’s Leftist Leader Rejects Big Spending to Ease Virus’s Sting
first_paragraph: For the second time in a month, top business leaders sat down with Mexico’s president to implore him to do more to save the economy.

title: China Hails Its Virus Triumphs, and Glosses Over Its Mistakes
first_paragraph: Under continued fire for its early mishandling of the coronavirus, the Chinese government vigorously defended its actions in a new, detailed account on Sunday that portrays the country’s approach to combating the outbreak as a model for the world.

title: China Vowed to Keep Wildlife Off the Menu, a Tough Promise to Keep
first_paragraph: Bamboo rats lifted Mao Zuqin out of poverty. Now, because of the coronavirus pandemic, poverty threatens again.

title: U.K. Lab to Sidestep Drug Industry to Sell Potential Virus Vaccine
first_paragraph: A prominent British laboratory is forming a special partnership that would sidestep the drug industry to sell a potential vaccine against the coronavirus without profits or licensing fees in Britain and in low- and middle-income countries.

title: China Defends Its Coronavirus Response
first_paragraph: The Chinese government on Sunday strongly defended its handling of the coronavirus, pushing back at criticism that officials had suppressed early reports of the outbreak and contending instead that China had set a strong example for how to combat it.

title: Coronavirus Depletes the Keepers of Europe’s Memory
first_paragraph: For years, Gildo Negri visited schools to share his stories about blowing up bridges and cutting electrical wires to sabotage Nazis and fascists during World War II. In January, the 89-year-old made another visit, leaving his nursing home outside Milan to help students plant trees in honor of Italians deported to concentration camps.

title: Amazon Deforestation Soars as Pandemic Hobbles Enforcement
first_paragraph: Since coming to office, President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil has enabled increased razing of the Amazon rainforest.

title: Huge Crowds Around the Globe March in Solidarity Against Police Brutality
first_paragraph: They were warned by Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia against attending Black Lives Matter marches on Saturday because of the coronavirus risk, but tens of thousands would not be deterred.

title: Coronavirus Nearly Ended Street Homelessness in U.K. Maybe Not for Long.
first_paragraph: Driving through the East London borough of Newham recently, Ryan Anderson and Billy Tattingham pointed out some of the places they had slept before the coronavirus outbreak.

title: Macron Beat Back the Coronavirus. France Is Not Impressed.
first_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron’s government has beaten back the coronavirus, prevented mass layoffs, propped up the salaries of the unemployed, staved off long food lines, and achieved a lower death rate than its neighbors, Germany excepted.

title: How the Coronavirus Makes a No-Deal Brexit More Likely
first_paragraph: The coronavirus epidemic in Britain has killed more than 40,000 people, sickened hundreds of thousands more, including Prime Minister Boris Johnson, and paralyzed the economy. Now it may claim another casualty: a trade agreement between Britain and the European Union.

title: Musicians Playing Through the Lockdown, to One Listener at a Time
first_paragraph: Patrick Kingsley, an international correspondent, and Laetitia Vancon, a photojournalist, are driving more than 3,700 miles to explore the reopening of the European continent after coronavirus lockdowns. Read all their dispatches.

title: Mexico Is Reopening After Quarantine. Many Worry It’s Too Early.
first_paragraph: Packed street markets. Buzzing metro stations. Thronged sidewalks. And noticeably fewer people wearing masks.

title: Coronavirus Rips Into Regions Previously Spared
first_paragraph: For months, one enduring mystery of the coronavirus was why some of the world’s most populous countries, with rickety health systems and crowded slums, had managed to avoid the brunt of an outbreak that was burning through relatively affluent societies in Europe and the United States.

title: Amsterdam’s Red Light Zone Stays Shut as Rest of City Edges Open
first_paragraph: The red lights still shone above the windows in De Wallen, Amsterdam’s main red-light district, but the windows themselves were empty.

title: What Will It Take to Reopen the World to Travel?
first_paragraph: After months of locked-down borders, countries that have stifled the coronavirus are trying to choreograph a risky dance: how to bring back visitors without importing another burst of uncontrolled contagion.

title: Powerful Cyclone Lashes Mumbai as City Grapples With Coronavirus
first_paragraph: A powerful cyclone slammed into India’s coast Wednesday afternoon, striking the commercial hub of Mumbai, lashing beach towns with heavy rain and strong winds, and pushing thousands of people into emergency shelters.

title: Yemen Aid Falls Short, Threatening Food and Health Programs
first_paragraph: International donors pledged about $1.35 billion in humanitarian aid for Yemen on Tuesday, far short of the $2.4 billion the United Nations had said was needed to pull a country shredded by years of war, hunger and disease from the brink of further disaster.

title: Embattled at Home, Trump Finds Himself Isolated Abroad, Too
first_paragraph: With American cities burning and the coronavirus still raging, killing more people than in any other country, President Trump also has growing problems overseas. He has never before been so isolated and ignored, even mocked.

title: As Protests Engulf the United States, China Revels in the Unrest
first_paragraph: The cartoon shows the Statue of Liberty cracking into pieces, a police officer breaking through its copper robe. A man’s head lies on the ground in front of the White House, its facade splattered with blood.

title: New Ebola Outbreak in Congo, Already Hit by Measles and Coronavirus
first_paragraph: A fresh outbreak of the deadly Ebola virus has flared up in the Democratic Republic of Congo, a country that was already contending with the world’s largest measles epidemic, as well as the coronavirus.

title: Putin Sets New Date for Vote on Extending His Rule
first_paragraph: Pushing to get his political program back on track, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said on Monday that a referendum on constitutional changes that would allow him to dispense with term limits and stay in office until 2036 would be held on July 1.

title: Global Anger Grows Over George Floyd Death, and Becomes an Anti-Trump Cudgel
first_paragraph: Mass protests over the police killing of another black man in the United States spread globally in the past few days, as many demonstrators not only expressed solidarity with their American counterparts but denounced racism in their own countries.

title: Resisting Lockdown, Nicaragua Becomes a Place of Midnight Burials
first_paragraph: Just hours after Yamil Acevedo died in a hospital, funeral home workers in hazardous materials suits strapped his coffin to the back of a pickup truck, drove it to a cemetery and buried him in the dark of night.

title: Coronavirus Turns a Spanish Sea Delicacy Back Into Daily Fare
first_paragraph: With an intensity of flavor to match their color, the big, bright-red prawns caught off Spain’s eastern coast are the kind of delicacy that someone might eat once or twice in a year and remember fondly for the rest of it.

title: U.S. Sends Two Million Doses of Hydroxychloroquine to Brazil
first_paragraph: The United States has delivered two million doses of a malaria drug to Brazil for use in the fight against the coronavirus pandemic, and the two countries are embarking on a joint research effort to study whether the drug is safe and effective for the prevention and early treatment of Covid-19, the White House announced Sunday.

title: China and India Brawl at 14,000 Feet Along the Border
first_paragraph: High in the Himalayas, an enormous fistfight erupted in early May between the soldiers of China and India. Brawls at 14,000 feet along their inhospitable and disputed frontier are not terribly unusual, but what happened next was.

title: In Some Nations, Coronavirus Is Only One of Many Outbreaks
first_paragraph: A dengue epidemic ravaged Honduras last year, sickening over 100,000 people and leaving 180 dead. As this year began, officials braced for another surge in cases of the mosquito-borne disease and wondered how they would manage with their frail public health system and shortage of trained personnel.

title: Coronavirus Slams Broken, Embattled Yemen
first_paragraph: In northern Yemen, more and more people are falling ill and dying after having trouble breathing, yet the Iran-backed group that controls the region, the Houthis, has acknowledged only a few coronavirus deaths.

title: When Going to Work Means Taking a Calculated Risk
first_paragraph: Last week I spoke with one of Canada’s leading experts about the effects of working from home. But the coronavirus shutdown has also created a class of people who still go to their regular workplaces but may not want to be there.

title: In Brazil, a President Under Fire Lashes Out at Investigators
first_paragraph: The embattled president of Brazil stood outside his mansion on Thursday, indignant and angry, wearing a necktie patterned with assault rifles.

title: Older Italians Warily Eye Young Crowds, Fearing 2nd Coronavirus Wave
first_paragraph: After months of living under a strict lockdown in Italy, a closely gathered group of teenagers welcomed a warm evening this week at a verdant park in Milan, gazing at phone screens, embracing and forming a small circle around a playful dog. No one wore a mask.

title: Its Coronavirus Caseload Soaring, India Is Reopening Anyway
first_paragraph: Its coronavirus cases are skyrocketing, putting it among the world’s most worrisome pandemic zones in recent weeks. Nonetheless, India is reopening, lifting its lockdown at what experts fear may be the worst time.

title: ‘It’s Too Late’: In Sprawling Indonesia, Coronavirus Surges
first_paragraph: The 1,340 Maluku Islands are a long way from anywhere. So remote are these Indonesian isles that the country’s most famous novelist was imprisoned there in a gulag that was actually an archipelago.

title: Proud of Your Lockdown Baking? This Man Built a Giant Kookaburra
first_paragraph: Some have taken to baking to while away the hours during coronavirus lockdown; others embraced gardening. For Farvardin Daliri, it was the perfect opportunity to complete his magnum opus: a 15-foot-tall replica of a bird known as a laughing kookaburra.

title: ‘It’s Not the Virus’: Mexico’s Broken Hospitals Become Killers, Too
first_paragraph: The senseless deaths torment doctors and nurses the most: The man who died because an inexperienced nurse unplugged his ventilator. The patient who died from septic shock because no one monitored his vital signs. The people whose breathing tubes clogged after being abandoned in their hospital beds for hours on end.

title: A €750 Billion Virus Recovery Plan Thrusts Europe Into a New Frontier
first_paragraph: For decades, even when the 2008 financial crisis threatened to blow the bloc apart, the European Union’s wealthier nations resisted the notion of collective debt. But the coronavirus has so fundamentally damaged the bloc’s economy that it is now forcing European leaders to consider the sort of unified and sweeping response once thought unworkable.

title: Boris Johnson Defends ‘Toxic’ Aide Again. Why Protect a Political Burden?
first_paragraph: Prime Minister Boris Johnson went to the mat yet again on Wednesday for his embattled adviser, Dominic Cummings, signaling to lawmakers that he had no plans to dismiss Mr. Cummings for breaching the rules by driving 260 miles to his parents’ house during the country’s coronavirus lockdown.

title: ‘Overtaken by Aliens’: India Faces Another Plague as Locusts Swarm
first_paragraph: Magan Doodi, a groundskeeper at a golf course in Jaipur, was making his rounds earlier this week when he saw the sky suddenly turn a weird pink.

title: Canada’s ‘Voice of the Nation’ Rings Out in a Capital Quieted by a Virus
first_paragraph: Finding a spot on the sweeping lawn in front of Canada’s ornately Gothic Parliament buildings to hear a concert this month was not a problem in the middle of a pandemic.

title: Visiting My Grandparents, Separated by Plexiglass
first_paragraph: Elian Peltier, who is based in London, covered the coronavirus pandemic in Spain before returning to his home country, France. We asked him to tell us about a visit to his grandparents.

title: Dominic Cummings Offers a Sorry-Not-Sorry for U.K. Lockdown Breach
first_paragraph: Prime Minister Boris Johnson took a breathtaking gamble with his own popularity on Monday, allowing his closest aide to go public with a detailed, yet stubbornly unapologetic, explanation for making a 260-mile journey that broke lockdown rules and ignited a political firestorm in Britain.

title: ISIS Prisoners Threaten U.S. Mission in Northeastern Syria
first_paragraph: A year after American-backed forces seized the last remnant of territory under Islamic State rule in Syria, some 10,000 captured ISIS fighters in Kurdish-run wartime prisons pose “a significant risk” to the United States mission in the country’s northeast, military commanders say.

title: On a Scottish Isle, Nursing Home Deaths Expose a Covid-19 Scandal
first_paragraph: On the Isle of Skye off the western coast of Scotland, residents thought they had sealed themselves off from the coronavirus. They shuttered hotels. Officials warned of police checks. Traffic emptied on the only bridge from the mainland.

title: Coronavirus Threatens China’s Devotion to Chopsticks and Sharing Food
first_paragraph: At Chilli Kitchen in Beijing, spicy and mouth-numbing Sichuan dishes are laid out family style. Using red chopsticks, diners dive into steaming bowls of pork wontons bathed in fragrant chili oil and sesame seeds, and rummage through platters filled with dried red chili peppers to unearth juicy bits of roasted fish.

title: Putin Speaks, Officials Shrug, and Doctors Are Caught in the Middle
first_paragraph: Assailed by critics as an absentee leader at the start of the coronavirus crisis in Russia, President Vladimir V. Putin re-emerged with a splash on state television last month to show that he cared and was taking charge.

title: Spain’s Courts, Already Strained, Face Crisis as Lockdown Lifts
first_paragraph: A flood of new court cases, some with little precedent, is expected to deluge a Spanish judicial system already gasping for breath, bogged down by delays and lagging in technology.

title: New Zealand Earthquake Interrupts Jacinda Ardern’s TV Interview
first_paragraph: A sizable earthquake struck New Zealand on Monday, shaking Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern during a live television interview, but failing to cause major damage or disrupt Ms. Ardern’s calm demeanor.

title: Boris Johnson Backs Top Aide Accused of Flouting Lockdown Rules
first_paragraph: Prime Minister Boris Johnson, defying a storm of criticism, said on Sunday that he would not dismiss his most influential adviser, Dominic Cummings, for breaching Britain’s lockdown rules by driving across the country to visit relatives, even when he was falling ill with the coronavirus.

title: Push to Reopen Houses of Worship in Europe and Mideast Brings Perils and Tensions
first_paragraph: As nations weigh the calculus of reopening parts of society after locking down because of the coronavirus, Germany has plunged ahead after bringing its outbreak under control, reopening houses of worship and allowing the faithful to gather again in larger numbers.

title: For Some Italians, the Future of Work Looks Like the Past
first_paragraph: On a small farm outside Rome, workers crouched in the corridors of a cornfield and tended to stalks for the coming harvest. The ones from Morocco, Romania and Nigeria knew exactly what to do. It was the new Italian hires who needed help.

title: Hong Kong Police Fire Tear Gas as Protesters Resist China’s Grip
first_paragraph: Thousands of protesters swarmed some of Hong Kong’s busiest neighborhoods on Sunday, singing, chanting and erecting roadblocks of torn-up bricks and debris, as the police repeatedly fired tear gas, pepper spray and a water cannon during the city’s largest street mobilization in months.

title: Afghan Sides Agree to Rare Cease-Fire During Eid al-Fitr
first_paragraph: The Taliban and the Afghan government announced a cease-fire for the three days of the Islamic festival Eid al-Fitr, which starts on Sunday in Afghanistan, offering the war-torn nation a rare respite from violence that has been intensifying.

title: Is It Time to Stop Clapping for Health Care Workers? An Organizer Thinks So
first_paragraph: On Thursday nights, Britons bang pots and pans and let out hearty cheers of support for doctors and nurses who care for coronavirus patients and for other essential workers amid the pandemic.

title: Rattled by a Pandemic, People Turn to Leaders — Any Leaders
first_paragraph: As world leaders grapple with when and how to safely reopen their countries, many are also facing a political problem: how to maintain support as they oversee tanking economies, stifling restrictions and staggering death tolls.

title: European Defense and ‘Strategic Autonomy’ Are Also Coronavirus Victims
first_paragraph: The coronavirus has upended the best-laid plans and priorities of many, including the European Union. But one of the biggest casualties may be European efforts to build a more credible and independent European military.

title: Jacinda Ardern Sold a Drastic Lockdown With Straight Talk and Mom Jokes
first_paragraph: Halfway into a Facebook Live video last week, updating the world on New Zealand’s plan to reopen restaurants, schools and even movie theaters, Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern noticed a concern cropping up among the commenters: They thought she looked tired.

title: Virus Lockdown Forces Iran Into Its First Virtual Quds Day
first_paragraph: For the past four decades, on the last Friday of Ramadan, supporters of Iran’s government have marched to denounce Israel. They burn Israel’s flag. They mock effigies of the leaders of Israel and of its patron, the United States. They chant pledges to liberate Jerusalem, or Quds, as the city is known in Arabic.

title: What’s Lost and Gained When We Put In 9-to-5 From Home?
first_paragraph: On Thursday, Tobi Lütke, the founder and chief executive of Ottawa-based Shopify, announced on Twitter that most of his company’s 5,000 employees had permanently become stay-at-home workers.

title: Argentina Tries to Escape Default as It Misses Bond Payment
first_paragraph: Argentina missed a bond payment on Friday and inched closer to another crushing default, which would plunge it into a new period of economic isolation and deepen a recession that has been exacerbated by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Britain Orders a 14-Day Quarantine on Arriving Travelers
first_paragraph: Britain on Friday moved ahead with a 14-day mandatory quarantine on arriving travelers, and heavy fines for those who break the rules, outlining strict new travel restrictions as other European nations are thinking about easing theirs.

title: Coronavirus Cases Fall in Europe’s Capitals, but Fears Over Reopening Linger
first_paragraph: During a week of bluebird skies and Mediterranean temperatures, when sunbathers thronged parks and cars poured back onto streets, one sound has been notably absent in London: the wail of ambulance sirens.

title: Why the Call to Prayer Made Me Cry This Ramadan
first_paragraph: Abdi Latif Dahir is a Kenyan who was appointed the East Africa correspondent for The New York Times last year. He has fasted every day of Ramadan since he was 9 years old.

title: Democracy Fades in Malaysia as Old Order Returns to Power
first_paragraph: The members of Malaysia’s Parliament, wearing face masks to match their crisp white uniforms, convened this week in the vast lower house chamber for the first time this year.

title: U.K. to Quarantine All Incoming Air Travelers; a Chinese Coronavirus Vaccine Shows Promise
first_paragraph: Britain will quarantine everyone flying into the country, including citizens, for 14 days beginning June 8 to fight the spread of the coronavirus, Home Secretary Priti Patel announced on Friday.

title: Boris Johnson Avoids Criminal Inquiry Into His Dealings as London’s Mayor
first_paragraph: A British police watchdog agency said on Thursday that it would not conduct a criminal investigation into Prime Minister Boris Johnson over claims that as mayor of London he had done official favors for an American businesswoman whose apartment he sometimes visited during working hours.

title: Cyclone Amphan’s Death Toll Rises to 80 in India and Bangladesh
first_paragraph: More than 80 people were killed by the powerful cyclone that slammed into India and Bangladesh on Wednesday, wiping out thousands of homes and drenching low-lying areas in torrential rain, officials said on Thursday.

title: Coronavirus Changed China’s Big Political Event. Here’s What to Expect.
first_paragraph: China’s biggest event on the political calendar, the annual session of the National People’s Congress, is always a tightly choreographed legislative pageant aimed at conveying the strength of the ruling Communist Party.

title: In Istanbul Under Lockdown, Baklava Makers Are Essential Workers
first_paragraph: Every weekend, for over a month now, Istanbul has been under a strict curfew because of the coronavirus. No one is allowed out, not for exercise or groceries, and the police impose fines. Sometimes, like last weekend and next, the street-emptying lockdown stretches for four days to take in public holidays.

title: After New Coronavirus Outbreaks, China Imposes Wuhan-Style Lockdown
first_paragraph: In Shulan, a city in China’s northeast, the streets are eerily quiet, devoid of taxis and buses. Apartment complexes have been sealed off, confining residents inside. Teams of government workers go door to door rounding up sick people as part of what they call a “wartime” campaign.

title: As Paris Tiptoes Toward Normalcy, Infections Are Sharply Down
first_paragraph: Coronavirus infections have dropped sharply in Paris following a strict two-month lockdown and a growing contact tracing effort, health officials say, and they have remained in check since the city began a halting return to life nearly two weeks ago.

title: Future of Shakespeare’s Globe Theater Is Threatened by Lockdown
first_paragraph: Shakespeare’s Globe, a celebrated institution in London that showcases some of the world’s most recognizable stage plays, is in danger of permanently closing if it does not receive emergency funding to help make up for revenue it has lost during the coronavirus lockdown.

title: In China’s Crisis, Xi Sees a Crucible to Strengthen His Rule
first_paragraph: Before an adulatory crowd of university professors and students, China’s leader, Xi Jinping, offered a strikingly bold message about the global coronavirus pandemic. Summoning images of sacrifice from Communist Party lore, he told them that the calamity was ripe with possibility for China.

title: Iran Extends Temporary Release of British-Iranian Woman
first_paragraph: A British-Iranian woman who was granted temporary release from prison in Iran in March amid the coronavirus pandemic has had her furlough extended indefinitely, her family said on Wednesday, raising hopes that she could be granted clemency and return to Britain.

title: Burundi Turns Out to Replace President of 15 Years, Pandemic or No
first_paragraph: Standing shoulder to shoulder without masks or gloves, throngs of voters in Burundi waited in long lines on Wednesday to mark their ballots to replace the country’s long-reigning, autocratic president.

title: After Cyclone Hits India and Bangladesh, the Waiting Begins
first_paragraph: This live briefing has ended. The day after the cyclone struck, the death toll rose in Bangladesh and India.

title: Cambridge University Will Hold Its Lectures Online Next Year
first_paragraph: Cambridge on Tuesday became the first British university to move all student lectures online for the coming academic year, underscoring the far-reaching changes the coronavirus is forcing on higher education institutions around the world.

title: Iran Quietly Lowers the Temperature With U.S.
first_paragraph: After years of increasing tensions that nearly led to war, Iran has moderated its approach to the West, shifting from a policy of provocation to one of limited cooperation. The change reflects an effort to avoid direct confrontation with the United States that the Iranians say could benefit President Trump in the November election.

title: One Crisis Too Many: How the Coronavirus Pushed Germany to Shift Course
first_paragraph: In her time as chancellor of Germany, Angela Merkel has seen the European Union put to the test by Brexit, a wave of migration, the Greek debt crisis and populism, and still she held to a largely steadfast course.

title: For Boris Johnson, Parliament Is Becoming a House of Horrors
first_paragraph: For Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, debating in Parliament used to be a raucous affair, as backbenchers from his Conservative Party hollered and whooped, booing his rivals and cheering him on like a classmate in a schoolyard brawl. These days, to his evident chagrin, it is more like a legal deposition.

title: Amid Pandemic, Finding Normalcy in the Abnormal
first_paragraph: Two blocks from my apartment on the western edge of Hong Kong Island, a Starbucks has been transformed into what looks like a construction zone, or maybe a strange art installation.

title: Clinic Bombed as Afghan Forces Fend Off Taliban Attack on Kunduz
first_paragraph: In a day of intensifying violence across Afghanistan, the country’s security forces bombed a clinic in the northern province of Kunduz on Tuesday in their efforts to thwart another coordinated assault by the Taliban on the provincial capital that the militants have twice overrun and continue to besiege.

title: Raids Reveal Massive Fentanyl Production in Myanmar
first_paragraph: The jungle-covered hills of Shan State in Myanmar might seem an unlikely outpost along global trade routes. But it is the remote region, wracked by ethnic conflict and undisturbed by normal policing, where much of the world’s synthetic drug trade originates.

title: Super Cyclone Bears Down on India and Bangladesh
first_paragraph: A crushing cyclone barreled up the Bay of Bengal on Tuesday, heading for a swampy stretch along the border of India and Bangladesh and threatening to unleash 165-mile-an-hour winds and massive floods when it makes landfall on Wednesday.

title: Italy’s Great Beautification: Hair Salons Are Back
first_paragraph: As Italy further loosened Europe’s first lockdown against the coronavirus and allowed restaurants, bars, churches and stores to open, Lucilla Vettraino went directly to her hair salon.

title: Merkel, Breaking German ‘Taboo,’ Backs Shared E.U. Debt to Tackle Virus
first_paragraph: Faced with economic calamity and the threat of the coronavirus further fracturing the European Union, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Monday broke with decades of German economic orthodoxy and agreed to back the idea of collective European debt to help those countries that have been hit hardest by the pandemic.

title: Toronto Was Obeying Social Distance Rules. Then Came Adorable Baby Foxes.
first_paragraph: A crowd of people bunched shoulder to shoulder one recent spring day on a boardwalk overlooking Lake Ontario. They leaned over a waist-high fence, taking pictures with their phones.

title: Lesotho’s Leader, Long Suspected in Wife’s Murder, Resigns
first_paragraph: The leader of Lesotho, accused of being behind the murder of his estranged wife, announced his resignation on Tuesday, possibly paving the way for him to be formally charged in the killing.

title: Iran Sees New Surge in Virus Cases After Reopening Country
first_paragraph: When Iran began to reopen late last month, commuters packed subways and buses, young people lined up for takeout hamburgers and pizza, and traffic snarled highways. Shoppers crowded the traditional bazaars of Isfahan and Tehran. Worshipers resumed communal prayer at mosques during Ramadan evenings.

title: Yes, Those Were Sex Dolls Cheering On a South Korean Soccer Team
first_paragraph: As a handful of the world’s sports leagues inch back to life, they have sought ways to maintain a bit of the old pre-pandemic festivity in stadiums devoid of spectators.

title: Hope, Fear and Grief: Wuhan After the Lockdown Ends
first_paragraph: They have delighted in the small things, like getting bubble tea and takeout noodles. They have rediscovered places like the neighborhood playground. They have searched for new vocabularies to describe their losses.

title: Farm Workers Airlifted Into Germany Provide Solutions and Pose New Risks
first_paragraph: In a normal season, as many as 300,000 migrant workers from Eastern Europe make their way to Germany to harvest asparagus, pick strawberries and plant late-season crops.

title: Canadian Military Jet Crashes During Flyover for Coronavirus Workers, Killing One
first_paragraph: A Canadian Air Force jet crashed, killing one of the military personnel on board, in Kamloops, British Columbia, on Sunday during a flyover that was intended as a tribute to Canadians, especially those on the front lines of the coronavirus pandemic, the authorities said.

title: Covid-19 Outbreak in Nigeria Is Just One of Africa’s Alarming Hot Spots
first_paragraph: In the northern Nigerian city of Kano, some people say they now get four or five death notices on their phones each day: A colleague has died. A friend’s aunt. A former classmate.

title: Ending Crisis, Israel Swears in Netanyahu-Led Government to Rescue Economy
first_paragraph: Ending a 510-day political crisis that three elections had failed to resolve, Israel on Sunday swore in a new government charged with responding to the coronavirus pandemic, extending Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s record-setting tenure just a week before his corruption trial is set to begin.

title: Afghan Rivals Sign Power-Sharing Deal as Political Crisis Subsides
first_paragraph: Afghanistan’s monthslong election dispute, which resulted in the bizarre reality of two men taking the oath of office as president, reached a resolution on Sunday when President Ashraf Ghani gave his chief rival, Abdullah Abdullah, the leading role in the country’s peace process with the Taliban and the right to appoint half the cabinet.

title: Will Cirque du Soleil Rise Again?
first_paragraph: Until the coronavirus pandemic hit, the Mongolian contortionist Uranbileg Angarag wowed spectators nightly at Cirque du Soleil shows on a cruise ship, contorting her body into a ball and balancing on a vertical stick held in her mouth.

title: Wandering a Grand Hotel Emptied by Coronavirus, and Checking 1,400 Taps
first_paragraph: Every five days, Daniel Ordoñez opens 1,400 pipe taps in a waterfront hotel here in Barcelona that locals call “The Sail” because of its shape.

title: 100 Babies Stranded in Ukraine After Surrogate Births
first_paragraph: The babies lie in cribs, sleeping, crying or smiling at nurses, swaddled in clean linens and apparently well cared for, but separated from their parents as an unintended consequence of coronavirus travel bans.

title: Stuck at Home, Men in Japan Learn to Help. Will It Last?
first_paragraph: Susumu Kataoka was just looking for a diversion from long days sheltering at home with his family during the coronavirus outbreak. He grabbed his drone and took it for a spin around their Tokyo house, snapping some pictures and posting them on Facebook.

title: Modi’s Popularity Soars as India Weathers the Pandemic
first_paragraph: Just before the coronavirus arrived in India, Prime Minister Narendra Modi faced serious challenges, perhaps the biggest of his tenure.

title: Another Health Minister in Brazil Exits Amid Chaotic Coronavirus Response
first_paragraph: The Brazilian government’s chaotic response to the coronavirus pandemic worsened Friday as its latest health minister quit barely a month into the job, with daily deaths from infection climbing and a defiant president exhorting people to get back to work.

title: What Coronavirus Means for Going to the Lake
first_paragraph: Like many Canadians in areas where this is a holiday weekend, my wife and I would normally be at our cottage, dragging outdoor furniture and small boats out of their winter dens, assessing the handiwork of mice and squirrels and generally getting set up for a summer of fun.

title: U.K. Coronavirus Testers Pay Price for a Day of Triumph
first_paragraph: On May 1, a visibly relieved Matt Hancock announced that the British government had exceeded its target of 100,000 coronavirus tests a day. As health secretary, Mr. Hancock had set the goal after enduring intense criticism for the country’s lagging coronavirus testing program.

title: Why Are Women-Led Nations Doing Better With Covid-19?
first_paragraph: Monday was a day of triumph for Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern. Thanks to the efforts of the entire nation, she said, New Zealand had been largely successful in meeting its ambitious goal of eradicating, rather than just controlling, outbreaks of Covid-19. The lockdown she had put in place on March 25 could now end.

title: From ‘Respect’ to ‘Sick and Twisted’: How Coronavirus Hit U.S.-China Ties
first_paragraph: “Evil.” “Lunacy.” “Shameless.” “Sick and twisted.” China has hit back at American criticism over its handling of the coronavirus pandemic with an outpouring of vitriol as acrid as anything seen in decades.

title: ‘A Lot of Bad News Out There’: Parenting in a Pandemic
first_paragraph: I didn’t want to be that parent, the one who talks about how when I was a child I had to walk uphill both ways, in the snow, just to get to school.

title: In Jerusalem, Ramadan Restrictions Last Seen During the Crusades Return
first_paragraph: The last time Muslim worshipers were kept out of the Aqsa Mosque compound throughout the entire month of Ramadan was when crusaders controlled Jerusalem in the Middle Ages.

title: Australia Is Returning to Normal. What Does That Mean?
first_paragraph: Recently, as coronavirus restrictions began lifting, I met up with my good friend Sofia for a long walk along Sydney’s coastline. The weather had turned, finally, from a perennial summer to something chillier, but the ocean was full of the usual smattering of surfers and brave swimmers.

title: Severe Tropical Storm Vongfong Takes Aim at Philippine Heartland
first_paragraph: Tens of thousands of people fled to evacuation centers on Friday as the first typhoon to hit the Philippines this season barreled toward the main island of Luzon, dumping torrential rains and raising fears that the coronavirus could spread in crowded shelters.

title: As Coronavirus Overruns Russia, Doctors Are Dying on the Front Lines
first_paragraph: Dr. Rimma Kamalova says her hospital’s leadership ignored her warnings about an unexplained pneumonia outbreak back in March. She kept working.

title: Here’s How Wuhan Plans to Test All 11 Million of Its People for Coronavirus
first_paragraph: Wuhan, the Chinese city where the coronavirus pandemic began, has announced an ambitious plan to test all of its 11 million residents for the virus in the coming days, a campaign that will be closely watched by governments elsewhere.

title: Duterte’s Shutdown of TV Network Leaves Void Amid Coronavirus Crisis
first_paragraph: Through earthquakes and typhoons, floods and political turmoil, Fe Repalde knew she could count on one constant: Her tiny, flickering television was always tuned to ABS-CBN, one of the most influential networks in the Philippines.

title: Typhoon Vongfong Makes Landfall in the Philippines
first_paragraph: A typhoon packing winds of nearly 100 miles per hour made landfall in the eastern Philippines on Thursday after gathering strength across the Pacific Ocean, prompting evacuations and raising concerns that the nation’s most populous area may still lie in its path.

title: At Least 70 Dead in Mexico From Drinking Tainted Alcohol
first_paragraph: At least 70 people have died across Mexico since late April after drinking tainted alcohol, including at least 20 residents of a poor mountain town in the central state Puebla who consumed a cheap, popular moonshine.

title: Matt Damon Dishes About His Irish Lockdown in Radio Interview
first_paragraph: Matt Damon has broken his silence about riding out the coronavirus lockdown in a seaside town in Ireland, dishing to a Dublin radio station about his newest FaceTime buddy (Bono) and what he was carrying in a SuperValu bag (beach towels) when he was spotted by locals.

title: Across Europe, Reopening Borders in Time for Summer
first_paragraph: Europeans longing to swap their balconies for beaches, mountains or museums elsewhere on the continent got a morale boost on Wednesday, when the European Commission recommended the reopening of borders that were closed to stop the spread of the coronavirus.

title: In Italy, Some Fear the Virus Is a Get-Out-of-Jail Card for Mafiosi
first_paragraph: They were among the most vulnerable as the coronavirus roared through Italy: older or riddled with serious underlying medical conditions. A brush with the virus within the confines of the place where they woke up each morning might seriously threaten their lives.

title: Where Bats Are Still on the Menu, if No Longer the Best Seller
first_paragraph: Six days a week, the butchers of Tomohon gather at Indonesia’s most notorious market and cut up bats, rats, snakes and lizards that were taken from the wilds of Sulawesi island.

title: Three Months, Two Continents and Four Stints in Quarantine
first_paragraph: Before the pandemic, my friends called me “the empress,” a joking reference to my last name. But these days, they have begun referring to me by another, slightly less esteemed royal moniker: I am now the Quarantine Queen.

title: Coronavirus ‘May Never Go Away,’ a Top W.H.O. Official Warns
first_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has devastated the tourism industry, as countries sealed their borders, flights ground to a halt and billions of people sheltered at home.

title: Germany’s ‘R-Naught’: Are Three Days Over 1.0 Cause for Worry?
first_paragraph: When Chancellor Angela Merkel explained “R-naught,” or the reproduction variable, for the coronavirus during a news conference last month, she identified 1.0 as a key threshold.

title: Modi Announces $260 Billion Coronavirus Rescue Package for India
first_paragraph: In a televised address Tuesday night, India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi, announced an economic rescue package of more than $260 billion for a nation that, although relatively successful in controlling coronavirus infections, has been left economically devastated.

title: From Maternity Ward to Cemetery, a Morning of Murder in Afghanistan
first_paragraph: The morning was not yet over, but already it felt as if the very cycle of life in Afghanistan was under assault, with attacks at a maternity ward and a funeral serving as grim reminders that its people are in peril from cradle to grave.

title: ‘The New Church of England’: Coronavirus Renews Pride in U.K.’s Health Service
first_paragraph: Outside her home in south London, Gill Cronin bangs a metal pot with a wooden spoon as a motorbike passes, its horn blaring. On the dot of 8 p.m., the street erupts in a noisy tribute to Britain’s health workers.

title: Bafflement Greets Boris Johnson’s Plan for Reopening Britain
first_paragraph: When the coronavirus first struck, Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain agonized long and hard before closing stores, pubs and restaurants as part of the country’s fight against the disease. But with the spread of the virus now curbed, easing the lockdown is proving harder still.

title: A Coronavirus Mystery Explained: Moscow Has 1,700 Extra Deaths
first_paragraph: Ever since the coronavirus took hold globally, researchers have been puzzled by Russia’s mortality rate of only about 13 deaths per million, far below the world average of 36 in a country with an underfunded health system.

title: China Is Defensive. The U.S. Is Absent. Can the Rest of the World Fill the Void?
first_paragraph: When Australia started pushing for a global inquiry into the origins of the coronavirus pandemic, no other countries were on board, and officials had no idea how it would work or how harshly China might react.

title: Ethiopian Troops May Have Shot Down Aid Plane in Somalia, Report Says
first_paragraph: A plane carrying humanitarian supplies that crashed in Somalia on Monday may have been shot down by Ethiopian troops, according to a new report from the office of the African Union Force Commander in Somalia.

title: Britain to Impose Quarantine on Air Travelers to Fight Coronavirus
first_paragraph: Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced on Sunday that Britain would soon impose a mandatory quarantine on travelers arriving in the country by air to try to avert a new wave of coronavirus infections, signaling how cautious the country will be in relaxing its seven-week lockdown.

title: As Europe Reopens Schools, Relief Combines With Risk
first_paragraph: It was Lea Hammermeister’s first day back at school after almost two months at home and she was already preparing for a test.

title: Lebanon’s Economic Crisis Explodes, Threatening Decades of Prosperity
first_paragraph: Flawed policies and sudden shocks have thrust Lebanon into its worst economic crisis in decades, with its currency collapsing, businesses shutting, prices for basic goods skyrocketing and the threat of hunger looming for its poorest people.

title: Surviving Covid-19 May Not Feel Like Recovery for Some
first_paragraph: When Morena Colombi tested negative for the coronavirus on March 16, the official tallies counted her among the Covid-19 recoveries, a success amid the tragedies overwhelming Italy. But she was nowhere near recovered, her cough and crippling fatigue nowhere near gone.

title: ‘A Nightmare’: Losing a Home to Australia’s Fires, Then Locked Down by a Virus
first_paragraph: The scent of burning debris had just begun to fade from Lindy Marshall’s memory when disaster struck again.

title: In U.K., Hard-Hit Minority Communities Struggle to Bury the Dead
first_paragraph: Normally, the mosque, one of England’s largest, would be filled with thousands of worshipers during the holy month of Ramadan, but now it is mostly empty, except for stacks of coffins.

title: Europe’s Battle-Hardened Nations Show Resilience in Virus Fight
first_paragraph: As the coronavirus has hopscotched the world, a paradox has emerged: Rich nations are not necessarily better at fighting the crisis than poorer ones.

title: Bangkok Opens Up as Virus Caseloads Drop, and Pretty Pups Benefit
first_paragraph: When the coronavirus lockdown in Bangkok eased a bit after six weeks, the first appointment my family made was not for a medical checkup or a walk in a park.

title: As South Korea Eases Limits, Virus Cluster Prompts Seoul to Close Bars
first_paragraph: while keeping a vigilant eye out for any sign of backsliding, any need for restrictions to snap back into place.

title: Taiwan’s Weapon Against Coronavirus: An Epidemiologist as Vice President
first_paragraph: The calls come at night, when Taiwan’s vice president, Chen Chien-jen, is usually at home in his pajamas. Scientists seek his advice on the development of antiviral medications. Health officials ask for guidance as they investigate an outbreak of the coronavirus on a navy ship.

title: A Novelist Breaks the Code of Being a Woman in Japan
first_paragraph: To explain the pressure felt by women in Japanese society, the novelist Mieko Kawakami recalls a playground prank from elementary school.

title: Argentina Teeters on Default, Again, as Pandemic Guts Economy
first_paragraph: Argentina is hurtling toward default on international loans in two weeks, a prospect that threatens to revive its reputation as a serial deadbeat and global financial pariah that could haunt the Latin American country long after the coronavirus pandemic is over.

title: Taking on Covid-19, South Africa Goes After Cigarettes and Booze, Too
first_paragraph: The dealer had a stash, but the young woman wasn’t getting through the door without an introduction. That’s where her friend, already a trusted customer, came in. And even then there were complications.

title: Russia Was Ready to Celebrate a Glorious Past. The Present Intervened.
first_paragraph: As the coronavirus began its silent but relentless march on Moscow in February, the names of the millions of Russian soldiers killed in the far deadlier horrors of World War II were already appearing, one by one, on state television, scrolling down the screen in a harrowing torrent.

title: Locked Down on V-E Day, Europe Celebrates World War II Liberation
first_paragraph: There were no poignant handshakes with veterans. Military parades were canceled. Wreaths were laid, but with appropriate social distancing.

title: As India Reopens, Deadly Accidents Break Out
first_paragraph: Sixteen migrant workers were crushed to death by a freight train in central India on Friday as they were traveling home, the latest casualties connected to India’s coronavirus lockdown and efforts to reopen the economy.

title: Hidden Toll: Mexico Ignores Wave of Coronavirus Deaths in Capital
first_paragraph: The Mexican government is not reporting hundreds, possibly thousands, of deaths from the coronavirus in Mexico City, dismissing anxious officials who have tallied more than three times as many fatalities in the capital than the government publicly acknowledges, according to officials and confidential data.

title: Reopenings Mark a New Phase: Global ‘Trial-and-Error’ Played Out in Lives
first_paragraph: The world is entering a period of high-stakes experimentation, with cities and countries serving as open-air laboratories for how to most safely and effectively reopen amid the coronavirus.

title: Pandemic Forces Poland to Delay Presidential Election
first_paragraph: Poland’s presidential election has been postponed just days before the governing party planned to go forward with a hastily organized, mail-in vote that had been denounced by opposition candidates as a power grab.

title: Israeli Army’s Idea Lab Aims at a New Target: Saving Lives
first_paragraph: The Israeli Defense Ministry’s research-and-development arm is best known for pioneering cutting-edge ways to kill people and blow things up, with stealth tanks and sniper drones among its more lethal recent projects.

title: Coronavirus Killing Black Britons at Twice the Rate of Whites
first_paragraph: Black people in England and Wales are twice as likely to die from the coronavirus as white people, even accounting for differences in class and in some underlying health measures, according to official figures released on Thursday, laying bare an extraordinary gap in the toll of the coronavirus.

title: Google Sibling Abandons Ambitious City of the Future in Toronto
first_paragraph: Citing the economic turmoil from the coronavirus pandemic, a corporate sibling of Google said on Thursday that it had abandoned ambitious plans to create a sensor-laden, data driven “city of tomorrow” out of a shabby district along Toronto’s Lake Ontario shoreline.

title: As Local Health Systems Buckle, Russia’s Oligarchs Take Charge
first_paragraph: As the coronavirus pandemic gained pace in Russia this spring, a billionaire steel magnate, Aleksei A. Mordashov, called four regional governors and urged them to lock down the cities where he operates.

title: Filipino Musicians Drive Hong Kong’s Music Scene, but Gigs Have Dried Up
first_paragraph: The lively melodies were resounding off wood, glass and marble as the pianist performed jazz standards at a swanky hotel lobby.

title: Parents Nervously Return to Work in Italy. Children Are Still at Home.
first_paragraph: When Chiara Monti went to her office on Monday morning, she joined millions of Italians returning to work after nearly two months of being on lockdown because of the coronavirus. And when she arrived, she immediately went to the personnel office and asked to have her hours reduced.

title: Iraq Chooses New Prime Minister, an Ex-Intelligence Chief Backed by U.S.
first_paragraph: Iraq’s Parliament chose an American-backed former intelligence chief as the new prime minister early Thursday morning, giving the country its first real government in more than five months as it confronts an array of potentially crippling crises.

title: Germany’s Reopening Offers Hope for a Semblance of Normal Life
first_paragraph: Germany was a leader in the West in taking on the coronavirus pandemic, and then a leader in the calibrated restarting of public life. On Wednesday, Chancellor Angela Merkel had a hopeful message for the nation: The experiment was working.

title: As U.K. Deaths Mount, Political Terrain Gets Trickier for Boris Johnson
first_paragraph: For Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, the political risks of running up the worst death toll in Europe from the coronavirus became starkly clear on Wednesday in a near-empty House of Commons, where he faced off for the first time against the new leader of the opposition, Keir Starmer.

title: Kenya and Somalia to Jointly Investigate Cargo Plane Crash
first_paragraph: Somali and Kenyan officials have agreed to jointly investigate the crash of a private cargo plane in Somalia on Monday, an incident many thought could further escalate political tensions between the two countries.

title: Despite Rising Tensions, Iran and U.S. Are Negotiating a Prisoner Release
first_paragraph: Iran and the United States are negotiating a deal that would release a United States Navy veteran held by the Iranian authorities in exchange for an Iranian-American doctor detained by the Americans, according to a senior Iranian official and a spokesman for the veteran’s family.

title: As India Loosens Its Strict Lockdown, Coronavirus Deaths Jump Sharply
first_paragraph: Part of India’s success in blunting the spread of the coronavirus had been a fierce lockdown that was zealously obeyed.

title: Erdogan Faces His Biggest Test of the Pandemic: The Economy
first_paragraph: An economic crisis was looming even before the coronavirus gripped Turkey with unexpected ferocity. But the contagion has quickly and ruthlessly laid bare the ways President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has left the economy vulnerable, presenting him with the greatest challenge of his 18 years in power.

title: In a Town Split by a Border, Virus Rules Vary From Door to Door
first_paragraph: With the border dividing the Netherlands and Belgium cutting straight through the entrance of her studio and art gallery, Sylvia Reijbroek was confused over which country’s rules to follow when the coronavirus upended Europe.

title: Herd Immunity, or Big 2nd Wave? Israel Antibody Testing Hopes to Find Out
first_paragraph: Israel, whose aggressive response to the coronavirus has held its fatality rate to a fraction of those of the United States and other hard-hit nations, is readying a nationwide serological test of 100,000 citizens to see how widely the virus has spread across its population and how vulnerable it may be to a new wave of the contagion.

title: New Report Says Coronavirus May Have Made Early Appearance in France
first_paragraph: Weeks before Chinese authorities acknowledged that the coronavirus could be transmitted by humans, and nearly a month before the first officially recorded cases in Europe, a 42-year-old fishmonger showed up at a hospital in suburban Paris coughing, feverish and having trouble breathing. It was Dec. 27.

title: A ‘Breakdown of Trust’: Pandemic Corrodes Church-State Ties in Russia
first_paragraph: A physics student at Moscow State University, Dmitri Pelipenko turned away from science in 2018 to devote himself to God, enrolling as a novice monk at Holy Trinity-St. Sergius Lavra, the spiritual center of the Russian Orthodox Church.

title: Irish Return an Old Favor, Helping Native Americans Battling the Virus
first_paragraph: More than 170 years ago, the Choctaw Nation sent $170 to starving Irish families during the potato famine. A sculpture in County Cork commemorates the generosity of the tribe, itself poor. In recent decades, ties between Ireland and the Choctaws have grown.

title: Leading Philippine Broadcaster, Target of Duterte’s Ire, Forced Off the Air
first_paragraph: A leading media network in the Philippines was forced off the air on Tuesday, making it the first major broadcaster to have met such a fate during the administration of President Rodrigo Duterte, which is cracking down on news outlets that have been critical of his leadership.

title: Taiwan Says ‘Play Ball!’ (With Cardboard Fans and Robot Drummers)
first_paragraph: On a balmy Saturday evening inside one of Taiwan’s largest baseball stadiums, the floodlights flickered to life and the players took their positions.

title: World Leaders Join to Pledge $8 Billion for Vaccine as U.S. Goes It Alone
first_paragraph: Prime ministers, a king, a prince and Madonna all chipped in to an $8 billion pot to fund a coronavirus vaccine.

title: Hope and Worry Mingle as Countries Relax Coronavirus Lockdowns
first_paragraph: Wearing a Plexiglas visor, large white mask and blue rubber gloves, Catia Gabrielli looked ready for whatever could come her way on Monday as Italy tentatively loosened some of its strictest lockdown provisions against the coronavirus.

title: As Virus Deaths Jump, Boris Johnson’s Press Relations Turn Testy
first_paragraph: When Prime Minister Boris Johnson faced journalists last week for the first time since recovering from the coronavirus, he took his leadoff question from a member of the public, Michelle from Cornwall, who asked him about the dangers of infected tourists coming to her seaside region after the lockdown is lifted.

title: As World Comes to Halt Amid Pandemic, So Do Migrants
first_paragraph: A migrant shelter in southern Mexico called La 72 has for years been a popular way station for those traveling from Central America to the United States. Last year it received a record number of visitors, sometimes sheltering more than 2,000 a month.

title: Coronavirus Survivors Want Answers, and China Is Silencing Them
first_paragraph: The text messages to the Chinese activist streamed in from ordinary Wuhan residents, making the same extraordinary request: Help me sue the Chinese government. One said his mother had died from the coronavirus after being turned away from multiple hospitals. Another said her father-in-law had died in quarantine.

title: In Sydney, the Magic Hour Means Noise. It’s Heavenly to Hear.
first_paragraph: At night, the crickets make my street sound like the wilderness. In the morning, I hear the birds chirping at top volume from sun up until deep into what used to be rush hour.

title: Italians Find Promise of Antibodies Remains Elusive, for Now
first_paragraph: Cooped up, stir crazy and desperate for their lives back, many Europeans and Americans have seized on antibodies and their promise of potential immunity to the coronavirus as the golden ticket to reopen societies and economies.

title: Beirut’s Nightlife Survived Civil War. Can It Withstand Pandemic?
first_paragraph: When the disruptive threat of the coronavirus first came for Beirut, I was, appropriately enough, in a local bar.

title: Global Backlash Builds Against China Over Coronavirus
first_paragraph: Australia has called for an inquiry into the origin of the virus. Germany and Britain are hesitating anew about inviting in the Chinese tech giant Huawei. President Trump has blamed China for the contagion and is seeking to punish it. Some governments want to sue Beijing for damages and reparations.

title: The Covid-19 Riddle: Why Does the Virus Wallop Some Places and Spare Others?
first_paragraph: The coronavirus has killed so many people in Iran that the country has resorted to mass burials, but in neighboring Iraq, the body count is fewer than 100.

title: As Putin Dallies, Russia’s Small Businesses Are Withering Away
first_paragraph: Two weeks into the coronavirus lockdown, Aleksandr B. Zatulivetrov, a Russian businessman, had had enough.

title: No More Jenga, No More ‘Amen’ as Cities Learn to Live With Coronavirus
first_paragraph: Worshipers at one of Seoul’s largest Catholic churches must refrain from singing hymns or saying “amen” for fear of spreading saliva. Priests sanitize their hands during communion. Holy water has been removed from the chapel.

title: Filmmaker Who Mocked Egypt’s President Dies in Prison
first_paragraph: An Egyptian filmmaker imprisoned over a music video that mocked President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi died at a maximum-security facility on Friday after two years in detention without trial, his lawyer said.

title: Two Medical Systems, Two Pandemic Responses
first_paragraph: After lamenting in a recent Canada Letter about my inability to find an expert who could offer an informed comparison of how the medical systems in Canada and the United States were responding to the coronavirus pandemic, I soon heard from Prof. Peter Berman.

title: Kim Jong-un Resurfaces, State Media Says, After Weeks of Health Rumors
first_paragraph: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, resurfaced in public view on Friday, the North’s state news media reported Saturday, controverting three weeks of rumors and unconfirmed news reports that he was in grave danger after undergoing heart surgery.

title: U.K. Virus Tests Surpass Target, but Britain’s Deaths May Overtake Italy’s
first_paragraph: For Britons looking to judge their government’s desperate response to the coronavirus pandemic, the verdict has increasingly come down to two numbers: 100,000, the number of tests that officials promised to conduct every day by the end of April; and 27,510, the latest death toll.

title: In a City Frozen in Fear, Time Freezes, Too
first_paragraph: The first thing that disappeared was the annoying sound of a power drill up the street, from a house under construction.

title: In Odd Turn With Israel, Gazans Get Economic Adrenaline Shot from Virus
first_paragraph: Ziad Qassem’s 25 years as a tailor seemed worthless in the cruel economy of the blockaded Gaza Strip: Unemployed for eight months, piling up debt, he sat idle in his apartment, worried how he would provide for his wife and five children.

title: Bolsonaro Fights for Survival, Turning to Empowered Military Elders
first_paragraph: Jair Bolsonaro ascended to Brazil’s presidency with a sweeping set of promises, like cutting out the rot of corruption, firing up the economy and doing away with the country’s notorious pork-barrel politics.

title: Blood Samples, Vital for Antibody Tests, Sold at Exorbitant Rates
first_paragraph: After 10 terrible days of chills, nausea, a fever of 103 and a headache of such intensity that her nose bled, Aleacia Jenkins knew she had been stricken with the coronavirus even before she tested positive.

title: Tanzanian Cartoonist Has a Stick for Every Powerful Eye
first_paragraph: In a quiet office on the third floor of a building in Nairobi’s central business district, the cartoonist known by his pen name, Gado, was sketching a satire about the coronavirus.

title: ‘Hospital Needs to Be Quarantined,’ but Works On in Country at War
first_paragraph: Even when their city was repeatedly overrun by the Taliban and fighting reached their doorsteps, the doctors and nurses in the northern Afghan city of Kunduz kept working. They dressed wounds and saved lives at the main government hospital even as a nearby trauma center was bombed, killing more than 40 people.

title: Racing Against the Virus From Inside Australia’s Healthcare System
first_paragraph: When my director cut short his camping holiday on Australia Day, to come back to the emergency department at the Melbourne hospital where I work as an emergency physician, I thought he was unnecessarily sacrificing his life for the sake of his work. Covid-19 was still mainly confined to China. Italy was not yet in crisis and New York wasn’t even on our radar. But in hindsight, his return was prudent.

title: Hundreds of Rohingya Refugees Stuck at Sea With ‘Zero Hope’
first_paragraph: Somewhere in turquoise waters, perhaps where the Bay of Bengal meets the Andaman Sea, wooden boats filled with Rohingya refugees are listing, adrift now for more than 10 weeks.

title: Companies Sell the Blood of Recovered Coronavirus Patients for Exorbitant Prices
first_paragraph: Some biotech companies are cashing in on the race to produce coronavirus antibody tests, taking blood samples from people who have been infected and selling them at exorbitant prices.

title: In a Victory for Women in Sudan, Female Genital Mutilation Is Outlawed
first_paragraph: Sudan’s new government has outlawed the practice of female genital mutilation, a move hailed as a major victory by women’s rights campaigners in a country where the often dangerous practice is widespread.

title: As Workers Fall Ill, U.S. Presses Mexico to Keep American-Owned Plants Open
first_paragraph: The Trump administration and major U.S. manufacturers have successfully pressured Mexico to keep factories that supply the United States operating during the coronavirus pandemic, even as outbreaks erupt and waves of cases and deaths sweep the companies.

title: Top E.U. Diplomat Says Disinformation Report Was Not Watered Down for China
first_paragraph: Facing pointed criticism from lawmakers on Thursday, the European Union’s top diplomat denied that Chinese officials had pressured his team to soften language in a recent report on disinformation about the coronavirus pandemic.

title: The Best Movies and TV Shows New on Netflix Canada in May
first_paragraph: Every month, Netflix Canada adds a new batch of TV shows and movies to its library. Here are the titles we think are most interesting for May, broken down by release date. Netflix occasionally changes schedules without giving notice.

title: Putin, Russia’s Man of Action, Is Passive, Even Bored, in the Coronavirus Era
first_paragraph: This was supposed to be a moment of triumph for President Vladimir V. Putin, a celebration of his grand successes in restoring the Russian state to a place of pride in the world and consolidating his grip on power, all topped off by a glorious military parade in Red Square on May 9, the 75th anniversary of the Red Army’s victory over Nazi Germany.

title: Millions Had Risen Out of Poverty. Coronavirus Is Pulling Them Back.
first_paragraph: She was just 12 when she dropped out of school and began clocking in for endless shifts at one of the garment factories springing up in Bangladesh, hoping to pull her family out of poverty.

title: Highways of Peru Swell With Families Fleeing Virus
first_paragraph: The bus terminals in Lima are so crowded with people waiting to escape to the countryside that families are sleeping outside, side by side.

title: As Fighting Surges, Yemen Is Hit With 1st Cluster of Covid-19 Infections
first_paragraph: The first confirmed expansion of the coronavirus in Yemen was reported on Wednesday, prompting renewed calls from aid groups and the United Nations for a humanitarian cease-fire to help combat the infection at a time when the country is mired in increased fighting, widespread hunger and a major cholera outbreak.

title: ‘This Isn’t the Time for Caviar’: A Chef Finds New Flavors in a Pandemic
first_paragraph: When the coronavirus struck, desperate chefs in Bangkok’s fine-dining scene began offering sea urchin on toast and Wagyu katsu sandwiches for delivery since eating in was banned.

title: Pandemic Shakes France’s Faith in a Cornerstone: Strong Central Government
first_paragraph: A couple of baguettes tucked under her arm, Maha Rambousek fiddled with a face mask that kept sliding off her nose. After a local decree made masks mandatory in public, she had quickly stitched it together, but was left confused when the policy was overturned two days later by the central government.

title: China Mounts Aggressive Defense to Calls for Coronavirus Compensation
first_paragraph: China is pushing back against the growing chorus of voices around the world calling for the country to pay compensation for the damage caused by the coronavirus pandemic, which originated in the Chinese city of Wuhan.

title: Greece Has ‘Defied the Odds’ in the Pandemic
first_paragraph: For years, Greece has been seen as one of the European Union’s most troubled members, weighed down by a financial crisis, corruption and political instability. But in the coronavirus pandemic, the country has emerged as a welcome surprise: its outbreak appears to be far more limited than what was expected.

title: War Within War: As Saudi Prince Edges Away from Yemen, His Allies Feud
first_paragraph: After five years of war, the Saudi crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, appeared to be inching away from his ruinous campaign in Yemen in recent weeks, seizing on the coronavirus pandemic to declare a unilateral cease-fire that, although ineffective, at least signaled that the prince finally agreed with critics who insisted the fight was unwinnable.

title: Where There’s a Will in England, There’s a Way
first_paragraph: On a Ping-Pong table in her North London garden lay Atalanta Georgopoulos’s last will and testament. She signed, and then backed a safe distance away. Up to the table strode her neighbor and his house cleaner, witnesses to the will, each with their own pens, the three of them trying not to make the completion of her will the very act that also kills her.

title: ‘Life Has to Go On’: How Sweden Has Faced the Virus Without a Lockdown
first_paragraph: She stood leaning on her cane, briefly resting among dozens of bubbly young Swedes out enjoying one of the first sunny spring days of the year.

title: ‘I Could Be One of Them’: Belgians Help Migrants Amid Coronavirus
first_paragraph: When Belgium went into lockdown in mid-March because of the coronavirus pandemic, the authorities emptied half of the country’s migrant detention centers to help prevent the spread of the virus, leaving hundreds of people without a home.

title: Spain’s Villages Wage a Lonely Fight Against the Coronavirus
first_paragraph: The deafening rumble rose from the depths of the countryside, a welcome yet unnerving sign of life in a corner of northeastern Spain, where villages perched on craggy hills overlook vineyards and fields of olive and almond trees.

title: Coronavirus Diplomacy: How China’s Red Cross Serves the Communist Party
first_paragraph: Donations flooded in to fight the virus devastating the city of Wuhan, and the ruling Communist Party directed them to a group it could trust: the Chinese Red Cross.

title: Unified in Coronavirus Lockdown, India Splinters Over Reopening
first_paragraph: When the Indian government eased coronavirus restrictions last week, allowing many shops to reopen in rural parts of the country, Uday Shankar Sharma, a retail store owner in a small farming village, said he had no intention of complying.

title: Israelis and Palestinians Remember the Slain, Home Alone or Online En Masse
first_paragraph: Civil-defense sirens sounded at 8 p.m. to mark the start of Israel’s solemn Memorial Day observance, but unlike in ordinary years, when the moment is marked by a sudden halt to traffic and an abrupt quieting of nightlife, Monday night’s remembrance of fallen soldiers or victims of terrorism came with most of the country already on lockdown.

title: Boris Johnson, Back on the Job, Urges Caution in Easing Covid-19 Rules
first_paragraph: A pale but vigorous-sounding Prime Minister Boris Johnson returned to work on Monday, declaring that the coronavirus that nearly killed him was like an “unexpected and invisible mugger” the British people had begun to wrestle to the floor but had not yet fully disabled.

title: In Race for a Coronavirus Vaccine, an Oxford Group Leaps Ahead
first_paragraph: In the worldwide race for a vaccine to stop the coronavirus, the laboratory sprinting fastest is at Oxford University.

title: ‘Afraid to Be a Nurse’: Health Workers Under Attack
first_paragraph: The senior nurse went on national television to make a plea on behalf of her fellow health care workers: Please stop assaulting us.

title: Jakarta’s Trash Mountain: ‘When People Are Desperate for Jobs, They Come Here’
first_paragraph: Even in the pouring rain, in the middle of the night, they are out scavenging, wearing headlamps to scan a mountain of rotting garbage more than 15 stories high.

title: To Pressure Iran, Pompeo Turns to the Deal Trump Renounced
first_paragraph: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is preparing a legal argument that the United States remains a participant in the Iran nuclear accord that President Trump has renounced, part of an intricate strategy to pressure the United Nations Security Council to extend an arms embargo on Tehran or see far more stringent sanctions reimposed on the country.

title: As Coronavirus Strikes Prisons, Hundreds of Thousands Are Released
first_paragraph: Prisons across the world have become powerful breeding grounds for the coronavirus, prompting governments to release hundreds of thousands of inmates in a mad scramble to curb the spread of the contagion behind bars.

title: Comic Insults Aside, Mayors Act as Sentinels in Italy’s Coronavirus Tragedy
first_paragraph: In a sort of coronavirus edition of “Undercover Boss,” the mayor of the northern Italian town of Asti this past week surreptitiously inspected supermarkets for the illegal sale of inessential products.

title: Kashmir, Under Siege and Lockdown, Faces a Mental Health Crisis
first_paragraph: Sara Begum’s suffering began on Aug. 3, when masked policemen barged into her home, badly roughed up her son and whisked him away.

title: U.K. Coronavirus Briefings Offer a More Genteel Spin Than Trump’s
first_paragraph: Each evening at the stroke of 5, a British cabinet minister and two expert advisers walk into a clubby, wood-paneled room at 10 Downing Street and take their places behind three socially distanced lecterns.

title: Kim Jong-un’s Absence and North Korea’s Silence Keep Rumor Mill Churning
first_paragraph: North Korea is still sending letters and gifts to foreign leaders and domestic workers in the name of its leader, Kim Jong-un. Its news media brims, as usual, with panegyrical propaganda extolling Mr. Kim’s leadership. South Korea reiterates that it has detected “nothing unusual” in the North. President Trump has called “incorrect” and “fake” a report that Mr. Kim was “in grave danger” after surgery.

title: ‘A Perfect Storm’ in Brazil as Troubles Multiply for Bolsonaro
first_paragraph: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil was struggling to govern effectively long before the explosive resignation speech of his star cabinet minister, who basically called his soon-to-be former boss a criminal.

title: A Ramadan Like No Other: Images From Around the World
first_paragraph: Sprawling banquets that convened crowds of relatives have shrunk to modest meals for immediate family. Imams who led prayers in packed mosques have been addressing the faithful over Zoom. And stay-at-home orders and social distancing guidelines have sapped the nighttime jubilance of cities with large Muslim populations, from Cairo to Jakarta to Dearborn, Mich.

title: ‘There Are No Viruses Here’: Leader of Belarus Scoffs at Lockdowns
first_paragraph: As he headed off the ice after playing a hockey game in an amateur tournament in late March, the leader of Belarus brushed aside reporters’ anxious questions about the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Boris Johnson Aide Attended Secretive U.K. Coronavirus Panel
first_paragraph: The British government came under heightened pressure to disclose details about a secretive scientific advisory group after a report on Friday that a top political aide to Prime Minister Boris Johnson had taken part in the group’s meetings on the coronavirus pandemic.

title: 12 Rangers Among 17 Killed in Congo Park Ambush
first_paragraph: Twelve rangers were among 17 people killed in Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo, officials said, in one of the worst massacres in the park’s recent history. The park blamed members of a Rwandan rebel group for the attack.

title: Tux, Gown, Masks: Arab Couples Scramble to Marry During a Pandemic
first_paragraph: Carfuls of hooting men careened through the half-empty streets of Cairo, then skidded to a halt on Qasr el Nil, the most famous bridge over the Nile. A newly married couple leapt out, trailed by festive relatives, hoping for a coveted photo at an iconic beauty spot.

title: Economic Freeze Cuts Remittances, a Lifeline for Migrants’ Families
first_paragraph: The money would arrive like clockwork: $300 every couple of weeks, sent by her husband, a day laborer and undocumented immigrant living in Indianapolis.

title: Americans Stranded Abroad Weigh Options; Spain Announces Easing of Restrictions
first_paragraph: Many Americans who had assumed they could stay overseas till the pandemic ebbed now face an unnerving choice: either prepare for the possibility of being infected and treated in foreign hospitals, or risk infection on the way back to the United States.

title: Nova Scotia Mourns In an Uneasy Time
first_paragraph: For Canada and particularly Nova Scotia, it was a terrible week in the midst of an uneasy time. A village that was once best known for a dance hall became a scene of horror and the starting point for the most deadly mass shooting in the country’s history: 22 victims plus the killer.

title: As Ramadan Begins, Muslims (Mostly) Accede to Pandemic Orders
first_paragraph: It was a rare moment in the 1,400-year history of Islam, and another sobering milestone in the march of the coronavirus.

title: Pregnant women in Britain will be offered Covid-19 vaccines.
first_paragraph: Pregnant women in Britain are now eligible to receive a Covid-19 vaccine, British health authorities announced on Friday, citing data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that showed that about 90,000 pregnant women had been vaccinated in the United States without any health issues.

title: A Week of Discouraging, Frightening and Frustrating Pandemic Developments
first_paragraph: I was feeling vaguely guilty this week when heading out to a sports complex in suburban Ottawa for my vaccination. As I write this, only 19 percent of Canadians have shared my experience and just before my vaccine day arrived, tens of thousands of vaccination appointments in Manitoba and Ontario were canceled.

title: The global death toll from Covid-19 is nearing 3 million.
first_paragraph: nearly three million people have died from the virus since the first cases surfaced more than 14 months ago and upended life for people across the globe.

title: Vaccine hesitancy runs high in some African countries, in some cases leaving unused doses to expire.
first_paragraph: With growing community transmission and high average mortality rates from the coronavirus in Malawi, there was widespread concern among the country’s health care advocates this week when the authorities announced that they would throw away 16,000 vaccine doses that had expired.

title: In Italy, younger people are accused of jumping the line to get the vaccine.
first_paragraph: Last year, in the worst days of the pandemic in Italy, old people died in record numbers. Now, as the country rolls out its vaccination campaign, national authorities have uncovered a rash of line-cutting by younger people and accused them of depriving the elderly and the most vulnerable of their shots.

title: Overwhelmed by the virus, Paraguay considers ditching Taiwan for China — and its vaccines.
