first_paragraph: A rash of provocative headlines this week flooded social media platforms, touting a tantalizing notion: Mouthwash, they read, can “kill” the coronavirus “within 30 seconds,” according to the findings of a new study that has not yet been published in a peer-reviewed scientific journal.

title: The F.D.A. Wanted to Ban Some Hair Straighteners. It Never Happened.
first_paragraph: It’s been more than a decade since a popular hair treatment called Brazilian Blowout appeared in salons, promising months of straight hair after a single application. But soon users were complaining that the product emitted noxious fumes that stung their eyes, brought on headaches, nosebleeds and nausea, and made it hard to breathe.

title: The Pandemic’s Real Toll? 300,000 Deaths, and It’s Not Just From the Coronavirus
first_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic caused nearly 300,000 deaths in the United States through early October, federal researchers said on Tuesday.

title: How the F.D.A. Stood Up to the President
first_paragraph: On Sept. 23, Dr. Stephen M. Hahn left a virtual meeting of the White House’s coronavirus task force to take a call from the president’s chief of staff, Mark Meadows.

title: Trump’s Antibody ‘Cure’ Will Be in Short Supply
first_paragraph: Nearly two weeks ago, President Trump told Americans that they would soon be getting an antibody treatment that he had promoted, without evidence, as a “cure” for the coronavirus. This weekend, as the country braced for another major wave of coronavirus infections, Mr. Trump’s health secretary promised such therapies were just around the corner.

title: Some Signs of Recovery From Severe Covid Lung Damage
first_paragraph: When Annie Coissieux tried to stand up for the first time after weeks in the hospital battling Covid-19, she couldn’t get on her feet.

title: A Rapid Test Offers Hope for Community Screening
first_paragraph: A $5 rapid test for the coronavirus may be nearly as effective as the slower, more complex polymerase chain reaction test for identifying people who may spread the coronavirus, a novel experiment has found.

title: Eli Lilly’s Antibody Trial Is Paused Over Potential Safety Concern
first_paragraph: A government-sponsored clinical trial that is testing an antibody treatment for Covid-19 developed by the drugmaker Eli Lilly has been paused because of a “potential safety concern,” according to emails that government officials sent on Tuesday to researchers at testing sites. The company confirmed the pause.

title: She Hunts Viral Rumors About Real Viruses
first_paragraph: In late September, Heidi Larson, an anthropologist and the founder of the Vaccine Confidence Project in London, sat on a Zoom call with the project team for Verified, a United Nations-led group that is working to combat a rising tide of misinformation about potential vaccines for Covid-19.

title: First, a Vaccine Approval. Then ‘Chaos and Confusion.’
first_paragraph: The United States may be within months of a profound turning point in the country’s fight against the coronavirus: the first working vaccine.

title: ‘I Feel Like I Have Dementia’: Brain Fog Plagues Covid Survivors
first_paragraph: After contracting the coronavirus in March, Michael Reagan lost all memory of his 12-day vacation in Paris, even though the trip was just a few weeks earlier.

title: Nevada Revokes Halt on Rapid Antigen Testing in Nursing Homes
first_paragraph: Under pressure from the federal government, Nevada health officials on Friday rescinded a statewide order directing nursing homes to halt the use of two government-issued rapid coronavirus tests that the state had deemed to be inaccurate.

title: Extra Pounds May Raise Risk of Severe Covid-19
first_paragraph: Obese Americans are more likely to become dangerously ill if they are infected with the new coronavirus. Now public health officials are warning that a much broader segment of the population also may be at risk: even moderately excess weight may increase the odds of severe disease.

title: Can Trump Really Speed Approval of Covid Treatments?
first_paragraph: In a five-minute video posted to his Twitter account on Wednesday, President Trump stood in front of the White House and offered a lavish endorsement for a treatment he had received while hospitalized at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center.

title: White House Blocked C.D.C. From Requiring Masks on Public Transportation
first_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention drafted a sweeping order last month requiring all passengers and employees to wear masks on all forms of public and commercial transportation in the United States, but it was blocked by the White House, according to two federal health officials.

title: Trump’s Testimonial Is a Double-Edged Sword for Regeneron
first_paragraph: When President Trump promoted an experimental drug as a “cure” for Covid-19 in a video on Wednesday, it might have seemed that he was at it again: touting a questionable fix for a deadly pandemic, not unlike his earlier enthusiasm for the malaria drug hydroxychloroquine or even, at one point, disinfectant.

title: Federal Official Threatens Nevada for Halting Rapid Tests in Nursing Homes
first_paragraph: The leader of the nation’s coronavirus testing efforts condemned Nevada’s health department on Friday for ordering nursing homes to discontinue two brands of government-issued rapid coronavirus tests that the state had found to be inaccurate.

title: Trump Could Be Back in Public by Saturday. Experts Worry It’s Too Soon.
first_paragraph: The White House physician, Dr. Sean P. Conley, predicted in a memo released Thursday that President Trump could safely “return to public engagements” on Saturday, based on the date on which he tested positive for the coronavirus and his response to treatments.

title: Trump’s Covid Treatments Were Tested in Cells Derived From Fetal Tissue
first_paragraph: When the Trump administration suspended federal funding in 2019 for most new scientific research projects involving fetal tissue derived from abortions, officials argued that whatever the scientific benefits, there was a pressing moral imperative to find alternative research methods.

title: Workers With Health Insurance Face Rising Out-of-Pocket Costs
first_paragraph: The high cost of health care is persisting during the pandemic, even for people lucky enough to still have job-based insurance.

title: Regeneron Asks F.D.A. for Emergency Approval for Drug That Trump Claimed Cured Him
first_paragraph: The drugmaker Regeneron said on Wednesday evening that it had submitted an application to the Food and Drug Administration for emergency approval of the experimental antibody cocktail that President Trump had praised just hours earlier without evidence as a “cure” for the coronavirus.

title: In a First, New England Journal of Medicine Joins Never-Trumpers
first_paragraph: Throughout its 208-year history, The New England Journal of Medicine has remained staunchly nonpartisan. The world’s most prestigious medical journal has never supported or condemned a political candidate.

title: Nevada Halts Use of Rapid Coronavirus Tests in Nursing Homes, Citing Inaccuracies
first_paragraph: Nevada has ordered its nursing facilities to immediately suspend the use of two rapid tests for the coronavirus, manufactured by companies Quidel and Becton, Dickinson and Company, after the tests’ performance was found to be lacking, according to a directive issued on Friday by the state’s department of health.

title: ‘I Won’t Be Used as a Guinea Pig for White People’
first_paragraph: The recruiters strode to the front of the room, wearing neon-yellow vests and resolute expressions. But to the handful of tenants overwhelmed by unemployment and gang violence in Northview Heights, the pitch verged on the ludicrous.

title: Why Doctors Aren’t So Sure Trump Is Feeling Better From Covid-19
first_paragraph: Standing on the steps of Walter Reed National Military Medical Center on Monday, with a phalanx of white-coated doctors behind him, the White House physician, Dr. Sean P. Conley, ticked off President Trump’s encouraging vital signs: no fever, only slightly elevated blood pressure and a blood oxygen level in the healthy range.

title: In Reversal, White House Approves Stricter Guidelines for Vaccine Makers
first_paragraph: a step that had been held up for two weeks by top White House officials. The guidelines make it highly unlikely that a vaccine could be authorized by Election Day.

title: The White House Bet on Abbott’s Rapid Tests. It Didn’t Work Out.
first_paragraph: After months of crowded events and often maskless encounters, a growing number of top government officials, including President Trump, and their close contacts have tested positive for the coronavirus.

title: She’s 13, and the Source of a Family’s Covid-19 Outbreak
first_paragraph: Adolescents who contract Covid-19 usually do not get as sick as adults and often experience few if any symptoms, but they can spread the novel coronavirus that causes the disease to others.

title: White House Is Not Tracing Contacts for ‘Super-Spreader’ Rose Garden Event
first_paragraph: Despite almost daily disclosures of new coronavirus infections among President Trump’s close associates, the White House is making little effort to investigate the scope and source of its outbreak.

title: The Coronavirus May Be Adrift in Indoor Air, C.D.C. Acknowledges
first_paragraph: Two weeks after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention took down a statement about airborne transmission of the coronavirus, the agency on Monday replaced it with language citing new evidence that the virus can spread beyond six feet indoors.

title: Carter Williams, Who Unshackled Nursing Home Residents, Dies at 97
first_paragraph: In journal articles, conferences, congressional hearings and meetings with regulators, Carter Catlett Williams illuminated the miseries of nursing home residents with the sympathetic and descriptive powers of a novelist.

title: Some Insurers End Pandemic Waivers of Fees and Deductibles for Telehealth
first_paragraph: Some people will have to start paying more out of their own pockets for telemedicine appointments, if their virtual visits with doctors are unrelated to Covid-19 and are needed to monitor conditions like diabetes or to check out sudden knee pain.

title: Trump’s Travail: A Virus That Thrives Indoors
first_paragraph: On Saturday, President Trump met with Judge Amy Coney Barrett, the nominee to the Supreme Court, and others in the Oval Office. On Tuesday, he debated former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. in an indoor hall, neither with a mask, talking at high volume and often without pause.

title: President Trump Received Experimental Antibody Treatment
first_paragraph: President Trump has received a dose of an experimental antibody cocktail being developed by the drug maker Regeneron, in addition to several other drugs, including zinc, vitamin D and the generic version of the heartburn treatment Pepcid, according to a letter from his doctor that was released by the White House Friday afternoon.

title: Trump Has the Coronavirus. What Risks Does He Face?
first_paragraph: President Trump’s announcement on Friday that he had tested positive for the coronavirus has raised many questions about what the infection could mean for the health of America’s top leader.

title: Companies Ditch Plans for Rapid Coronavirus Spit Tests at Home
first_paragraph: For months, public health experts have been eagerly watching the companies developing spit tests for the coronavirus that could be used at home, producing results in a matter of minutes.

title: Timothy Ray Brown, First Patient Cured of H.I.V., Dies at 54
first_paragraph: Timothy Ray Brown, the first person to be cured of H.I.V., through an experimental surgical procedure that offered hope though not a realistic treatment for most people with the virus, died on Tuesday at his home in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 54.

title: White House Blocked C.D.C. Order to Keep Cruise Ships Docked
first_paragraph: The White House has blocked a new order from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to keep cruise ships docked until mid-February, a step that would have displeased the politically powerful tourism industry in the crucial swing state of Florida.

title: Huge Study of Coronavirus Cases in India Offers Some Surprises to Scientists
first_paragraph: With 1.3 billion people jostling for space, India has always been a hospitable environment for infectious diseases of every kind. And the coronavirus has proved to be no exception: The country now has more than six million cases, second only to the United States.

title: ‘Testing Hell’: Gift of Devices to Nursing Homes Brings New Problems
first_paragraph: After months of enduring a dearth of protective medical gear and staggering death tolls from the coronavirus pandemic, nursing home operators and employees across the United States experienced something close to elation as rapid-result test machines paid for by the federal government began arriving last month at 14,000 residential facilities that serve the elderly.

title: Trump Allies Say the Virus Has Almost Run Its Course. ‘Nonsense,’ Experts Say.
first_paragraph: In the last week, leading epidemiologists from respected institutions have, through different methods, reached the same conclusion: About 85 to 90 percent of the American population is still susceptible to SARS-CoV-2, the virus causing the current pandemic.

title: ‘The Drug Became His Friend’: Pandemic Drives Hike in Opioid Deaths
first_paragraph: On the first Friday in June, Jefrey Cameron, 29, left his home around midnight to buy heroin. He had been struggling with addiction for seven years but had seemingly turned a corner, holding down a job that he loved at Basil’s Pizzeria, driving his teenage sister to the mall to go shopping and sharing a home with his grandmother. But then the coronavirus pandemic hit.

title: Trump Announces Plan to Ship 150 Million Rapid Coronavirus Tests
first_paragraph: President Trump at the White House on Monday announced a plan to distribute 150 million rapid coronavirus tests purchased by the federal government to states, tribes and other jurisdictions in the coming months.

title: The Coronavirus Mostly Spares Younger Children. Teens Aren’t So Lucky.
first_paragraph: Teenagers are about twice as likely to become infected with the coronavirus as younger children, according to an analysis released Monday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: A Theory About Conspiracy Theories
first_paragraph: More than 1 in 3 Americans believe that the Chinese government engineered the coronavirus as a weapon, and another third are convinced that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has exaggerated the threat of Covid-19 to undermine President Trump.

title: Some Workers Face Looming Cutoffs in Health Insurance
first_paragraph: Jeremy Fritz stopped working as an assistant manager for a fitness center in Carlsbad, Calif., during the pandemic lockdown in the spring when gyms were first closed.

title: How to Keep the Coronavirus at Bay Indoors
first_paragraph: As the autumn chill ushers people back into homes, classrooms and offices, the coronavirus may resurge even in states that have so far restrained its spread.

title: In Isolating Times, Can Robo-Pets Provide Comfort?
first_paragraph: When Linda Spangler asked her mother, in a video chat, what she would like as gift for her 92nd birthday, the response came promptly.

title: How Do Children Fight Off the Coronavirus?
first_paragraph: Why the coronavirus affects children much less severely than adults has become an enduring mystery of the pandemic. The vast majority of children do not get sick; when they do, they usually recover.

title: Virus Cases Surged in Young Adults. The Elderly Were Hit Next.
first_paragraph: As millennials mingled in bars and restaurants over the summer, and students returned to college campuses, coronavirus infections surged among young adults.

title: Novavax Enters Final Stage of Coronavirus Vaccine Trials
first_paragraph: The vaccine maker Novavax said Thursday that it would begin the final stages of testing its coronavirus vaccine in the United Kingdom and that another large trial was scheduled to begin next month in the United States.

title: Losing Your Hair Can Be Another Consequence of the Pandemic
first_paragraph: Annrene Rowe was getting ready to celebrate her 10th wedding anniversary this summer when she noticed a bald spot on her scalp. In the following days, her thick shoulder-length hair started falling out in clumps, bunching up in the shower drain.

title: Johnson & Johnson’s Vaccine Advances, Sparking Optimism in Race
first_paragraph: The feverish race for a coronavirus vaccine got an infusion of energy on Wednesday as Johnson & Johnson announced that it has begun the final stage of its clinical trials, the fourth company to do so in the United States as the country hits a grim milestone of 200,000 deaths from the pandemic.

title: F.D.A. to Release Stricter Guidelines for Emergency Vaccine Authorization
first_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration plans to soon issue stricter guidelines for the emergency authorization of any new coronavirus vaccine, adding a new layer of caution to the vetting process even as President Trump continues to contradict his own scientific experts and promise that a vaccine will be available as early as next month.

title: ‘I Had Heart Surgery in the Middle of a Coronavirus Hot Spot’
first_paragraph: I really did not want to have heart surgery. Who wants their chest sliced open and carved like a turkey in the middle of a pandemic hot zone? But that’s what I did in August.

title: Advice on Airborne Virus Transmission Vanishes From C.D.C. Website
first_paragraph: Just days after publishing significant new guidance on airborne transmission of the coronavirus, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Monday withdrew the advice, saying only that it had been “posted in error” on the agency’s website.

title: Top U.S. Health Officials Tiptoe Around Trump’s Vaccine Timeline
first_paragraph: As the nation’s coronavirus death toll neared 200,000, top administration health officials on Sunday delicately sidestepped President Trump’s ambitious declaration last week that a coronavirus vaccine would be available for every American by April.

title: AstraZeneca, Under Fire for Vaccine Safety, Releases Trial Blueprints
first_paragraph: AstraZeneca revealed details of its large coronavirus vaccine trials on Saturday, the third in a wave of rare disclosures by drug companies under pressure to be more transparent about how they are testing products that are the world’s best hope for ending the pandemic.

title: In ‘Power Grab,’ Health Secretary Azar Asserts Authority Over F.D.A.
first_paragraph: In a stunning declaration of authority, Alex M. Azar II, the secretary of health and human services, this week barred the nation’s health agencies, including the Food and Drug Administration, from signing any new rules regarding the nation’s foods, medicines, medical devices and other products, including vaccines.

title: C.D.C. Reverses Testing Guidelines for People Without Covid-19 Symptoms
first_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Friday reversed a controversial recommendation suggesting people who have had close contact with a person infected with the coronavirus do not need to get tested if they have no symptoms.

title: ‘This Does Not Look Good for Children’: Fires Pose Risk to Young Lungs
first_paragraph: Ian MacDonald, a 14-year-old in Portland, Ore., got a treat from his parents the other day. He was allowed to go outside.

title: Many Hospitals Charge More Than Twice What Medicare Pays for the Same Care
first_paragraph: Hospitals across the country are charging private insurance companies 2.5 times what they get from Medicare for the same care, according to a new RAND Corporation study of hospital prices released on Friday.

title: Coronavirus May Increase Premature Births, Studies Suggest
first_paragraph: Pregnant women who are infected with the coronavirus and hospitalized are at risk for developing serious complications, and may face an elevated risk for delivering their babies prematurely, according to new studies from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. They may also be at greater risk of losing the pregnancy or having a stillbirth.

title: C.D.C. Testing Guidance Was Published Against Scientists’ Objections
first_paragraph: A heavily criticized recommendation from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention last month about who should be tested for the coronavirus was not written by C.D.C. scientists and was posted to the agency’s website despite their serious objections, according to several people familiar with the matter as well as internal documents obtained by The New York Times.

title: Moderna and Pfizer Reveal Secret Blueprints for Coronavirus Vaccine Trials
first_paragraph: Two drug companies that are leading the race to develop coronavirus vaccines bowed to public pressure on Thursday, abandoning their traditional secrecy and releasing comprehensive road maps of how they are evaluating their vaccines.

title: ‘Warp Speed’ Officials Debut Plan for Distributing Free Vaccines
first_paragraph: Federal officials outlined details Wednesday of their preparations to administer a future coronavirus vaccine to Americans, saying they would begin distribution within 24 hours of any approval or emergency authorization, and that their goal was that no American “has to pay a single dime” out of their own pocket.

title: An Experimental Drug Protects Covid-19 Patients, Eli Lilly Claims
first_paragraph: A single infusion of an experimental drug markedly reduced levels of the coronavirus in newly infected patients and lowered the chances that they would need hospitalization, the drug’s maker announced on Wednesday.

title: Gates Offers Grim Global Health Report, and Some Optimism
first_paragraph: On Monday, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation released the fourth of its annual Goalkeeper reports, which track the slow but steady progress the world has made toward more than a dozen health-related goals set forth by the United Nations in 2015.

title: Fever Checks Are No Safeguard Against Covid-19
first_paragraph: In recent weeks, a new cadre of gatekeepers armed with thermometer guns has appeared at the entrances of hospitals, office buildings and manufacturing plants to screen out feverish individuals who may carry the coronavirus.

title: AstraZeneca Partly Resumes Coronavirus Vaccine Trial After Halting It for Safety
first_paragraph: The pharmaceutical company AstraZeneca said Saturday that it had resumed its coronavirus vaccine trial in Britain after suspending it six days ago over potential safety issues but that its trials in the United States and other countries were still on hold.

title: Now It’s Not Safe at Home Either. Wildfires Bring Ashen Air Into the House.
first_paragraph: The new thing we do here when we get up in the morning, even before the tooth brushing and the coffee making, is to look at the sky. Then we look at the internet to see if our eyes deceive.

title: A University Had a Great Coronavirus Plan, but Students Partied On
first_paragraph: At the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, more than 40,000 students take tests twice a week for the coronavirus. They cannot enter campus buildings unless an app vouches that their test has come back negative. Everyone has to wear masks.

title: How the Coronavirus Attacks the Brain
first_paragraph: The coronavirus targets the lungs foremost, but also the kidneys, liver and blood vessels. Still, about half of patients report neurological symptoms, including headaches, confusion and delirium, suggesting the virus may also attack the brain.

title: AstraZeneca Pauses Vaccine Trial for Safety Review
first_paragraph: The pharmaceutical company AstraZeneca halted large, late-stage global trials of its coronavirus vaccine on Tuesday because of a serious suspected adverse reaction in a participant, the company said. It is not yet known whether the reaction was directly caused by the company’s vaccine or was coincidental.

title: 9 Drug Companies Pledge to ‘Stand With Science’ on Coronavirus Vaccines
first_paragraph: Nine pharmaceutical companies issued a joint pledge on Tuesday that they would “stand with science” and not put forward a vaccine until it had been thoroughly vetted for safety and efficacy.

title: A New Theory Asks: Could a Mask Be a Crude ‘Vaccine’?
first_paragraph: As the world awaits the arrival of a safe and effective coronavirus vaccine, a team of researchers has come forward with a provocative new theory: that masks might help to crudely immunize some people against the virus.

title: For Long-Haulers, Covid-19 Takes a Toll on Mind as Well as Body
first_paragraph: Forty hours after treating her first coronavirus patient, on March 30, Angela Aston came home to her family with a cough. “Gosh, your throat is scratchy,” her husband told her. Right away she knew she had likely been infected with Covid-19. As a nurse practitioner, Ms. Aston, 50, was confident she knew how to handle her symptoms, and disappeared to her bedroom to quarantine and rest.

title: Daily Coronavirus Testing at Home? Many Experts Are Skeptical
first_paragraph: Over the past few weeks, a Harvard scientist has made headlines for a bold idea to curb the spread of the coronavirus: rolling out so-called antigen tests, a decades-old underdog in testing technology, to tens of millions of Americans for near-daily, at-home use.

title: Russians Publish Early Coronavirus Vaccine Results
first_paragraph: On Friday, a team of Russian scientists published the first report on their Covid-19 vaccine, which had been roundly criticized because of President Vladimir Putin’s decision last month to approve it before clinical trials had proved it safe and effective.

title: Trump Administration Will Redirect $62 Million Owed to the W.H.O.
first_paragraph: As the United States withdraws from membership in the World Health Organization, the Trump administration will redirect $62 million still owed for this year’s dues to other health-related causes also under United Nations auspices, State Department officials announced on Wednesday.

title: C.D.C. Tells States How to Prepare for Covid-19 Vaccine by Early November
first_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has notified public health officials in all 50 states and five large cities to prepare to distribute a coronavirus vaccine to health care workers and other high-risk groups as soon as late October or early November.

title: Steroids Can Be Lifesaving for Covid-19 Patients, Scientists Report
first_paragraph: International clinical trials published on Wednesday confirm the hope that cheap, widely available steroid drugs can help seriously ill patients survive Covid-19, the illness caused by the coronavirus.

title: Why the Coronavirus More Often Strikes Children of Color
first_paragraph: One of the notable features of the new coronavirus, evident early in the pandemic, was that it largely spared children. Some become severely ill, but deaths have been few, compared to adults.

title: A Parent’s Toughest Call: In-Person Schooling or Not?
first_paragraph: All summer, as information about how the coronavirus affects children has trickled in, I’ve been updating a balance sheet in my head. Every study I read, every expert I talked to, was filling in columns on this sheet: reasons for and against sending my children back to school come September.

title: In an Era of Face Masks, We’re All a Little More Face Blind
first_paragraph: We’re all getting used to face masks, either wearing them or figuring out who we’re looking at. They can even trip up those of us who are experts in faces.

title: Dermatology Has a Problem With Skin Color
first_paragraph: In the spring, teenagers started showing up at doctors’ offices in droves with angry red and purple blisters on their fingers and toes. The latest unexpected feature of the coronavirus infection fascinated the public, and suddenly photographs of so-called Covid toes were everywhere on social media.

title: Trump Program to Cover Uninsured Covid-19 Patients Falls Short of Promise
first_paragraph: Marilyn Cortez, a retired cafeteria worker in Houston with no health insurance, spent much of July in the hospital with Covid-19. When she finally returned home, she received a $36,000 bill that compounded the stress of her illness.

title: Your Coronavirus Test Is Positive. Maybe It Shouldn’t Be.
first_paragraph: Some of the nation’s leading public health experts are raising a new concern in the endless debate over coronavirus testing in the United States: The standard tests are diagnosing huge numbers of people who may be carrying relatively insignificant amounts of the virus.

title: Two P.R. Experts at F.D.A. Have Been Ousted After Blood Plasma Fiasco
first_paragraph: The head of the Food and Drug Administration ousted its top spokeswoman from her position on Friday in an urgent bid to restore the tarnished credibility of the agency after he made erroneous claims that overstated the benefits of plasma treatments for Covid-19 at a news conference with President Trump.

title: When Retirement Comes Too Early
first_paragraph: Joey Himelfarb estimates that in his 25 years in sales, hawking everything from Hewlett-Packard computers to cars and swimming pools, he has been laid off or downsized at least a half-dozen times.

title: The Psychiatrist Will See You Online Now
first_paragraph: For about two years, Michael Raymos made the drive from Modesto, Calif., to Sacramento and back for therapy, and for the therapist, who could listen to stories of childhood abuse and gently unwind their hold on the present. Those regular office sessions, at a clinic at the University of California, Davis, created a strong bond, and Mr. Raymos came to rely on them to manage symptoms of post-traumatic stress and the emotional weight of a neurodegenerative disorder that struck him in 2012, in the prime of adulthood.

title: Reopened Schools Find Health Risks in Water After Covid-19 Lockdowns
first_paragraph: The new coronavirus is not the only illness that teachers, students, parents and staff will have to worry about as some schools attempt to reopen this fall. Legionella could lurk in the water supplies of school buildings, and some measures to keep people in schools safe from coronavirus may even increase risks from deadly illnesses caused by the bacteria.

title: What if the First Coronavirus Vaccines Aren’t the Best?
first_paragraph: Seven months into the coronavirus crisis, with more than 30 vaccines rapidly advancing through the rigorous stages of clinical trials, a surprising number of research groups are placing bets on some that have not yet been given to a single person.

title: One Meeting in Boston Seeded Tens of Thousands of Infections, Study Finds
first_paragraph: On Feb. 26, 175 executives at the biotech company Biogen gathered at a Boston hotel for the first night of a conference. At the time, the coronavirus seemed a faraway problem, limited mostly to China.

title: Why Does the Coronavirus Hit Men Harder? A New Clue
first_paragraph: The coronavirus may infect anyone, young or old, but older men are up to twice as likely to become severely sick and to die as women of the same age.

title: Your Flu Shot Has Never Been More Important
first_paragraph: Public health officials, fearing that the confluence of Covid-19 and influenza cases could result in a “twindemic” that will further overburden hospitals and testing locations, are urging flu shots for nearly everyone, and the sooner the better.

title: Flu Season Could Make Coronavirus Testing Delays Even Worse
first_paragraph: Come fall, the rise of influenza and other seasonal respiratory infections could exacerbate already staggering delays in coronavirus testing, making it easier for the virus to spread unnoticed, experts said.

title: F.D.A. ‘Grossly Misrepresented’ Blood Plasma Data, Scientists Say
first_paragraph: At a news conference on Sunday announcing the emergency approval of blood plasma for hospitalized Covid-19 patients, President Trump and two of his top health officials cited the same statistic: that the treatment had reduced deaths by 35 percent.

title: First Documented Coronavirus Reinfection Reported in Hong Kong
first_paragraph: A 33-year-old man was infected a second time with the coronavirus more than four months after his first bout, the first documented case of so-called reinfection, researchers in Hong Kong reported Monday.

title: Why Antibody Tests Won’t Help You Much
first_paragraph: Getting an antibody test to see if you had Covid-19 months ago is pointless, according to guidelines issued this week by a major medical society.

title: Trump Administration Says Some Coronavirus Tests Can Bypass F.D.A. Scrutiny
first_paragraph: The Trump administration this week ordered the Food and Drug Administration to allow the use of a certain class of laboratory tests, including some for the coronavirus, without first confirming that they work.

title: For Quick Coronavirus Testing, Israel Turns to a Clever Algorithm
first_paragraph: A team of three Israeli scientists has pioneered a coronavirus testing procedure that they say is faster and more efficient than any now in use, testing samples in pools of as many as 48 people at once.

title: Drug Pitched to Trump for Covid-19 Comes From a Deadly Plant
first_paragraph: A plant extract trumpeted this week as a “cure” for Covid-19 by the leader of a pillow company is untested and potentially dangerous, scientists say.

title: U.S. Mail Delays Slow Delivery of Medicines
first_paragraph: To many people who rely on the mail to deliver their prescriptions, the latest political skirmishing over the U.S. Postal Service doesn’t really matter. They’ve been dealing with delays for weeks, and while some are not urgent, others are more worrisome.

title: New Measures Aim to Boost Vaccine Rates for Flu and Children’s Shots
first_paragraph: The Trump administration has announced measures intended to boost childhood vaccination rates that have sagged during the coronavirus pandemic, putting hundreds of thousands at risk of contracting serious and life-threatening diseases.

title: An ‘Unprecedented’ Effort to Stop the Coronavirus in Nursing Homes
first_paragraph: The coronavirus crept into Heartland Health Care Center, a nursing home in Moline, Ill., on the last day of July, when a member of the nursing staff tested positive.

title: Pediatrics Group Offers ‘Long Overdue’ Apology for Racist Past
first_paragraph: Dr. Roland B. Scott was the first African-American to pass the pediatric board exam, in 1934. He was a faculty member at Howard University, and went on to establish its center for the study of sickle cell disease; he gained national acclaim for his research on the blood disorder.

title: This Trawler’s Haul: Evidence That Antibodies Block the Coronavirus
first_paragraph: A fishing vessel that left Seattle in May returned with an unexpected catch: the first direct evidence in humans that antibodies to the coronavirus can thwart infection.

title: Why Pooled Testing for the Coronavirus Isn’t Working in America
first_paragraph: Earlier this summer, Trump administration officials hailed a new strategy for catching coronavirus infections: pooled testing.

title: Federal Study of Covid Treatments Enters a New Phase
first_paragraph: A large federal study that found an antiviral drug, remdesivir, can hasten the recovery in hospitalized Covid-19 patients, has begun a new phase of investigation.

title: A Novel Way to Combat Covid-19 in Nursing Homes: Strike Teams
first_paragraph: The coronavirus entered Cherry Springs Village quietly, then struck with force. Nearly every staff member and resident of the long-term care facility would become infected.

title: What if ‘Herd Immunity’ Is Closer Than Scientists Thought?
first_paragraph: We’ve known from the beginning how the end will arrive. Eventually, the coronavirus will be unable to find enough susceptible hosts to survive, fading out wherever it briefly emerges.

title: Scientists See Signs of Lasting Immunity to Covid-19, Even After Mild Infections
first_paragraph: To the immune system, not all germs are equally memorable. But our body’s cells seem to be seriously studying up on the coronavirus.

title: Obesity Raises the Risk of Death From Covid-19 Among Men
first_paragraph: The coronavirus has been an unpredictable foe from the start. It triggers silent or barely perceptible infections in some individuals, while in others it sets off a cascade of complications that overwhelm the body and lead to death.

title: Clinical Trials of Coronavirus Drugs Are Taking Longer Than Expected
first_paragraph: As the coronavirus pandemic continues to wreak havoc in the United States and treatments are needed more than ever, clinical trials for some of the most promising experimental drugs are taking longer than expected.

title: Nursing Home Families Yearn to Visit Loved Ones Again
first_paragraph: Three years ago, Cathy Baum helped both her mother and her mother-in-law move into memory care in an assisted living facility in Reston, Va. Because Ms. Baum lived nearby, she could visit four to five days a week and keep a watchful eye on them.

title: Young Adults Report Rising Levels of Anxiety and Depression in Pandemic
first_paragraph: The collateral damage from the pandemic continues: Young adults, as well as Black and Latino people of all ages, describe rising levels of anxiety, depression and even suicidal thoughts, and increased substance abuse, according to findings reported by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Don’t Like What You See on Zoom? Get a Face-Lift and Join the Crowd
first_paragraph: A growing number of people, stuck at home and tired of staring at their own haggard faces on Zoom, are finding a fix: face and eye lifts, chin and tummy tucks and more.

title: In N.Y.C.’s Spring Virus Surge, a Frightening Echo of 1918 Flu
first_paragraph: The 1918 influenza pandemic is the deadliest in modern history, claiming an estimated 50 million lives worldwide, including 675,000 in the United States.

title: On Native American Land, Contact Tracing Is Saving Lives
first_paragraph: The coronavirus is raging through the White Mountain Apache tribe. Spread across a large reservation in eastern Arizona, the Apaches have been infected at more than 10 times the rate of people in the state as a whole.

title: The Nation Wanted to Eat Out Again. Everyone Has Paid the Price.
first_paragraph: Across the United States this summer, restaurants and bars, reeling from mandatory lockdowns and steep financial declines, opened their doors to customers, thousands of whom had been craving deep bowls of farro, frothy margaritas and juicy burgers smothered in glistening onions.

title: 11 Supposedly Fun Things We’ll Never Do the Same Way Again
first_paragraph: Early in the pandemic, Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nation’s top infectious disease expert, said something that grabbed a lot of attention: Handshakes should become a thing of the past.

title: For Doctors of Color, Microaggressions Are All Too Familiar
first_paragraph: When Dr. Onyeka Otugo was doing her training in emergency medicine, in Cleveland and Chicago, she was often mistaken for a janitor or food services worker even after introducing herself as a doctor. She realized early on that her white male counterparts were not experiencing similar mix-ups.

title: C.D.C. Closes Some Offices Over Bacteria Discovery
first_paragraph: The nation’s foremost public health agency is learning that it is not immune to the complex effects of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: New York Is Positioned to Reopen Schools Safely, Health Experts Say
first_paragraph: New York State, the center of the worst coronavirus outbreak in the world four months ago, is now one of the few places in the country that may be able to safely reopen schools, several public health experts said after Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo gave districts permission to do so.

title: Why the Coronavirus Is More Likely to ‘Superspread’ Than the Flu
first_paragraph: For a spiky sphere just 120 nanometers wide, the coronavirus can be a remarkably cosmopolitan traveler.

title: Want to Be a Doctor? Take Your Chances in a Closed Room With Strangers
first_paragraph: Students applying to graduate schools can take the GRE, the LSAT and other tests at home this year because of the risks of gathering in an exam room for hours during the pandemic. But applicants sitting for the longest and arguably most grueling graduate entrance exam, the Medical College Admission Test, do not have that option.

title: The Coronavirus Is New, but Your Immune System Might Still Recognize It
first_paragraph: Eight months ago, the new coronavirus was unknown. But to some of our immune cells, the virus was already something of a familiar foe.

title: Even Asymptomatic People Carry the Coronavirus in High Amounts
first_paragraph: Of all the coronavirus’s qualities, perhaps the most surprising has been that seemingly healthy people can spread it to others. This trait has made the virus difficult to contain, and continues to challenge efforts to identify and isolate infected people.

title: Health Experts to F.D.A.: Make Your Vaccine Deliberations Public
first_paragraph: A coalition of leading public health experts urged the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday night to conduct full safety and efficacy reviews of potential coronavirus vaccines before making the products widely available to the public.

title: Do You Want to Be a Vaccine Volunteer?
first_paragraph: Maybe you are an altruist looking for a way to help fight the coronavirus. Maybe you are hoping to be among the first to try an experimental vaccine. Or maybe you are just bored or could use a few hundred dollars.

title: Forget Spas and Bars. Hotels Tout Housekeeping to Lure Back Travelers.
first_paragraph: When Beau Phillips checked into a hotel near Toledo recently, a table in front of the counter barricaded him from getting too close to the clerk, who wore a mask and stood behind a plastic window.

title: Scientists Are Optimistic About New Vaccine Studies From Novavax
first_paragraph: Novavax, the little-known Maryland company that received a $1.6 billion deal from the federal government for its experimental coronavirus vaccine, announced encouraging results in two preliminary studies on Tuesday.

title: ‘The Biggest Monster’ Is Spreading. And It’s Not the Coronavirus.
first_paragraph: It begins with a mild fever and malaise, followed by a painful cough and shortness of breath. The infection prospers in crowds, spreading to people in close reach. Containing an outbreak requires contact tracing, as well as isolation and treatment of the sick for weeks or months.

title: Birx Says U.S. Epidemic Is in a ‘New Phase’
first_paragraph: Dr. Deborah L. Birx, the Trump administration’s coronavirus coordinator, said on Sunday that the nation was in a “new phase” of the coronavirus epidemic that was much more sprawling across the country than last spring’s outbreaks in major cities like New York and Seattle.

title: The Coronavirus Infected Hundreds at a Georgia Summer Camp
first_paragraph: As schools and universities plan for the new academic year, and administrators grapple with complex questions about how to keep young people safe, a new report about a coronavirus outbreak at a sleepaway camp in Georgia provides fresh reasons for concern.

title: Covid-19 Tests Are in Short Supply. Should You Still Get One?
first_paragraph: First, health officials said you should not get tested for the coronavirus unless you had symptoms. Then the message shifted: Mass testing was essential to trace and contain the pandemic.

title: Sanofi and GlaxoSmithKline Snag Biggest Coronavirus Vaccine Deal Yet
first_paragraph: The French drug maker Sanofi said on Friday that it had secured an agreement of up to $2.1 billion to supply the U.S. federal government with 100 million doses of its experimental coronavirus vaccine, the largest such deal announced to date.

title: Contact Tracing Is Failing in Many States. Here’s Why.
first_paragraph: In Arizona’s most populated region, the coronavirus is so ubiquitous that contact tracers have been unable to reach a fraction of those infected.

title: Children May Carry Coronavirus at High Levels, Study Finds
first_paragraph: It has been a comforting refrain in the national conversation about reopening schools: Young children are mostly spared by the coronavirus and don’t seem to spread it to others, at least not very often.

title: Aboard the Diamond Princess, a Case Study in Aerosol Transmission
first_paragraph: In a year of endless viral outbreaks, the details of the Diamond Princess tragedy seem like ancient history. On Jan. 20, one infected passenger boarded the cruise ship; a month later, more than 700 of the 3,711 passengers and crew members had tested positive, with many falling seriously ill. The invader moved as swiftly and invisibly as the perpetrators on Agatha Christie’s Orient Express, leaving doctors and health officials with only fragmentary evidence to sift through.

title: Johnson & Johnson’s Coronavirus Vaccine Protects Monkeys, Study Finds
first_paragraph: An experimental coronavirus vaccine developed by Johnson & Johnson protected monkeys from infection in a new study. It is the second vaccine candidate to show promising results in monkeys this week.

title: A Covid Patient Goes Home After a Rare Double Lung Transplant
first_paragraph: The last thing that Mayra Ramirez remembers from the emergency room at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago is calling her family to say she had Covid, was about to be put on a ventilator and needed her mother to make medical decisions for her.

title: Old Vaccines May Stop the Coronavirus, Study Hints. Scientists Are Skeptical.
first_paragraph: Billions of dollars are being invested in the development of vaccines against the coronavirus. Until one arrives, many scientists have turned to tried-and-true vaccines to see whether they may confer broad protection, and may reduce the risk of coronavirus infection, as well.

title: School Closures in the Spring Saved Lives, Study Asserts
first_paragraph: In a new analysis, pediatric researchers have estimated that the states’ decisions to close schools last spring likely saved tens of thousands of lives from Covid-19 and prevented many more coronavirus infections.

title: A Viral Epidemic Splintering Into Deadly Pieces
first_paragraph: Once again, the coronavirus is ascendant. As infections mount across the country, it is dawning on Americans that the epidemic is now unstoppable, and that no corner of the nation will be left untouched.

title: Masks May Reduce Viral Dose, Some Experts Say
first_paragraph: findings that have driven much of the conversation around these crucial accessories during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Your Coronavirus Antibodies Are Disappearing. Should You Care?
first_paragraph: Your blood carries the memory of every pathogen you’ve ever encountered. If you’ve been infected with the coronavirus, your body most likely remembers that, too.

title: C.D.C. Calls on Schools to Reopen, Downplaying Health Risks
first_paragraph: The nation’s top public health agency issued a full-throated call to reopen schools in a statement that aligned with President Trump’s pressure on communities, listing numerous benefits of being in school and downplaying the potential health risks.

title: FEMA Sends Faulty Protective Gear to Nursing Homes Battling Virus
first_paragraph: Expired surgical masks. Isolation gowns that resemble oversize trash bags. Extra-small gloves that are all but useless for the typical health worker’s hands.

title: ‘It’s Like Groundhog Day’: Coronavirus Testing Labs Again Lack Key Supplies
first_paragraph: Labs across the country are facing backlogs in coronavirus testing thanks in part to a shortage of tiny pieces of tapered plastic.

title: Covid-19 Patients No Longer Need Tests to End Isolation
first_paragraph: Most Americans recovering from Covid-19 can come out of isolation without further testing to show they no longer carry the coronavirus, federal health officials said on Wednesday.

title: Can You Get Covid-19 Again? It’s Very Unlikely, Experts Say
first_paragraph: The anecdotes are alarming. A woman in Los Angeles seemed to recover from Covid-19, but weeks later took a turn for the worse and tested positive again. A New Jersey doctor claimed several patients healed from one bout only to become reinfected with the coronavirus. And another doctor said a second round of illness was a reality for some people, and was much more severe.

title: States Must Standardize Coronavirus Data, Former C.D.C. Director Says
first_paragraph: As criticism of the Trump administration’s response to the coronavirus pandemic intensifies, a former director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Tuesday called on state health officials to start reporting coronavirus data in a detailed and uniform fashion, rather than the disorganized hodgepodge most states now produce.

title: Coronavirus Infections Much Higher Than Reported Cases in Parts of U.S., Study Shows
first_paragraph: The number of people infected with the coronavirus in different parts of the United States was anywhere from two to 13 times higher than the reported rates for those regions, according to data released Tuesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: During Coronavirus Lockdowns, Some Doctors Wondered: Where Are the Preemies?
first_paragraph: This spring, as countries around the world told people to stay home to slow the spread of the coronavirus, doctors in neonatal intensive care units were noticing something strange: Premature births were falling, in some cases drastically.

title: Older Children Spread the Coronavirus Just as Much as Adults, Large Study Finds
first_paragraph: In the heated debate over reopening schools, one burning question has been whether and how efficiently children can spread the virus to others.

title: Mistrust of a Coronavirus Vaccine Could Imperil Widespread Immunity
first_paragraph: Almost daily, President Trump and leaders worldwide say they are racing to develop a coronavirus vaccine, in perhaps the most urgent mission in the history of medical science. But the repeated assurances of near-miraculous speed are exacerbating a problem that has largely been overlooked and one that public health experts say must be addressed now: persuading people to actually get the shot.

title: Inside Johnson & Johnson’s Nonstop Hunt for a Coronavirus Vaccine
first_paragraph: Each workday morning in March, Noe Mercado drove through the desolate streets of Boston to a tall glass building on Blackfan Circle, in the heart of the city’s biotech hub. Most residents had gone into hiding from the coronavirus, but Mr. Mercado had an essential job: searching for a vaccine against this new, devastating pathogen.

title: How a Struggling Company Won $1.6 Billion to Make a Coronavirus Vaccine
first_paragraph: In late February, as the coronavirus spread around the world, Dr. Richard Hatchett, the head of an international nonprofit that gives money to vaccine developers, got on an important call to discuss vaccine candidates after his plane touched down at London’s Heathrow Airport.

title: Citing Educational Risks, Scientific Panel Urges That Schools Reopen
first_paragraph: Wading into the contentious debate over reopening schools, an influential committee of scientists and educators on Wednesday recommended that, wherever possible, younger children and those with special needs should attend school in person.

title: First Coronavirus Vaccine Tested in Humans Shows Early Promise
first_paragraph: An experimental coronavirus vaccine made by the biotech company Moderna provoked a promising immune response against the virus and appeared safe in the first 45 people who received it, researchers reported on Tuesday in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: 2 Stylists Had Coronavirus, but Wore Masks. 139 Clients Didn’t Fall Sick.
first_paragraph: Vigilant mask wearing might have spared nearly 140 people from catching the coronavirus at a hair salon in Missouri, according to a report published on Tuesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. In May, the people interacted with two hair stylists with confirmed coronavirus infections, but none ended up showing symptoms of Covid-19.

title: Baby Was Infected With Coronavirus in Womb, Study Reports
first_paragraph: Researchers on Tuesday reported strong evidence that the coronavirus can be transmitted from a pregnant woman to a fetus.

title: The Flu May Linger in the Air, Just Like the Coronavirus
first_paragraph: The coronavirus is not the flu. But the two viruses have something crucial in common: Both have been described as spreading primarily through close contact with symptomatic people or the surfaces they’ve touched.

title: You’d Rather Get a Coronavirus Vaccine Through Your Nose
first_paragraph: Of the 150-plus coronavirus vaccines in development around the world, the lion’s share will rely on a needle prick to make their way into the body.

title: Trump’s Health Officials Warn More Will Die as Covid Cases Rise
first_paragraph: Two of the Trump administration’s top health officials acknowledged Sunday that the country is facing a very serious situation with the onslaught of rising coronavirus cases in several states, striking a far more sober tone than President Trump at this stage of the pandemic in the United States.

title: How to Reopen Schools: What Science and Other Countries Teach Us
first_paragraph: As school districts across the United States consider whether and how to restart in-person classes, their challenge is complicated by a pair of fundamental uncertainties: No nation has tried to send children back to school with the virus raging at levels like America’s, and the scientific research about transmission in classrooms is limited.

title: Study of Coronavirus in Pregnant Women Finds Striking Racial Differences
first_paragraph: Black and Latino pregnant women in Philadelphia are five times as likely as their white counterparts to have been exposed to the coronavirus, according to data collected from nearly 1,300 women between April and June.

title: Sutter Health’s Request to Delay $575 Million Settlement Is Denied
first_paragraph: Despite citing the surge in coronavirus cases and economic fallout from the pandemic in California, Sutter Health failed to persuade a state judge on Thursday to delay the $575 million settlement it reached last December over accusations of price gouging and monopolistic practices.

title: The Coronavirus Can Be Airborne Indoors, W.H.O. Says
first_paragraph: The coronavirus may linger in the air in crowded indoor spaces, spreading from one person to the next, the World Health Organization acknowledged on Thursday.

title: These Scientists Raced to Find a Covid-19 Drug. Then the Virus Found Them.
first_paragraph: In January, as a frightening new virus filled hospital wards in Wuhan, China, Stephanie Giordano, a 25-year-old researcher at the drugmaker Regeneron, in a suburb of New York City, began working on a treatment for the disease.

title: Grave Shortages of Protective Gear Flare Again as Covid Cases Surge
first_paragraph: As coronavirus cases surge across the country, hospitals, nursing homes and private medical practices are facing a problem many had hoped would be resolved by now: a dire shortage of respirator masks, isolation gowns and disposable gloves that protect front-line medical workers from infection.

title: 8 Questions From a Disease Detective on the Pandemic’s Origins
first_paragraph: For decades, Dr. Daniel R. Lucey, an infectious disease specialist at Georgetown University, has crisscrossed the globe to study epidemics and their origins. His attention now is on the Covid-19 pandemic, which first came to public notice late last year in Wuhan, China. Its exact beginnings are sufficiently clouded that the World Health Organization has begun a wide inquiry into its roots. The advance team is to leave for China this weekend, and Dr. Lucey has publicly encouraged the health agency to address what he considers eight top questions.

title: W.H.O. to Review Evidence of Airborne Transmission of Coronavirus
first_paragraph: After hundreds of experts urged the World Health Organization to review mounting scientific research, the agency acknowledged on Tuesday that airborne transmission of the coronavirus may be a threat in indoor spaces.

title: U.S. Will Pay $1.6 Billion to Novavax for Coronavirus Vaccine
first_paragraph: The federal government will pay the vaccine maker Novavax $1.6 billion to expedite the development of a coronavirus vaccine. It’s the largest deal to date from Operation Warp Speed, the sprawling federal effort to make coronavirus vaccines and treatments available to the American public as quickly as possible.

title: In Nick Cordero’s Death, a Reminder of Covid-19’s Unknowns
first_paragraph: The death of the Broadway actor Nick Cordero from Covid-19 has shaken people far beyond the theater world, in large part because he was just 41 and reportedly had no underlying health conditions.

title: Airborne Coronavirus: What You Should Do Now
first_paragraph: The coronavirus can stay aloft for hours in tiny droplets in stagnant air, infecting people as they inhale, mounting scientific evidence suggests.

title: A New Generation of Fast Coronavirus Tests Is Coming
first_paragraph: Researchers around the world are working on the next generation of coronavirus tests that give answers in less than an hour, without onerous equipment or highly trained personnel.

title: 239 Experts With One Big Claim: The Coronavirus Is Airborne
first_paragraph: The coronavirus is finding new victims worldwide, in bars and restaurants, offices, markets and casinos, giving rise to frightening clusters of infection that increasingly confirm what many scientists have been saying for months: The virus lingers in the air indoors, infecting those nearby.

title: DNA Inherited From Neanderthals May Increase Risk of Covid-19
first_paragraph: A stretch of DNA linked to Covid-19 was passed down from Neanderthals 60,000 years ago, according to a new study.

title: U.S. Coronavirus Cases Are Rising Sharply, but Deaths Are Still Down
first_paragraph: After a minor late-spring lull, the number of confirmed coronavirus cases in the United States is once again on the rise. States like Arizona, Florida and Texas are seeing some of their highest numbers to date, and as the nation hurtles further into summer, the surge shows few signs of stopping.

title: Can an Algorithm Predict the Pandemic’s Next Moves?
first_paragraph: Judging when to tighten, or loosen, the local economy has become the world’s most consequential guessing game, and each policymaker has his or her own instincts and benchmarks. The point when hospitals reach 70 percent capacity is a red flag, for instance; so are upticks in coronavirus case counts and deaths.

title: Did a Mutation Help the Coronavirus Spread? More Evidence, but Lingering Questions
first_paragraph: For months, scientists have debated whether a variant of the coronavirus that has come to predominate in much of the world did so partly because it is more transmissible than other viruses.

title: Federal Officials Turn to a New Testing Strategy as Infections Surge
first_paragraph: The Trump administration plans to adopt a decades-old testing strategy that will vastly increase the number of coronavirus tests performed in the United States and permit widespread tracking of the virus as it surges across the country.

title: Here’s What Recovery From Covid-19 Looks Like for Many Survivors
first_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of seriously ill coronavirus patients who survive and leave the hospital are facing a new and difficult challenge: recovery. Many are struggling to overcome a range of troubling residual symptoms, and some problems may persist for months, years or even the rest of their lives.

title: Researchers Debate Infecting People on Purpose to Test Coronavirus Vaccines
first_paragraph: One way to quickly see if a coronavirus vaccine works would be to immunize healthy people and then deliberately expose them to the virus, some researchers are suggesting.

title: In Early February, the Coronavirus Was Moving Through New York
first_paragraph: A new study offers the first physical evidence that the coronavirus was circulating at low levels in New York City as early as the first week of February.

title: Remdesivir, the First Coronavirus Drug, Gets a Price Tag
first_paragraph: Remdesivir, the first drug shown to be effective against the coronavirus, will be distributed under an unusual agreement with the federal government that establishes nonnegotiable prices and prioritizes American patients, health officials announced on Monday.

title: Actual Coronavirus Infections Vastly Undercounted, C.D.C. Data Shows
first_paragraph: The number of coronavirus infections in many parts of the United States is more than 10 times higher than the reported rate, according to data released on Friday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Obamacare Faces Unprecedented Test as Economy Sinks
first_paragraph: The Affordable Care Act, the landmark health law that has been a subject of caustic debate for more than a decade, is being tested as never before, as millions of Americans lose their jobs and medical coverage in the midst of the nation’s gravest health crisis in a century.

title: Study Suggests Coronavirus Emerged Much Earlier Than Thought. Some Are Skeptical.
first_paragraph: In a study not yet published in a journal, scientists have reported that the new coronavirus was present in wastewater in Barcelona, Spain in March 2019, a finding that, if confirmed, would show that the pathogen had emerged much earlier than previously thought.

title: In Norway, Gymgoers Avoid Infections as Virus Recedes
first_paragraph: Like many countries, Norway ordered all gyms to close in March to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. But unlike any other nation, Norway also funded a rigorous study to determine whether the closings were really necessary.

title: Is It Safe to Go Back to the Dentist?
first_paragraph: At Dr. Todd Bertman’s office, the receptionist wears a plastic face shield. So do the hygienist and the nine doctors in the practice in Manhattan’s East Village.

title: Study Raises Concerns for Pregnant Women With the Coronavirus
first_paragraph: Pregnant women infected with the coronavirus are more likely to be hospitalized, admitted to an intensive care unit and put on a ventilator than are infected women who are not pregnant, according to a new government analysis.

title: Breakthrough Drug for Covid-19 May Be Risky for Mild Cases
first_paragraph: Scientists in Britain announced a major breakthrough in the battle against the coronavirus last week, reporting they had found the first drug to reduce deaths among critically ill Covid-19 patients.

title: Regeneron Funneled Kickbacks Through a Patient Charity, Federal Lawsuit Claims
first_paragraph: The drugmaker Regeneron funneled tens of millions of dollars to a charity that paid the out-of-pocket costs for patients who took the company’s expensive eye drug, then lied to internal auditors about it, according to a lawsuit filed Wednesday by federal prosecutors in Massachusetts.

title: Sanofi Accelerates Its Timeline for Coronavirus Vaccine Development
first_paragraph: After lagging behind its competitors in starting clinical trials, the French drugmaker Sanofi has announced plans to speed a vaccine development timeline that could yield approval from regulatory authorities sometime next year, perhaps in the first half of 2021, the company announced on Tuesday.

title: A Simple Way to Save Lives as Covid-19 Hits Poorer Nations.
first_paragraph: As the coronavirus pandemic hits more impoverished countries with fragile health care systems, global health authorities are scrambling for supplies of a simple treatment that saves lives: oxygen.

title: F.D.A. Warns of Potentially Toxic Hand Sanitizers
first_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration is warning consumers to avoid nine hand sanitizer products manufactured in Mexico because, it said, they may contain methanol, a substance that can be toxic if absorbed through the skin or ingested.

title: Gilead to Test a Version of Remdesivir That Can Be Inhaled
first_paragraph: The American biopharmaceutical company Gilead Sciences will soon start trials of an inhalable version of remdesivir, an antiviral drug that has shown promise as a therapeutic against the coronavirus in early trials, according to a statement released Monday.

title: Public Health Experts Reject President’s View of Fading Pandemic
first_paragraph: Public health experts warned on Sunday that the coronavirus pandemic is not going away anytime soon. They directly contradicted President Trump’s promise that the disease that has infected more than two million Americans would “fade away” and his remarks that disparaged the value of evidence from coronavirus tests.

title: The Pandemic’s Mental Toll: More Ripple Than Tsunami
first_paragraph: The psychological fallout from the coronavirus pandemic has yet to fully show itself, but some experts have forecast a tsunami of new disorders, and news accounts have amplified that message.

title: Federal Agency Halts Studies of Hydroxychloroquine, Drug Trump Promoted
first_paragraph: The National Institutes of Health said Saturday that it had stopped two clinical trials of hydroxychloroquine, the malaria drug that President Trump promoted to treat and prevent the coronavirus, one because the drug was unlikely to be effective and the other because not enough patients signed up to participate.

title: Coronavirus Attacks the Lungs. A Federal Agency Just Halted Funding for New Lung Treatments.
first_paragraph: When the coronavirus kills, it attacks the lungs, filling them with fluid and robbing the body of oxygen. In chest X-rays, clear lungs turn white, a sign of how dangerously sick patients are.

title: Scientists Take Aim at Another Coronavirus Study in a Major Journal
first_paragraph: A group of leading scientists is calling on a journal to retract a paper on the effectiveness of masks, saying the study has “egregious errors” and contains numerous “verifiably false” statements.

title: As Some Sleepaway Summer Camps Close Down, Others Balance the Risks
first_paragraph: In 1993, after wrapping up her 10th sleepaway summer at Camp Louise, in Maryland, Dr. Megan Wollman-Rosenwald realized that she didn’t want the experience to end. So she found a way to game the system: She went to medical school, then returned in 2016 to her childhood mainstay as an on-site doctor for one week every year.

title: Dr. Tomisaku Kawasaki, Who Pinpointed a Mysterious Disease, Dies at 95
first_paragraph: Dr. Tomisaku Kawasaki, who in 1967 first identified a disease in children that remains mysterious today and that has recently been in the news in relation to Covid-19, died on June 5 in Tokyo. He was 95.

title: Why People Are Still Avoiding the Doctor (It’s Not the Virus)
first_paragraph: At first, Kristina Hartman put off getting medical care out of concern about the coronavirus. But then she lost her job as an administrator at a truck manufacturer in McKinney, Texas.

title: Flushing the Toilet May Fling Coronavirus Aerosols All Over
first_paragraph: Here’s one more behavior to be hyper-aware of in order to prevent coronavirus transmission: what you do after you use the toilet.

title: F.D.A. Revokes Emergency Approval of Malaria Drugs Promoted by Trump
first_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration said on Monday that it was revoking emergency authorization of two malaria drugs to treat Covid-19 in hospitalized patients, saying that they are “unlikely to be effective” and could carry potential risks.

title: The Pandemic Claims New Victims: Prestigious Medical Journals
first_paragraph: One study promised that popular blood-pressure drugs were safe for people infected with the coronavirus. Another paper warned that anti-malaria drugs endorsed by President Trump actually were dangerous to these patients.

title: Events Like Trump Rally Are ‘Perfect Storm’ for Viral Spread, Experts Say
first_paragraph: The coronavirus won’t be loosening its grip on the United States any time soon, leading infectious disease experts said on Sunday. They are also uncertain how the viral spread will be affected by the patchwork of states reopening businesses and by large events like protests and President Trump’s upcoming campaign rallies.

title: C.D.C. Calls for Masks at Large Gatherings, Warning of Crowd Risks
first_paragraph: Three months after the country’s top public health agency, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, abruptly stopped holding regular briefings on the coronavirus pandemic, its director, Dr. Robert Redfield, restarted them on Friday amid growing calls for the agency to claim a more prominent role in the virus response.

title: Coronavirus Can Set Off a ‘Cytokine Storm.’ These Drugs May Calm It.
first_paragraph: Many coronavirus patients seem to get better at first, then rapidly decline and are overtaken by an overwhelming immune response that causes the body to turn on itself.

title: Covid-19 Patient Gets Double Lung Transplant, Offering Hope for Others
first_paragraph: A young woman whose lungs were destroyed by the coronavirus received a double lung transplant last week at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago, the hospital reported on Thursday, the first known lung transplant in the United States for Covid-19.

title: After Outbreak on Carrier Roosevelt, Many Have Antibodies
first_paragraph: The agonizing tale of the coronavirus outbreak on the carrier Theodore Roosevelt starting in March led to the infection of hundreds of crew members, an emergency stop in Guam, the removal of the ship’s captain and the resignation of the acting Navy secretary.

title: Where Protesters Go, Street Medics Follow
first_paragraph: When Safa Abdulkadir, a first-year medical student at the University of Minnesota, attended a protest in Minneapolis in response to the killing of George Floyd, she had no intention of putting her medical knowledge to use. It was May 26, one day after Mr. Floyd was killed, and although Ms. Abdulkadir was attending the demonstration as a protester, she made a point of wearing her white lab coat, a common symbol of medical professionals and students.

title: In the W.H.O.’s Coronavirus Stumbles, Some Scientists See a Pattern
first_paragraph: Even as the World Health Organization leads the worldwide response to the coronavirus pandemic, the agency is failing to take stock of rapidly evolving research findings and to communicate clearly about them, several scientists warned on Tuesday.

title: Fauci Warns That the Coronavirus Pandemic Is Far From Over
first_paragraph: In a wide-ranging talk to biotech executives, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci delivered a grim assessment of the devastation wrought around the world by the coronavirus.

title: Testing Nursing Home Workers Can Help Stop Coronavirus. But Who Should Pay?
first_paragraph: Like all nursing home workers in New York State, Shikilia Davis is required to get a test for coronavirus twice a week, part of a state order aimed at containing the startling death toll of residents in nursing homes.

title: George Floyd Protests Add New Front Line for Coronavirus Doctors
first_paragraph: Outside medical centers across the country, doctors and other health care workers have been stopping work in recent days for 8 minutes and 46 seconds to join in protesting the death of George Floyd, who was pinned down by a police officer in Minneapolis for that amount of time before his death.

title: How to Navigate Your Community Reopening? Remember the Four C’s
first_paragraph: When the country was largely under lockdown, at least the rules were mostly clear. Essential workers ventured out; everyone else sheltered in. Bars and restaurants were closed except for dining out; hair salons and spas were shuttered. Outings were limited to the supermarket or the drugstore.

title: Navigating Home Care During the Pandemic
first_paragraph: In March, Amy Carrier asked one of the two women who provided home care for her mother to stop coming to work.

title: W.H.O. Finally Endorses Masks to Prevent Coronavirus Transmission
first_paragraph: Long after most nations urged their citizens to wear masks, and after months of hand-wringing about the quality of the evidence available, the World Health Organization on Friday endorsed the use of face masks by the public to reduce transmission of the coronavirus.

title: Disordered Eating in a Disordered Time
first_paragraph: For Emily Roll, a performance artist in southeast Michigan, the beginning of 2020 offered a glimpse of hope for an anorexia recovery that was a long time coming. After 15 years of struggling with an eating disorder, Mx. Roll began seeing a nutritionist and therapist. They were spending each day busy on their feet: doing yoga, working as a medical actor at a hospital, barista-ing at a coffee shop. That meant little time or energy for overexercising and undereating.

title: Two Huge Covid-19 Studies Are Retracted After Scientists Sound Alarms
first_paragraph: The studies, published in renowned scientific journals, produced astounding results and altered the course of research into the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Doctors Heavily Overprescribed Antibiotics Early in the Pandemic
first_paragraph: The desperately ill patients who deluged the emergency room at Detroit Medical Center in March and April exhibited the telltale symptoms of the coronavirus: high fevers and infection-riddled lungs that left them gasping for air.

title: 2,000 Free Meals a Night, Seasoned by Silicon Valley Chefs
first_paragraph: Andres Pantoja, an up-and-coming Silicon Valley sous chef, spent his pre-pandemic evenings delicately preparing the $115 plate of lamb chops and deboning the $42 Psari Plaki whole fish at a fashionable restaurant here. It is frantic work serving 200 upscale meals a night.

title: E.R. Visits Drop Sharply During Pandemic
first_paragraph: Emergency room visits in the United States have dropped sharply during the pandemic, underscoring concerns that people with serious medical conditions, like heart attacks, are avoiding hospitals, according to a new analysis released on Wednesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Malaria Drug Promoted by Trump Did Not Prevent Covid Infections, Study Finds
first_paragraph: The malaria drug hydroxychloroquine did not prevent Covid-19 in a rigorous study of 821 people who had been exposed to patients infected with the virus, researchers from the University of Minnesota and Canada are reporting on Wednesday.

title: Contact Tracing With Your Phone: It’s Easier but There Are Tradeoffs
first_paragraph: The handshake came first. Then the high-five, fist bump and more recently, the elbow touch. Canadian researchers are now working on a new greeting, the CanShake.

title: Who’s Wearing a Mask? Women, Democrats and City Dwellers
first_paragraph: As states continue to lift restrictions that were put in place to curb the coronavirus outbreak and as Americans start going out in public again, recent surveys suggest that gender, political affiliation and education level are factors that have a bearing on who is wearing a mask, and who isn’t.

title: Scientists Question Medical Data Used in Second Coronavirus Study
first_paragraph: Since the outbreak began, researchers have rushed to publish new findings about the coronavirus spreading swiftly through the world. On Tuesday, for the second time in recent days, a group of clinicians and researchers has questioned the data used in studies in two prominent medical journals.

title: Medical Workers Should Use Respirator Masks, Not Surgical Masks
first_paragraph: A new analysis of 172 studies, funded by the World Health Organization, confirms what scientists have said for months: N95 and other respirator masks are far superior to surgical or cloth masks in protecting essential medical workers against the coronavirus.

title: Will Protests Set Off a Second Viral Wave?
first_paragraph: Mass protests against police brutality that have brought thousands of people out of their homes and onto the streets in cities across America are raising the specter of new coronavirus outbreaks, prompting political leaders, physicians and public health experts to warn that the crowds could cause a surge in cases.

title: Do Runners Need to Wear Masks?
first_paragraph: Jane Rosen began yelling sometime in April. By May, it had become routine. The incidents usually occur near her minivan, which she parks alongside Central Park in New York City.

title: Blaming China for Pandemic, Trump Says U.S. Will Leave the W.H.O.
first_paragraph: After spending weeks accusing the World Health Organization of helping the Chinese government cover up the early days of the coronavirus epidemic in China, President Trump said on Friday that the United States would terminate its relationship with the agency.

title: It’s Not Whether You Were Exposed to the Virus. It’s How Much.
first_paragraph: When experts recommend wearing masks, staying at least six feet away from others, washing your hands frequently and avoiding crowded spaces, what they’re really saying is: Try to minimize the amount of virus you encounter.

title: Scientists Question Validity of Major Hydroxychloroquine Study
first_paragraph: More than 100 scientists and clinicians have questioned the authenticity of a massive hospital database that was the basis for an influential study published last week that concluded that treating people who have Covid-19 with chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine did not help and might have increased the risk of abnormal heart rhythms and death.

title: Coronavirus Epidemics Began Later Than Believed, Study Concludes
first_paragraph: The first confirmed coronavirus infections in Europe and the United States, discovered in January, did not ignite the epidemics that followed, according to a close analysis of hundreds of viral genomes.

title: Coronavirus Isn’t Keeping Florida Crowds From SpaceX Launch
first_paragraph: NASA has urged spectators to stay away from the Kennedy Space Center for Wednesday’s SpaceX launch to limit the spread of the coronavirus. But officials from cities and counties around the launch site, an area known as Florida’s Space Coast, are expecting large crowds to gather to watch the country’s first astronaut launch in nine years.

title: ‘This Is Not the Hunger Games’: National Testing Strategy Draws Concerns
first_paragraph: The Trump administration’s new testing strategy, released Sunday to Congress, holds individual states responsible for planning and carrying out all coronavirus testing, while planning to provide some supplies needed for the tests.

title: Fear of Covid-19 Leads Other Patients to Decline Critical Treatment
